   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Bangladesh</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the People's Republic of Bangladesh. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Bangladesh (disambiguation)">Bangladesh (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in South Asia
      </div>

               <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> <a href="/wiki/Garo_people" title="Garo people">Garos</a> </li>
               <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> <a href="/wiki/Bisnupriya_Manipuri_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Bisnupriya Manipuri people">Bisnupriya Manipuris</a> </li>
              </ul> 
             </div></li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>

         <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Bengali_alphabet" title="Bengali alphabet">Bengali text</a>.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Bangla_script_display_help" title="Wikipedia:Bangla script display help">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a>.</td>

      <p><b>Bangladesh</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="/Å/: 'ng' in 'sing'">Å</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/É/: 'a' in 'about'">É</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/É/: 'e' in 'dress'">É</span><span title="/Ê/: 'sh' in 'shy'">Ê</span></span>/</a></span></span>;<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>: <span lang="bn">à¦¬à¦¾à¦à¦²à¦¾à¦¦à§à¦¶</span>, <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Bengali" title="Help:IPA/Bengali">[ËbaÅlaËdeÊ]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bn-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6.oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0a/Bn-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6.oga" class="internal" title="Bn-à¦¬à¦¾à¦à¦²à¦¾à¦¦à§à¦¶.oga">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>People's Republic of Bangladesh</b>, is a country in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">eighth-most populous country</a> in the world, with a population exceeding 163 million people, in an area of 147,570 square kilometres (56,980&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), making it one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population_density" title="List of countries and dependencies by population density">most densely populated countries</a> in the world. Bangladesh shares land borders with <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> to the west, north, and east, <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> to the southeast, and the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a> to the south. It is narrowly separated from <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Siliguri_Corridor" title="Siliguri Corridor">Siliguri Corridor</a>, and from <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> by <a href="/wiki/Sikkim" title="Sikkim">Sikkim</a>, in the north, respectively. <a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a>, the capital and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Bangladesh" title="List of cities and towns in Bangladesh">largest city</a>, is the nation's economic, political, and cultural hub. <a href="/wiki/Chittagong" title="Chittagong">Chittagong</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Chittagong" title="Port of Chittagong">largest seaport</a> is the second-largest city. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh forms the larger and eastern part of the <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> region.<sup id="cite_ref-EyetsemitanGire2003_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EyetsemitanGire2003-17">[17]</a></sup> According to the ancient Indian texts, <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">RÄmÄyana</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">MahÄbhÄrata</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Vanga_Kingdom" title="Vanga Kingdom">Vanga Kingdom</a>, one of the namesakes of the Bengal region, was a strong naval power. In the ancient and classical periods of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>, the territory was home to many principalities, including the <a href="/wiki/Pundravardhana" title="Pundravardhana">Pundra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gangaridai" title="Gangaridai">Gangaridai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gauda_Kingdom" title="Gauda Kingdom">Gauda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samatata" title="Samatata">Samatata</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Harikela" title="Harikela">Harikela</a>. It was also a <a href="/wiki/Mauryan_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Mauryan Empire">Mauryan province</a> under the reign of <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a>. The principalities were notable for their overseas trade, contacts with the Roman world, the export of fine <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">muslin</a> and silk to the Middle East, and spreading of philosophy and art to <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chandra_dynasty" title="Chandra dynasty">Chandra dynasty</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sena_dynasty" title="Sena dynasty">Sena dynasty</a> were the last pre-Islamic Bengali <a href="/wiki/Middle_kingdoms_of_India" title="Middle kingdoms of India">middle kingdoms</a>. <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> was introduced during the Pala Empire, through trade with the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">AbbÄsid Caliphate</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-kumar_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kumar-18">[18]</a></sup> but following the <a href="/wiki/Ghurid_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghurid Empire">Ghurid</a> conquests led by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Bakhtiyar_Khalji" title="Muhammad bin Bakhtiyar Khalji">BakhtiyÄr KhaljÄ«</a>, the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> and preaching of <a href="/wiki/Shah_Jalal" title="Shah Jalal">Shah JalÄl</a> in the north-east, it spread across the entire region. In 1576, the wealthy <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate" title="Bengal Sultanate">Bengal Sultanate</a> was absorbed into the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, but its rule was briefly interrupted by the <a href="/wiki/Sur_Empire" title="Sur Empire">SÅ«r Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughal Bengal">Mughal Bengal</a>, worth 12% of world GDP (late 17th century), waved the <a href="/wiki/Proto-industrialization" title="Proto-industrialization">Proto-industrialization</a>, showed signs of a possible <a href="/wiki/Industrial_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrial revolution">Industrial revolution</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ray_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ray-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sengupta_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sengupta-20">[20]</a></sup> established relations with the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch</a> and <a href="/wiki/English_East_India_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="English East India Company">English East India Company</a>, and became also the basis of the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Mughal_War" title="Anglo-Mughal War">Anglo-Mughal War</a>. Following the death of Emperor <a href="/wiki/Aurangzeb" title="Aurangzeb">AurangzÄb Älamgir</a> and Governor <a href="/wiki/Shaista_Khan" title="Shaista Khan">ShÄista KhÄn</a> in the early 1700s, the region became a semi-independent state under the <a href="/wiki/Nawabs_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Nawabs of Bengal">Nawabs of Bengal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Siraj_Ud-Daulah" class="mw-redirect" title="Siraj Ud-Daulah">SirÄj ud-Daulah</a>, the last Nawab of Bengal, was defeated by the <a href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="British East India Company">British East India Company</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a> in 1757 and the whole region fell under <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">Company rule</a> by 1793.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the decline of the British <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Bengal Presidency</a>, the borders of modern Bangladesh were established with the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1947)" title="Partition of Bengal (1947)">partition of Bengal</a> in August 1947 at the time of <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partition of India</a>, when the region became <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a> as a part of the newly formed <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-22">[22]</a></sup> Later the rise of a pro-democracy movement thrived on <a href="/wiki/Bengali_nationalism" title="Bengali nationalism">Bengali nationalism</a> and self-determination, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Liberation War</a> and eventually resulted in the emergence of Bangladesh as a sovereign and independent nation in 1971. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bengalis" title="Bengalis">Bengalis</a> make up 98% of the total population of Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-à¦¬à¦¾à¦à¦²à¦¾à¦¦à§à¦¶à¦à§_à¦à¦¾à¦¨à§à¦¨_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-à¦¬à¦¾à¦à¦²à¦¾à¦¦à§à¦¶à¦à§_à¦à¦¾à¦¨à§à¦¨-5">[5]</a></sup> The large <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslim</a> population of Bangladesh makes it the <a href="/wiki/Islam_by_country" title="Islam by country">third-largest Muslim-majority country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> The constitution declares Bangladesh a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a>, while establishing Islam as a <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Secularism_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Secularism-24">[24]</a></sup> As a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> in <a href="/wiki/Global_politics" title="Global politics">world politics</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-balancing_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-balancing-25">[25]</a></sup> Bangladesh is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutional republic">constitutional republic</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a> of governance. The country is divided into <a href="/wiki/Divisions_of_Bangladesh" title="Divisions of Bangladesh">eight administrative divisions</a> and <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Bangladesh" title="Districts of Bangladesh">64 districts</a>. Although the country continues to face the challenges of the <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_genocide" title="Rohingya genocide">Rohingya refugee crisis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Bangladesh" title="Corruption in Bangladesh">corruption</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> and the adverse <a href="/wiki/Effects_of_climate_change" title="Effects of climate change">effects of climate change</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Braun-2010_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Braun-2010-28">[28]</a></sup> Bangladesh is one of the <a href="/wiki/Emerging_and_growth-leading_economies" title="Emerging and growth-leading economies">emerging and growth-leading economies</a> of the world, and is also one of the <a href="/wiki/Jim_O%27Neill,_Baron_O%27Neill_of_Gatley#Next_Eleven" title="Jim O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of Gatley">Next Eleven</a> countries, having Asia's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest real GDP growth rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IMF_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF-29">[29]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Bangladesh" title="Economy of Bangladesh">Bangladeshi economy</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">39th-largest in the world by nominal GDP</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">29th-largest by PPP</a>. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Bengal" title="Names of Bengal">Names of Bengal</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The exact origin of the word <i>Bangla</i> is unknown, though it is believed to come from "Vanga", an ancient kingdom and geopolitical division on the Ganges delta in the Indian subcontinent. It was located in southern Bengal, with the core region including present-day southwestern Bangladesh and southern West Bengal (India). In <a href="/wiki/Generations_of_Noah" title="Generations of Noah">Abrahamic tradition</a>, it is said to have come from "Bung/Bang", a son of Hind (the son of <a href="/wiki/Ham_(son_of_Noah)" title="Ham (son of Noah)">HÄm</a>, who was a son of <a href="/wiki/Noah_in_Islam" title="Noah in Islam">Noah</a>) who colonised the area for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-riaj_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riaj-30">[30]</a></sup> The suffix <i>"al"</i> came to be added to it from the fact that the ancient <a href="/wiki/Raja" title="Raja">rajas</a> of this land raised mounds of earth 10 feet high and 20 in breadth in lowlands at the foot of the hills which were called "al". From this suffix added to the Bung, the name Bengal arose and gained currency".<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> Support for this view is found in <a href="/wiki/Ghulam_Husain_Salim" title="Ghulam Husain Salim">Ghulam Husain Salim</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Riyaz-us-Salatin" title="Riyaz-us-Salatin">Riyaz-us-Salatin</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-riaj_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riaj-30">[30]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other theories point to a <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> <a href="/wiki/Proto-Dravidian_language" title="Proto-Dravidian language">proto-Dravidian</a> tribe,<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Austric" class="mw-redirect" title="Austric">Austric</a> word "Bonga" (Sun god),<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on a self-published source. (June 2020)">self-published source?</span></a></i>]</sup> and the Iron Age <a href="/wiki/Vanga_Kingdom" title="Vanga Kingdom">Vanga Kingdom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-34">[34]</a></sup> The Indo-Aryan suffix <i>Desh</i> is derived from the Sanskrit word <i>deÅha</i>, which means "land" or "country". Hence, the name <i>Bangladesh</i> means "Land of Bengal" or "Country of Bengal".<sup id="cite_ref-auto3_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-35">[35]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The term <i>Bangla</i> denotes both the <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> region and the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali language</a>. The earliest known usage of the term is the <a href="/wiki/Nesari" title="Nesari">Nesari plate</a> in 805&nbsp;AD. The term <i>Vangaladesa</i> is found in 11th-century South Indian records.<sup id="cite_ref-auto3_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The term gained official status during the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sultanate of Bengal">Sultanate of Bengal</a> in the 14th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Ahmed2004_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2004-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shamsuddin_Ilyas_Shah" title="Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah">Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah</a> proclaimed himself as the first "<a href="/wiki/Shah" title="Shah">Shah</a> of Bangala" in 1342.<sup id="cite_ref-Ahmed2004_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2004-37">[37]</a></sup> The word <i>Bangla</i> became the most common name for the region during the Islamic period. The <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> referred to the region as <i><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_settlement_in_Chittagong" title="Portuguese settlement in Chittagong">Bengala</a></i> in the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> The term <i>Bangladesh</i> was often written as two words, <i>Bangla Desh</i>, in the past. Starting in the 1950s, Bengali nationalists used the term in political rallies in <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bengal" title="History of Bengal">History of Bengal</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bangladesh" title="History of Bangladesh">History of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_and_medieval_periods">Early and medieval periods</span></h3> 
      <table class="box-Too_many_photos plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/80/Camera-photo.svg/40px-Camera-photo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/80/Camera-photo.svg/60px-Camera-photo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/80/Camera-photo.svg/80px-Camera-photo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This article contains <b>too many pictures, charts or diagrams</b> for its overall length.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Relevant discussion may be found on the <a href="/wiki/Talk:Bangladesh##" title="Talk:Bangladesh">talk page</a>. Please help to <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by removing or adjusting images in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Images" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Images">Manual of Style on use of images</a>.</span><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:374px;max-width:374px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:216px;max-width:216px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Mahajanapadas_(c._500_BCE).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/214px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png" decoding="async" width="214" height="165" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/321px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/428px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="771"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Vanga_Kingdom" title="Vanga Kingdom">Vanga Kingdom</a> and erstwhile neighbors in ancient South Asia
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:154px;max-width:154px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:South_Asia_historical_AD625_EN.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/South_Asia_historical_AD625_EN.svg/152px-South_Asia_historical_AD625_EN.svg.png" decoding="async" width="152" height="165" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/South_Asia_historical_AD625_EN.svg/228px-South_Asia_historical_AD625_EN.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/South_Asia_historical_AD625_EN.svg/304px-South_Asia_historical_AD625_EN.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1275" data-file-height="1380"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Gauda_Kingdom" title="Gauda Kingdom">Gauda Kingdom</a>, the first independent unified polity in the Bengal region
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Stone_Age" title="Stone Age">Stone Age</a> tools found in Bangladesh indicate human habitation for over 20,000 years,<sup id="cite_ref-Bharadwaj2003_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bharadwaj2003-40">[40]</a></sup> and remnants of <a href="/wiki/Copper_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Copper Age">Copper Age</a> settlements date back 4,000 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Bharadwaj2003_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bharadwaj2003-40">[40]</a></sup> Ancient Bengal was settled by <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic" class="mw-redirect" title="Austroasiatic">Austroasiatics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tibeto-Burman" class="mw-redirect" title="Tibeto-Burman">Tibeto-Burmans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Dravidian people">Dravidians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rigvedic_tribes" class="mw-redirect" title="Rigvedic tribes">Indo-Aryans</a> in consecutive waves of migration.<sup id="cite_ref-Bharadwaj2003_40-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bharadwaj2003-40">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-congress_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-41">[41]</a></sup> Archaeological evidence confirms that by the second millennium BCE, rice-cultivating communities inhabited the region. By the 11th century people lived in systemically-aligned housing, buried their dead, and manufactured copper ornaments and black and red pottery.<sup id="cite_ref-google5_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google5-42">[42]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra" class="mw-redirect" title="Brahmaputra">Brahmaputra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Meghna" class="mw-redirect" title="Meghna">Meghna</a> rivers were natural arteries for communication and transportation,<sup id="cite_ref-google5_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google5-42">[42]</a></sup> and estuaries on the Bay of Bengal permitted maritime trade. The early <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> saw the development of metal weaponry, coinage, agriculture and <a href="/wiki/Irrigation" title="Irrigation">irrigation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-google5_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google5-42">[42]</a></sup> Major urban settlements formed during the late Iron Age, in the mid-<a href="/wiki/First_millennium_BCE" class="mw-redirect" title="First millennium BCE">first millennium BCE</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> when the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Black_Polished_Ware" title="Northern Black Polished Ware">Northern Black Polished Ware</a> culture developed.<sup id="cite_ref-PierisRaven2010_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PierisRaven2010-44">[44]</a></sup> In 1879, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Cunningham" title="Alexander Cunningham">Alexander Cunningham</a> identified <a href="/wiki/Mahasthangarh" title="Mahasthangarh">Mahasthangarh</a> as the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Pundra_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Pundra Kingdom">Pundra Kingdom</a> mentioned in the <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> The oldest inscription in Bangladesh was found in Mahasthangarh and dates from the 3rd century BCE. It is written in the <a href="/wiki/Brahmi_script" title="Brahmi script">Brahmi script</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_world" title="Greco-Roman world">Greek and Roman</a> records of the ancient <a href="/wiki/Gangaridai" title="Gangaridai">Gangaridai</a> Kingdom, which (according to legend) deterred the invasion of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>, are linked to the fort city in <a href="/wiki/Wari-Bateshwar_ruins" title="Wari-Bateshwar ruins">Wari-Bateshwar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-thedailystar1_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thedailystar1-49">[49]</a></sup> The site is also identified with the prosperous trading center of Souanagoura listed on <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy%27s_world_map" title="Ptolemy's world map">Ptolemy's world map</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-google1_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google1-50">[50]</a></sup> Roman geographers noted a large seaport in southeastern Bengal, corresponding to the present-day <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_District" title="Chittagong District">Chittagong</a> region.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:458px;max-width:458px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:242px;max-width:242px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Asia_800ad.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Asia_800ad.jpg/240px-Asia_800ad.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Asia_800ad.jpg/360px-Asia_800ad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Asia_800ad.jpg/480px-Asia_800ad.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2099" data-file-height="1215"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a> was an imperial power during the Late Classical period on the Indian subcontinent, which originated in the region of Bengal
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%81%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%81%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_22.jpg/210px-%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%81%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_22.jpg" decoding="async" width="210" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%81%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_22.jpg/315px-%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%81%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%81%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_22.jpg/420px-%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%81%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8C%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A7_%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B9%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0_22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5232" data-file-height="3472"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The 9th-century ruins of <a href="/wiki/Somapura_Mahavihara" title="Somapura Mahavihara">Somapura Mahavihara</a>. The ruins hosted the largest monastery in pre-Islamic Bangladesh and is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ancient <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> states which ruled Bangladesh included the <a href="/wiki/Vanga_Kingdom" title="Vanga Kingdom">Vanga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samatata" title="Samatata">Samatata</a> and Pundra kingdoms, the Mauryan and <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empires</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Varman_dynasty" title="Varman dynasty">Varman dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shashanka" title="Shashanka">Shashanka</a>'s kingdom, the <a href="/wiki/Khadga_dynasty" title="Khadga dynasty">Khadga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Candra_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Candra dynasty">Candra dynasties</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sena_dynasty" title="Sena dynasty">Sena dynasty</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Harikela" title="Harikela">Harikela</a> kingdom and the <a href="/wiki/Deva_dynasty" title="Deva dynasty">Deva dynasty</a>. These states had well-developed currencies, banking, shipping, architecture, and art, and the ancient universities of <a href="/wiki/Bikrampur" title="Bikrampur">Bikrampur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mainamati" title="Mainamati">Mainamati</a> hosted scholars and students from other parts of Asia. <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a> of China was a noted scholar who resided at the <a href="/wiki/Somapura_Mahavihara" title="Somapura Mahavihara">Somapura Mahavihara</a> (the largest monastery in ancient India), and <a href="/wiki/Atisa" class="mw-redirect" title="Atisa">Atisa</a> travelled from Bengal to <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> to preach Buddhism. The earliest form of the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali language</a> began to emerge during the eighth century. Early Muslim explorers and missionaries arrived in Bengal late in the first millennium CE. The Islamic conquest of Bengal began with the 1204 <a href="/wiki/Ghurid_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghurid Empire">Ghurid</a> expeditions led by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Bakhtiyar_Khalji" title="Muhammad bin Bakhtiyar Khalji">Muhammad bin Bakhtiyar Khalji</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-google5_42-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google5-42">[42]</a></sup> Bengal was then ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> for a century by governors from the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_dynasty_(Delhi)" title="Mamluk dynasty (Delhi)">Mamluk</a>, Balban, and <a href="/wiki/Tughluq_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Tughluq dynasty">Tughluq dynasties</a>. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:382px;max-width:382px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:158px;max-width:158px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Bengal_Sultanate.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Bengal_Sultanate.png/156px-Bengal_Sultanate.png" decoding="async" width="156" height="116" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Bengal_Sultanate.png 1.5x" data-file-width="226" data-file-height="168"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sultanate of Bengal">Sultanate of Bengal</a> was the sovereign power of Bengal for much of the 14th, 15th and 16th centuries
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:220px;max-width:220px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Sixty_Dome_Mosque,Bagerhat.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Sixty_Dome_Mosque%2CBagerhat.jpg/218px-Sixty_Dome_Mosque%2CBagerhat.jpg" decoding="async" width="218" height="116" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Sixty_Dome_Mosque%2CBagerhat.jpg/327px-Sixty_Dome_Mosque%2CBagerhat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Sixty_Dome_Mosque%2CBagerhat.jpg/436px-Sixty_Dome_Mosque%2CBagerhat.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5811" data-file-height="3084"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The 15th-century <a href="/wiki/Sixty_Dome_Mosque" title="Sixty Dome Mosque">Sixty Dome Mosque</a> is the largest mosque in Bangladesh that was built during the period of the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate" title="Bengal Sultanate">Bengal Sultanate</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Subsequently, the independent <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate" title="Bengal Sultanate">Bengal Sultanate</a> was established by the rebel governors in 1352. During their rule Bengal was transformed into a cosmopolitan Islamic superpower and became a major <a href="/wiki/Trading_nation" title="Trading nation">trading nation</a> in the world, often referred by the Europeans as the richest country to trade with.<sup id="cite_ref-nanda_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nanda-52">[52]</a></sup> The sultanate's ruling houses included the <a href="/wiki/Ilyas_Shahi_dynasty" title="Ilyas Shahi dynasty">Ilyas Shahi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ganesha_dynasty" title="Ganesha dynasty">Ganesha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hussain_Shahi_dynasty" title="Hussain Shahi dynasty">Hussain Shahi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suri_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Suri dynasty">Suri</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karrani_dynasty" title="Karrani dynasty">Karrani dynasties</a>, and the era saw the introduction of a distinct mosque architecture<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_taka" title="History of the taka">tangka currency</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Arakan" title="Arakan">Arakan</a> region was brought under Bengali hegemony. The Bengal Sultanate was visited by explorers <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Battuta" title="Ibn Battuta">Ibn Battuta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Admiral_Zheng_He" class="mw-redirect" title="Admiral Zheng He">Admiral Zheng He</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Niccolo_De_Conti" class="mw-redirect" title="Niccolo De Conti">Niccolo De Conti</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Greater_Khorasan" title="Greater Khorasan">Khorasanis</a> referred to the land as an "inferno full of gifts", due to its unbearable climate but abundance of wealth.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed. (April 2020)">full citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> During the late 16th century, the <a href="/wiki/Baro-Bhuyan" title="Baro-Bhuyan">Baro-Bhuyan</a> (a confederation of Muslim and Hindu aristocrats) ruled eastern Bengal; its leader was the Mansad-e-Ala,<sup id="cite_ref-en.banglapedia.org_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-en.banglapedia.org-55">[55]</a></sup> a title held by <a href="/wiki/Isa_Khan" title="Isa Khan">Isa Khan</a> and his son <a href="/wiki/Musa_Khan" title="Musa Khan">Musa Khan</a>. The Khan dynasty is considered local heroes for resisting North Indian invasions with their river navies. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:372px;max-width:372px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:147px;max-width:147px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Mughal_Bengal.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mughal_Bengal.png/145px-Mughal_Bengal.png" decoding="async" width="145" height="145" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mughal_Bengal.png/218px-Mughal_Bengal.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mughal_Bengal.png/290px-Mughal_Bengal.png 2x" data-file-width="541" data-file-height="541"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Subah" title="Bengal Subah">Bengal Subah</a> was a <a href="/wiki/Administrative_subdivision" class="mw-redirect" title="Administrative subdivision">subdivision</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> encompassing much of the Bengal, Bihar and Orissa region
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:221px;max-width:221px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Awesome_look_of_Lalbagh_Fort.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Awesome_look_of_Lalbagh_Fort.jpg/219px-Awesome_look_of_Lalbagh_Fort.jpg" decoding="async" width="219" height="145" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Awesome_look_of_Lalbagh_Fort.jpg/329px-Awesome_look_of_Lalbagh_Fort.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Awesome_look_of_Lalbagh_Fort.jpg/438px-Awesome_look_of_Lalbagh_Fort.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Lalbagh_Fort" title="Lalbagh Fort">Lalbagh Fort</a> (also Fort Aurangabad) is an incomplete 17th-century Mughal fort complex that stands before the Buriganga River in the southwestern part of Dhaka
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> controlled Bengal by the 17th century. During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Akbar" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor Akbar">Emperor Akbar</a>, the Bengali agrarian calendar was reformed to facilitate tax collection. The Mughals established Dhaka as a fort city and commercial metropolis, and it was the capital of <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Subah" title="Bengal Subah">Bengal Subah</a> for 75 years.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> In 1666, the Mughals expelled the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mrauk_U" title="Kingdom of Mrauk U">Arakanese</a> from Chittagong. Mughal Bengal attracted foreign traders for its <a href="/wiki/Muslin" title="Muslin">muslin</a> and silk goods, and the <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Bangladesh" title="Armenians in Bangladesh">Armenians</a> were a notable merchant community. A <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_settlement_in_Chittagong" title="Portuguese settlement in Chittagong">Portuguese settlement in Chittagong</a> flourished in the southeast, and a <a href="/wiki/Dutch_settlement_in_Rajshahi" title="Dutch settlement in Rajshahi">Dutch settlement in Rajshahi</a> existed in the north. Bengal accounted for 40% of overall <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch</a> imports from Asia; including more than 50% of textiles and around 80% of silks.<sup id="cite_ref-Prakash_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash-57">[57]</a></sup> The Bengal Subah, described as the <i>Paradise of the Nations</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-paradise_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-paradise-58">[58]</a></sup> was the empire's wealthiest province, and a major global exporter,<sup id="cite_ref-Prakash_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash-57">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-richards95_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-richards95-59">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-riello_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riello-60">[60]</a></sup> a notable center of worldwide industries such as <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">muslin</a>, cotton textiles, silk,<sup id="cite_ref-google5_42-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google5-42">[42]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding_in_Bangladesh" title="Shipbuilding in Bangladesh">shipbuilding</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ray174_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ray174-61">[61]</a></sup> Its citizens also enjoyed one of the world's most superior <a href="/wiki/Standard_of_living" title="Standard of living">living standards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-harrison_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harrison-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the 18th century, the <a href="/wiki/Nawabs_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Nawabs of Bengal">Nawabs of Bengal</a> became the region's <i>de facto</i> rulers. The title of the ruler is popularly known as the <i>Nawab of Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa</i>, given that the Bengali Nawab's realm encompassed much of the eastern subcontinent. The Nawabs forged alliances with European colonial companies, which made the region relatively prosperous early in the century. Bengal accounted for 50% of the gross domestic product of the empire. The Bengali economy relied on <a href="/wiki/Textile_manufacturing" title="Textile manufacturing">textile manufacturing</a>, shipbuilding, <a href="/wiki/Saltpetre" class="mw-redirect" title="Saltpetre">saltpetre</a> production, craftsmanship, and agricultural produce. Bengal was a major hub for international trade â silk and cotton textiles from Bengal were worn in Europe, Japan, Indonesia, and Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-google5_42-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google5-42">[42]</a></sup> Annual Bengali shipbuilding output was 223,250 tons, compared to an output of 23,061 tons in the nineteen colonies of North America. Bengali shipbuilding proved to be more advanced than European shipbuilding prior to the Industrial Revolution. The <a href="/wiki/Flush_deck" title="Flush deck">flush deck</a> of Bengali rice ships was later replicated in European shipbuilding to replace the stepped deck design for ship <a href="/wiki/Hull_(watercraft)" title="Hull (watercraft)">hulls</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-star_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-star-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-books.google.com_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-67">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Muslim">Bengali Muslim</a> population was a product of conversion and religious evolution,<sup id="cite_ref-google5_42-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google5-42">[42]</a></sup> and their pre-Islamic beliefs included elements of Buddhism and Hinduism. The construction of mosques, Islamic academies (madrasas) and Sufi monasteries (<a href="/wiki/Khanqah" title="Khanqah">khanqahs</a>) facilitated conversion, and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_cosmology" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic cosmology">Islamic cosmology</a> played a significant role in developing Bengali Muslim society. Scholars have theorised that Bengalis were attracted to Islam by its egalitarian social order, which contrasted with the Hindu caste system.<sup id="cite_ref-Roy1999_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roy1999-71">[71]</a></sup> One of the notable Muslim preachers was Shah Jalal who arrived in the region of <a href="/wiki/Sylhet" title="Sylhet">Sylhet</a> in 1303 with many other disciples to preach the religion to the people.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> By the 15th century, Muslim poets were writing in the Bengali language. Notable medieval Bengali Muslim poets included <a href="/wiki/Daulat_Qazi" title="Daulat Qazi">Daulat Qazi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hakim_(poet)" title="Abdul Hakim (poet)">Abdul Hakim</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alaol" title="Alaol">Alaol</a>. <a href="/wiki/Syncretic" class="mw-redirect" title="Syncretic">Syncretic</a> cults, such as the <a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">Baul</a> movement, emerged on the fringes of Bengali Muslim society. The <a href="/wiki/Persianate" class="mw-redirect" title="Persianate">Persianate</a> culture was significant in Bengal, where cities like <a href="/wiki/Sonargaon" title="Sonargaon">Sonargaon</a> became the easternmost centers of Persian influence.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Mughals had aided France during the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a> to avoid losing the <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> region to the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British</a>. However, in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a> the British <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> registered a decisive victory over the Nawab of Bengal and his <a href="/wiki/French_East_India_Company" title="French East India Company">French</a><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> allies on 22 June 1757, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Robert_Clive" title="Robert Clive">Robert Clive</a>. The battle followed the order of <a href="/wiki/Siraj_ud-Daulah" title="Siraj ud-Daulah">Siraj-ud-Daulah</a>, the last independent Nawab of Bengal, to the English to stop the extension of their fortification. Robert Clive bribed <a href="/wiki/Mir_Jafar" title="Mir Jafar">Mir Jafar</a>, the commander-in-chief of the Nawab's army, and also promised him to make him Nawab of Bengal which helped him to defeat Siraj-ud-Daulah and capture <a href="/wiki/Calcutta" class="mw-redirect" title="Calcutta">Calcutta</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The battle consolidated the company's presence in Bengal, which later expanded to cover much of <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> over the next hundred years. Although they had lost control of Bengal Subah, <a href="/wiki/Shah_Alam_II" title="Shah Alam II">Shah Alam II</a> was involved in the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_War" title="Bengal War">Bengal War</a> which ended once more in their defeat at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Buxar" title="Battle of Buxar">Battle of Buxar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_period">Colonial period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Bengal Presidency</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_and_Assam" title="Eastern Bengal and Assam">Eastern Bengal and Assam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg/220px-Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="399" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg/330px-Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg/440px-Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2275" data-file-height="4123"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Portuguese (top left) at the Royal Court of emperor Akbar.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Two decades after <a href="/wiki/Vasco_Da_Gama" class="mw-redirect" title="Vasco Da Gama">Vasco Da Gama</a>'s landing in <a href="/wiki/Calicut" class="mw-redirect" title="Calicut">Calicut</a>, the Bengal Sultanate gave permission for the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> settlement in Chittagong to be established in 1528. It became the first European colonial enclave in Bengal. The Bengal Sultanate lost control of Chittagong in 1531 after Arakan declared independence and the established Kingdom of Mrauk U. </p>
      <p>Portuguese ships from Goa and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Malacca" title="Portuguese Malacca">Malacca</a> began frequenting the port city in the 16th century. The <i><a href="/wiki/Cartaz" title="Cartaz">cartaz</a></i> system was introduced and required all ships in the area to purchase naval trading licenses from the Portuguese settlement. <a href="/wiki/Slave_trade" class="mw-redirect" title="Slave trade">Slave trade</a> and piracy flourished. The nearby island of <a href="/wiki/Sandwip" title="Sandwip">Sandwip</a> was conquered in 1602. In 1615, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Navy" title="Portuguese Navy">Portuguese Navy</a> defeated a joint <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a> and Arakanese fleet near the coast of Chittagong. </p>
      <p>The Bengal Sultan after 1534 allowed the Portuguese to create several settlements at Chitagoong, Satgaon,<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Hughli, Bandel, and Dhaka. In 1535 the Portuguese allied with the Bengal sultan and held the Teliagarhi pass 280&nbsp;km from <a href="/wiki/Patna" title="Patna">Patna</a> helping to avoid the invasion by the Mughals. By then several of the products came from Patna and the Portuguese send in traders, establishing a factory there since 1580.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By the time the Portuguese assured military help against Sher Shah, the Mughals already had started to conquer the Sultanate of Ghiyasuddin Mahmud.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bengal was the wealthiest region in the Indian subcontinent, and its <a href="/wiki/Proto-industrialization" title="Proto-industrialization">proto-industrial</a> economy showed signs of driving an <a href="/wiki/Industrial_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrial revolution">Industrial revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-voss_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voss-80">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The region has been described as the "Paradise of Nations",<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> and its inhabitants's <a href="/wiki/Standards_of_living" class="mw-redirect" title="Standards of living">living standards</a> and <a href="/wiki/Real_wages" title="Real wages">real wages</a> were among the highest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> It alone accounted for 40% of <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch imports</a> outside the <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European</a> continent.<sup id="cite_ref-Prakash_57-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash-57">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-star_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-star-66">[66]</a></sup> The eastern part of Bengal was globally prominent in industries such as <a href="/wiki/Textile_manufacturing" title="Textile manufacturing">textile manufacturing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding" title="Shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ray_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ray-19">[19]</a></sup> and it was a major exporter of <a href="/wiki/Silk" title="Silk">silk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a> <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">textiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saltpeter" class="mw-redirect" title="Saltpeter">saltpeter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Agricultural" class="mw-redirect" title="Agricultural">agricultural</a> and industrial produce in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-star_66-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-star-66">[66]</a></sup> In 1666, the Mughal government of Bengal led by viceroy <a href="/wiki/Shaista_Khan" title="Shaista Khan">Shaista Khan</a> moved to retake Chittagong from Portuguese and Arakanese control. The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Mughal_War" title="Anglo-Mughal War">Anglo-Mughal War</a> was witnessed in 1686.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Clive.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Clive.jpg/220px-Clive.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Clive.jpg/330px-Clive.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Clive.jpg/440px-Clive.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="1870"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Clive.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Lord_Clive" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Clive">Lord Clive</a> meeting with <a href="/wiki/Mir_Jafar" title="Mir Jafar">Mir Jafar</a> after the Battle of Plassey
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the 1757 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a>, Bengal was the first region of the Indian subcontinent conquered by the <a href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="British East India Company">British East India Company</a>. The company formed the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Presidency of Fort William</a>, which administered the region until 1858. A notable aspect of <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">company rule</a> was the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Settlement" title="Permanent Settlement">Permanent Settlement</a>, which established the feudal <a href="/wiki/Zamindar" title="Zamindar">zamindari</a> system.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> The plunder of Bengal directly contributed to the Industrial Revolution in Britain, with the capital amassed from Bengal used to invest in British industries such as <a href="/wiki/Textile_manufacture_during_the_Industrial_Revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Textile manufacture during the Industrial Revolution">textile</a> and greatly increase British wealth, while at the same time leading to deindustrialisation of Bengal's traditional textile industry.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sengupta_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sengupta-20">[20]</a></sup> The economic mismanagement directly led to the <a href="/wiki/Great_Bengal_famine_of_1770" title="Great Bengal famine of 1770">Great Bengal famine of 1770</a>, which is estimated to have caused the deaths of about 10 million people,<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> as a third of the population in the affected region starved to death.<sup id="cite_ref-Jonsson2013p167_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jonsson2013p167-88">[88]</a></sup> Several rebellions broke out during the early 19th century (including one led by <a href="/wiki/Titumir" title="Titumir">Titumir</a>), but British rule displaced the Muslim ruling class. A conservative Islamic cleric, <a href="/wiki/Haji_Shariatullah" title="Haji Shariatullah">Haji Shariatullah</a>, sought to overthrow the British by propagating Islamic revivalism.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> Several towns in Bangladesh participated in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">Indian Rebellion of 1857</a><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> and pledged allegiance to the last Mughal emperor, <a href="/wiki/Bahadur_Shah_Zafar" title="Bahadur Shah Zafar">Bahadur Shah Zafar</a>, who was later exiled to neighbouring Burma. </p>
      <p>The challenge posed to company rule by the failed Indian Mutiny led to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="British Indian Empire">British Indian Empire</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Crown_colony" title="Crown colony">crown colony</a>. The British established several schools, colleges, and a university in what is now Bangladesh. <a href="/wiki/Syed_Ahmed_Khan" class="mw-redirect" title="Syed Ahmed Khan">Syed Ahmed Khan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ram_Mohan_Roy" title="Ram Mohan Roy">Ram Mohan Roy</a> promoted modern and <a href="/wiki/Liberal_education" title="Liberal education">liberal education</a> in the subcontinent, inspiring the <a href="/wiki/Aligarh_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Aligarh movement">Aligarh movement</a><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Renaissance" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengal Renaissance">Bengal Renaissance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> During the late 19th century, novelists, social reformers and feminists emerged from Muslim Bengali society. <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">Electricity</a> and municipal water systems were introduced in the 1890s; <a href="/wiki/Movie_theater" title="Movie theater">cinemas</a> opened in many towns during the early 20th century. East Bengal's <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantation economy</a> was important to the British Empire, particularly its <a href="/wiki/Jute" title="Jute">jute</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tea_production_in_Bangladesh" title="Tea production in Bangladesh">tea</a>. The British established <a href="/wiki/Free_port" class="mw-redirect" title="Free port">tax-free river ports</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Narayanganj" title="Port of Narayanganj">Port of Narayanganj</a>, and large seaports like the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Chittagong" title="Port of Chittagong">Port of Chittagong</a>. </p>
      <p>Bengal had the highest gross domestic product in British India.<sup id="cite_ref-daily-sun.com_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-daily-sun.com-93">[93]</a></sup> Bengal was one of the first regions in Asia to have a railway. The first railway in what is now Bangladesh began operating in 1862.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> In comparison, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> saw its first railway in 1872. The main railway companies in the region were the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_Railway" title="Eastern Bengal Railway">Eastern Bengal Railway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Assam_Bengal_Railway" title="Assam Bengal Railway">Assam Bengal Railway</a>. Railways competed with waterborne transport to become one of the main mediums of transport.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:164px;max-width:164px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:147px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Bengal_Presidency_1858.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Bengal_Presidency_1858.png/162px-Bengal_Presidency_1858.png" decoding="async" width="162" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Bengal_Presidency_1858.png/243px-Bengal_Presidency_1858.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Bengal_Presidency_1858.png/324px-Bengal_Presidency_1858.png 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1812"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Bengal Presidency</a> at its greatest extent
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:147px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:BengalPartition1905_Map.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/BengalPartition1905_Map.png/222px-BengalPartition1905_Map.png" decoding="async" width="222" height="147" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/BengalPartition1905_Map.png/333px-BengalPartition1905_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/BengalPartition1905_Map.png/444px-BengalPartition1905_Map.png 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1989"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Map showing the result of the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1905)" title="Partition of Bengal (1905)">Partition of Bengal (1905)</a>. The western part (Bengal) gained parts of Orissa, the eastern part as <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_and_Assam" title="Eastern Bengal and Assam">Eastern Bengal and Assam</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Supported by the Muslim aristocracy, the British government created the province of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_and_Assam" title="Eastern Bengal and Assam">Eastern Bengal and Assam</a> in 1905; the new province received increased investment in education, transport, and industry.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1905)" title="Partition of Bengal (1905)">first partition of Bengal</a> created an uproar in <a href="/wiki/Kolkata" title="Kolkata">Calcutta</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a>. In response to growing Hindu nationalism, the <a href="/wiki/All_India_Muslim_League" class="mw-redirect" title="All India Muslim League">All India Muslim League</a> was formed in Dhaka during the 1906 All India Muhammadan Educational Conference. The British government reorganised the provinces in 1912, reuniting East and West Bengal and making <a href="/wiki/Assam_Province" title="Assam Province">Assam</a> a second province. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg/340px-All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg" decoding="async" width="340" height="109" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg/510px-All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg/680px-All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="257"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Founding conference of the <a href="/wiki/All_India_Muslim_League" class="mw-redirect" title="All India Muslim League">All India Muslim League</a> in Dhaka, 1906
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Raj was slow to allow self-rule in the colonial subcontinent. It established the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Legislative_Council" title="Bengal Legislative Council">Bengal Legislative Council</a> in 1862, and the council's native Bengali representation increased during the early 20th century. The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Provincial_Muslim_League" title="Bengal Provincial Muslim League">Bengal Provincial Muslim League</a> was formed in 1913 to advocate <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil rights">civil rights</a> for Bengali Muslims within a constitutional framework. During the 1920s, the league was divided into factions supporting the <a href="/wiki/Khilafat_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Khilafat movement">Khilafat movement</a> and favouring co-operation with the British to achieve self-rule. Segments of the Bengali elite supported <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">secularist</a> forces.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> In 1929, the <a href="/wiki/Praja_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Praja Party">All Bengal Tenants Association</a> was formed in the Bengal Legislative Council to counter the influence of the Hindu landed gentry, and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Independence_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Independence Movement">Indian Independence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">Pakistan Movements</a> strengthened during the early 20th century. After the <a href="/wiki/Morley-Minto_Reforms" class="mw-redirect" title="Morley-Minto Reforms">Morley-Minto Reforms</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1919" title="Government of India Act 1919">diarchy</a> era in the <a href="/wiki/Legislatures_of_British_India" title="Legislatures of British India">legislatures of British India</a>, the British government promised <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1935" title="Government of India Act 1935">limited provincial autonomy</a> in 1935. The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Legislative_Assembly" title="Bengal Legislative Assembly">Bengal Legislative Assembly</a>, British India's largest legislature, was established in 1937. </p>
      <p>Although it won a majority of seats in 1937, the Bengal Congress boycotted the legislature. <a href="/wiki/A._K._Fazlul_Huq" title="A. K. Fazlul Huq">A. K. Fazlul Huq</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Krishak_Sramik_Party" title="Krishak Sramik Party">Krishak Praja Party</a> was elected as the first <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bengal" title="Prime Minister of Bengal">Prime Minister of Bengal</a>. In 1940 Huq supported the <a href="/wiki/Lahore_Resolution" title="Lahore Resolution">Lahore Resolution</a>, which envisaged independent states in the northwestern and eastern Muslim-majority regions of the subcontinent. The first Huq ministry, a coalition with the Bengal Provincial Muslim League, lasted until 1941; it was followed by a Huq coalition with the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha" title="Hindu Mahasabha">Hindu Mahasabha</a> which lasted until 1943. Huq was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Khawaja_Nazimuddin" title="Khawaja Nazimuddin">Khawaja Nazimuddin</a>, who grappled with the effects of the <a href="/wiki/Burma_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Burma Campaign">Burma Campaign</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943" title="Bengal famine of 1943">Bengal famine of 1943</a>, which killed up to 3 million people,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Quit_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Quit India">Quit India</a> movement. In 1946, the Bengal Provincial Muslim League won the provincial election, taking 113 of the 250-seat assembly (the largest Muslim League mandate in British India). <a href="/wiki/H._S._Suhrawardy" class="mw-redirect" title="H. S. Suhrawardy">H. S. Suhrawardy</a>, who made a final futile effort for a <a href="/wiki/United_Bengal" title="United Bengal">United Bengal</a> in 1946, was the last premier of Bengal. </p> 
      <h3><span id="Partition_of_Bengal_.281947.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Partition_of_Bengal_(1947)">Partition of Bengal (1947)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1947)" title="Partition of Bengal (1947)">Partition of Bengal (1947)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bengal_PMs.png" class="image"><img alt="Three Bengali Prime Ministers" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Bengal_PMs.png/220px-Bengal_PMs.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="91" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Bengal_PMs.png/330px-Bengal_PMs.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Bengal_PMs.png/440px-Bengal_PMs.png 2x" data-file-width="1458" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bengal_PMs.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bengal" title="Prime Minister of Bengal">Prime Ministers of Bengal</a> <a href="/wiki/A._K._Fazlul_Huq" title="A. K. Fazlul Huq">A. K. Fazlul Huq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khawaja_Nazimuddin" title="Khawaja Nazimuddin">Khawaja Nazimuddin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy" title="Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy">H. S. Suhrawardy</a>. One of them, Suhrawardy, proposed an <a href="/wiki/United_Bengal" title="United Bengal">independent Bengal</a> in 1947
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 3 June 1947, the <a href="/wiki/Mountbatten_Plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mountbatten Plan">Mountbatten Plan</a> outlined the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_British_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Partition of British India">partition of British India</a>. On 20 June, the Bengal Legislative Assembly met to decide on the partition of Bengal. At the preliminary joint meeting, it was decided (120 votes to 90) that if the province remained united it should join the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="Constituent Assembly of Pakistan">Constituent Assembly of Pakistan</a>. At a separate meeting of legislators from <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>, it was decided (58 votes to 21) that the province should be partitioned and West Bengal should join the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_India" title="Constituent Assembly of India">Constituent Assembly of India</a>. At another meeting of legislators from <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a>, it was decided (106 votes to 35) that the province should not be partitioned and (107 votes to 34) that East Bengal should join the Constituent Assembly of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> if Bengal was partitioned.<sup id="cite_ref-Mukherjee1987_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mukherjee1987-99">[99]</a></sup> On 6 July, the <a href="/wiki/Sylhet_Division" title="Sylhet Division">Sylhet region</a> of Assam voted in a <a href="/wiki/1947_Sylhet_referendum" title="1947 Sylhet referendum">referendum to join East Bengal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Cyril_Radcliffe" class="mw-redirect" title="Cyril Radcliffe">Cyril Radcliffe</a> was tasked with drawing the borders of Pakistan and India, and the <a href="/wiki/Radcliffe_Line" title="Radcliffe Line">Radcliffe Line</a> established the borders of present-day Bangladesh. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Union_with_Pakistan">Union with Pakistan</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="image"><img alt="Map of the world, with Pakistan in 1947 highlighted" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/220px-Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/330px-Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/440px-Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="541" data-file-height="541"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a> in 1947, with <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a> its eastern part
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a> was created on 14 August 1947.
