East Bengal, with Dhaka as its capital, was the most populous province of the 1947 <a href="/wiki/State_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="State of Pakistan">Pakistani federation</a> (led by <a href="/wiki/Governor_General_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Governor General of Pakistan">Governor General</a> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a>, who promised freedom of religion and secular democracy in the new state).<sup id="cite_ref-Ispahani2017_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ispahani2017-100">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Saikia2011_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Saikia2011-101">[101]</a></sup> East Bengal was also Pakistan's most cosmopolitan province, home to peoples of different faiths, cultures and ethnic groups. Partition gave increased economic opportunity to East Bengalis, producing an urban population during the 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Khawaja_Nazimuddin" title="Khawaja Nazimuddin">Khawaja Nazimuddin</a> was East Bengal's first <a href="/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_East_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Chief Minister of East Bengal">chief minister</a> with <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Chalmers_Bourne" title="Frederick Chalmers Bourne">Frederick Chalmers Bourne</a> its governor. The <a href="/wiki/All_Pakistan_Awami_Muslim_League" title="All Pakistan Awami Muslim League">All Pakistan Awami Muslim League</a> was formed in 1949. In 1950, the <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal_Legislative_Assembly" class="mw-redirect" title="East Bengal Legislative Assembly">East Bengal Legislative Assembly</a> enacted <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reform</a>, abolishing the Permanent Settlement and the <a href="/wiki/Zamindar" title="Zamindar">zamindari</a> system.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> The 1952 <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Language_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Language Movement">Bengali Language Movement</a> was the first sign of friction between the country's geographically-separated wings. The Awami Muslim League was renamed the more-secular <a href="/wiki/Awami_League" title="Awami League">Awami League</a> in 1953.<sup id="cite_ref-LewisSagar1992_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LewisSagar1992-105">[105]</a></sup> The first constituent assembly was dissolved in 1954; this was challenged by its East Bengali speaker, <a href="/wiki/Maulvi_Tamizuddin_Khan" title="Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan">Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan</a>. The <a href="/wiki/United_Front_(East_Pakistan)" title="United Front (East Pakistan)">United Front</a> coalition swept aside the Muslim League in a landslide victory in the <a href="/wiki/1954_East_Bengali_legislative_election" class="mw-redirect" title="1954 East Bengali legislative election">1954 East Bengali legislative election</a>. The following year, East Bengal was renamed East Pakistan as part of the <a href="/wiki/One_Unit" title="One Unit">One Unit</a> program and the province became a vital part of the <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia_Treaty_Organization" title="Southeast Asia Treaty Organization">Southeast Asia Treaty Organization</a>. </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:471px;max-width:471px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:257px;max-width:257px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Shaheed_Minar.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Shaheed_Minar.JPG/255px-Shaheed_Minar.JPG" decoding="async" width="255" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Shaheed_Minar.JPG/383px-Shaheed_Minar.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Shaheed_Minar.JPG/510px-Shaheed_Minar.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="753"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Shaheed_Minar,_Dhaka" title="Shaheed Minar, Dhaka">Shaheed Minar</a>, established to commemorate those killed during the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Language_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Language Movement">Bengali Language Movement</a> demonstrations of 1952 in then <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png/208px-21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png" decoding="async" width="208" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png/312px-21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png/416px-21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png 2x" data-file-width="1374" data-file-height="1056"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           Female students march in defiance of the <a href="/wiki/Section_144" class="mw-redirect" title="Section 144">Section 144</a> prohibition on assembly during the Bengali Language Movement in early 1953
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Pakistan adopted its first constitution in 1956. Three Bengalis were its Prime Minister until 1957: Nazimuddin, <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Ali_of_Bogra" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohammad Ali of Bogra">Mohammad Ali of Bogra</a> and Suhrawardy. None of the three completed their terms, and resigned from office. The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Army" title="Pakistan Army">Pakistan Army</a> imposed <a href="/wiki/1958_Pakistani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1958 Pakistani coup d'Ã©tat">military rule in 1958</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ayub_Khan_(general)" title="Ayub Khan (general)">Ayub Khan</a> was the country's strongman for 11 years. Political repression increased after the coup. Khan introduced a new constitution in 1962, replacing Pakistan's parliamentary system with a presidential and gubernatorial system (based on <a href="/wiki/Electoral_college" title="Electoral college">electoral college</a> selection) known as Basic Democracy. In 1962 Dhaka became the seat of the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="National Assembly of Pakistan">National Assembly of Pakistan</a>, a move seen as appeasing increased Bengali nationalism.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> The Pakistani government built the controversial <a href="/wiki/Kaptai_Dam" title="Kaptai Dam">Kaptai Dam</a>, displacing the <a href="/wiki/Chakma_people" title="Chakma people">Chakma people</a> from their indigenous homeland in the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts">Chittagong Hill Tracts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/1965_Pakistani_presidential_election" title="1965 Pakistani presidential election">1965 presidential election</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fatima_Jinnah" title="Fatima Jinnah">Fatima Jinnah</a> lost to Ayub Khan despite support from the Combined Opposition alliance (which included the Awami League).<sup id="cite_ref-Ahmed2004p157_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2004p157-108">[108]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1965">Indo-Pakistani War of 1965</a> blocked cross-border transport links with neighbouring India in what is described as a second partition.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> In 1966, Awami League leader <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> announced a <a href="/wiki/Six_point_movement" title="Six point movement">six-point movement</a> for a federal parliamentary democracy. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Maulvi_Tamizuddin_Khan_and_US_Chief_Justice.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Earl Warren and Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan shake hands as a third man looks on" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4a/Maulvi_Tamizuddin_Khan_and_US_Chief_Justice.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="257" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="200" data-file-height="257"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Maulvi_Tamizuddin_Khan_and_US_Chief_Justice.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States" title="Chief Justice of the United States">U.S. Chief Justice</a> <a href="/wiki/Earl_Warren" title="Earl Warren">Earl Warren</a> meets Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan, the plaintiff in <i><a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Pakistan_v._Maulvi_Tamizuddin_Khan" title="Federation of Pakistan v. Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan">Federation of Pakistan v. Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan</a></i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to senior <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> officials, Pakistan practised extensive <a href="/wiki/Economic_discrimination" title="Economic discrimination">economic discrimination</a> against East Pakistan: greater government spending on West Pakistan, financial transfers from East to West Pakistan, the use of East Pakistan's foreign-exchange surpluses to finance West Pakistani imports, and refusal by the central government to release funds allocated to East Pakistan because the previous spending had been under budget;<sup id="cite_ref-google.co.nz_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google.co.nz-110">[110]</a></sup> though East Pakistan generated 70 percent of Pakistan's export revenue with its jute and tea.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Sheikh Mujibur Rahman was arrested for treason in the <a href="/wiki/Agartala_Conspiracy_Case" title="Agartala Conspiracy Case">Agartala Conspiracy Case</a> and was released during the <a href="/wiki/1969_uprising_in_East_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="1969 uprising in East Pakistan">1969 uprising in East Pakistan</a> which resulted in Ayub Khan's resignation. General <a href="/wiki/Yahya_Khan" title="Yahya Khan">Yahya Khan</a> assumed power, reintroducing martial law. </p>
      <p>Ethnic and linguistic discrimination was common in Pakistan's civil and military services, in which Bengalis were under-represented. Fifteen percent of Pakistani central-government offices were occupied by East Pakistanis, who formed 10 percent of the military.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> Cultural discrimination also prevailed, making East Pakistan forge a distinct political identity.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> Pakistan banned Bengali literature and music in state media, including the works of Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/1970_Bhola_cyclone" title="1970 Bhola cyclone">cyclone</a> devastated the coast of East Pakistan in 1970, killing an estimated 500,000 people,<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> and the central government was criticised for its poor response.<sup id="cite_ref-countrystudies.us1_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-countrystudies.us1-116">[116]</a></sup> After the December 1970 elections, calls for the independence of East Bengal became louder; the Bengali-nationalist Awami League won 167 of 169 East Pakistani seats in the National Assembly. The League claimed the right to form a government and develop a new constitution but was strongly opposed by the Pakistani military and the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Peoples_Party" title="Pakistan Peoples Party">Pakistan Peoples Party</a> (led by <a href="/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto" title="Zulfikar Ali Bhutto">Zulfikar Ali Bhutto</a>). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="War_of_Independence">War of Independence</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:486px;max-width:486px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Human_Remains_and_War_Materiel_from_1971_Genocide_-_Liberation_War_Museum_-_Dhaka_-_Bangladesh_(12826731774).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Human_Remains_and_War_Materiel_from_1971_Genocide_-_Liberation_War_Museum_-_Dhaka_-_Bangladesh_%2812826731774%29.jpg/225px-Human_Remains_and_War_Materiel_from_1971_Genocide_-_Liberation_War_Museum_-_Dhaka_-_Bangladesh_%2812826731774%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="169" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Human_Remains_and_War_Materiel_from_1971_Genocide_-_Liberation_War_Museum_-_Dhaka_-_Bangladesh_%2812826731774%29.jpg/338px-Human_Remains_and_War_Materiel_from_1971_Genocide_-_Liberation_War_Museum_-_Dhaka_-_Bangladesh_%2812826731774%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Human_Remains_and_War_Materiel_from_1971_Genocide_-_Liberation_War_Museum_-_Dhaka_-_Bangladesh_%2812826731774%29.jpg/450px-Human_Remains_and_War_Materiel_from_1971_Genocide_-_Liberation_War_Museum_-_Dhaka_-_Bangladesh_%2812826731774%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           Human Remains and War Materiel from <a href="/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide">1971 Bangladesh genocide</a> in <a href="/wiki/Liberation_War_Museum" title="Liberation War Museum">Liberation War Museum</a>, Dhaka
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:255px;max-width:255px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Martyr%27s_intellectual_monument_at_Rayerbazar.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Martyr%27s_intellectual_monument_at_Rayerbazar.jpg/253px-Martyr%27s_intellectual_monument_at_Rayerbazar.jpg" decoding="async" width="253" height="169" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Martyr%27s_intellectual_monument_at_Rayerbazar.jpg/380px-Martyr%27s_intellectual_monument_at_Rayerbazar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Martyr%27s_intellectual_monument_at_Rayerbazar.jpg/506px-Martyr%27s_intellectual_monument_at_Rayerbazar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="480"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Martyred_Intellectuals_Memorial" title="Martyred Intellectuals Memorial">Martyred Intellectuals Memorial</a> near Rayerbazar killing field is built in memory of the <a href="/wiki/1971_killing_of_Bengali_intellectuals" title="1971 killing of Bengali intellectuals">martyred intellectuals</a> of Liberation War.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Bengali population was angered when Prime Minister-elect <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> was prevented from taking the office.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Civil_disobedience" title="Civil disobedience">Civil disobedience</a> erupted across East Pakistan, with calls for independence.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> Mujib addressed a <a href="/wiki/7_March_Speech_of_Bangabandhu" title="7 March Speech of Bangabandhu">pro-independence rally</a> of nearly 2 million people in Dacca (as Dhaka used to be spelled in English) on 7 March 1971, where he said, "This time the struggle is for our freedom. This time the struggle is for our independence." The flag of Bangladesh was raised for the first time on 23 March, Pakistan's Republic Day.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Later, on 25 March late evening, the Pakistani military junta led by <a href="/wiki/Yahya_Khan" title="Yahya Khan">Yahya Khan</a> launched a sustained military assault on East Pakistan under the code name of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Searchlight" title="Operation Searchlight">Operation Searchlight</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> The Pakistan Army arrested Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and flew him away to Karachi.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> However, before his arrest Mujib proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Bangladeshi_Independence" title="Proclamation of Bangladeshi Independence">Independence of Bangladesh</a> at midnight on 26 March which led the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a> to break out within hours. The Pakistan Army continued to massacre Bengali <a href="/wiki/1971_Dhaka_University_massacre" title="1971 Dhaka University massacre">students</a>, <a href="/wiki/1971_killing_of_Bengali_intellectuals" title="1971 killing of Bengali intellectuals">intellectuals</a>, politicians, civil servants and military defectors in the <a href="/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide">1971 Bangladesh genocide</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Mukti_Bahini" title="Mukti Bahini">Mukti Bahini</a> and other Bengali guerrilla forces created strong resistance throughout the country.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> During the war, an estimated 0.3 to 3 million people were killed and several million people took shelter in neighbouring India.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> Global public opinion turned against Pakistan as news of the atrocities spread;<sup id="cite_ref-Benvenisti2012_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Benvenisti2012-127">[127]</a></sup> the Bangladesh movement was supported by prominent political and cultural figures in the West, including <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted Kennedy</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">Bob Dylan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joan_Baez" title="Joan Baez">Joan Baez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Ocampo" title="Victoria Ocampo">Victoria Ocampo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Malraux" title="AndrÃ© Malraux">AndrÃ© Malraux</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Concert_for_Bangladesh" title="The Concert for Bangladesh">The Concert for Bangladesh</a> was held at <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> in New York City to raise funds for Bangladeshi refugees. The first major benefit concert in history, it was organised by Harrison and Indian Bengali sitarist <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Shankar" title="Ravi Shankar">Ravi Shankar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:461px;max-width:461px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:207px;max-width:207px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg/205px-1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg" decoding="async" width="205" height="146" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg/308px-1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg/410px-1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg 2x" data-file-width="936" data-file-height="666"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Surrender of Pakistan">Surrender of Pakistan</a> on 16 December 1971 at Suhrawardy Udyan, bringing the Bangladesh Liberation War to an end.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:250px;max-width:250px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Independence_Monument_glass_tower.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Independence_Monument_glass_tower.jpg/248px-Independence_Monument_glass_tower.jpg" decoding="async" width="248" height="146" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Independence_Monument_glass_tower.jpg/372px-Independence_Monument_glass_tower.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Independence_Monument_glass_tower.jpg/496px-Independence_Monument_glass_tower.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3800" data-file-height="2233"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Swadhinata_Stambha" title="Swadhinata Stambha">Swadhinata Stambha</a> or <b>Independence Monument</b> commemorates the historical events that took place in the <a href="/wiki/Suhrawardy_Udyan" title="Suhrawardy Udyan">Suhrawardy Udyan</a> regarding the Liberation War.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p> During the Bangladesh Liberation War, Bengali nationalists declared independence and formed the <a href="/wiki/Mukti_Bahini" title="Mukti Bahini">Mukti Bahini</a> (the Bangladeshi National Liberation Army). The <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Bangladesh" title="Provisional Government of Bangladesh">Provisional Government of Bangladesh</a> was established on 17 April 1971, converting the 469 elected members of the Pakistani national assembly and East Pakistani provincial assembly into the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Bangladesh" title="Constituent Assembly of Bangladesh">Constituent Assembly of Bangladesh</a>. The provisional government issued a <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Bangladeshi_Independence" title="Proclamation of Bangladeshi Independence">proclamation</a> that became the country's interim constitution and declared "equality, human dignity, and social justice" as its fundamental principles. Due to Mujib's detention, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Nazrul_Islam" title="Syed Nazrul Islam">Syed Nazrul Islam</a> took over the role of Acting President, while <a href="/wiki/Tajuddin_Ahmad" title="Tajuddin Ahmad">Tajuddin Ahmad</a> was named Bangladesh's first Prime Minister. The Mukti Bahini and other Bengali guerrilla forces formed the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh Forces">Bangladesh Forces</a> which became the military wing of the provisional government. Led by General <a href="/wiki/M._A._G._Osmani" title="M. A. G. Osmani">M. A. G. Osmani</a> and eleven <a href="/wiki/List_of_sectors_in_Bangladesh_Liberation_War" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sectors in Bangladesh Liberation War">sector commanders</a>, the forces held the countryside during the war and conducted wide-ranging guerrilla operations against Pakistani forces. As a result, almost the entire country except the capital Dacca was liberated by <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh Forces">Bangladesh Forces</a> by late November.</p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sriti_shoud.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Sriti_shoud.jpeg/220px-Sriti_shoud.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Sriti_shoud.jpeg/330px-Sriti_shoud.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Sriti_shoud.jpeg/440px-Sriti_shoud.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sriti_shoud.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/National_Martyrs%E2%80%99_Memorial" class="mw-redirect" title="National Martyrsâ Memorial">National Martyrsâ Memorial</a> set up in the memory of those who died in the Bangladesh Liberation War of 1971
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>This led the Pakistan Army to attack neighbouring India's western front on 2 December 1971. India retaliated in both the western and eastern fronts. With a joint ground advance by Bangladeshi and Indian forces, coupled with air strikes by both India and the small Bangladeshi air contingent, the capital Dacca was liberated from Pakistani occupation in mid-December. During the last phase of the war, both the Soviet Union and the United States dispatched naval forces to the Bay of Bengal in a Cold War standoff. The nine month long war ended with the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Surrender of Pakistan">surrender of Pakistani armed forces</a> to the Bangladesh-India Allied Forces on 16 December 1971.<sup id="cite_ref-laporte_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-laporte-132">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rummel-8-2_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rummel-8-2-133">[133]</a></sup> Under international pressure, Pakistan released Rahman from imprisonment on 8 January 1972 and he was flown by the British Royal Air Force to a million-strong homecoming in Dacca.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> Remaining Indian troops were withdrawn by 12 March 1972, three months after the war ended.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The cause of Bangladeshi self-determination was recognised around the world. By August 1972, the new state was recognised by 86 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Benvenisti2012_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Benvenisti2012-127">[127]</a></sup> Pakistan recognised Bangladesh in 1974 after pressure from most of the Muslim countries.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="People.27s_Republic_of_Bangladesh"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="People's_Republic_of_Bangladesh">People's Republic of Bangladesh</span></h3> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="First_parliamentary_era">First parliamentary era</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mujib_and_Ford.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A seated Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and Gerald Ford, smiling and talking" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Mujib_and_Ford.jpg/220px-Mujib_and_Ford.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Mujib_and_Ford.jpg/330px-Mujib_and_Ford.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Mujib_and_Ford.jpg/440px-Mujib_and_Ford.jpg 2x" data-file-width="604" data-file-height="366"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mujib_and_Ford.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> and U.S. president <a href="/wiki/Gerald_Ford" title="Gerald Ford">Gerald Ford</a> in 1974
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The constituent assembly adopted the constitution of Bangladesh on 4 November 1972, establishing a secular, multiparty parliamentary democracy. The new constitution included references to <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a>, and Prime Minister Sheikh Mujibur Rahman <a href="/wiki/Nationalised" class="mw-redirect" title="Nationalised">nationalised</a> major industries in 1972.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> A major reconstruction and rehabilitation program was launched. The Awami League won the country's first general election in 1973, securing a large majority in the "<a href="/wiki/Jatiyo_Sangshad" class="mw-redirect" title="Jatiyo Sangshad">Jatiyo Sangshad</a>", the national parliament. Bangladesh joined the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the UN, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, and Rahman strengthened ties with India. Amid growing agitation by the opposition <a href="/wiki/National_Awami_Party" title="National Awami Party">National Awami Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jashod" class="mw-redirect" title="Jashod">Jashod</a>, he became increasingly authoritarian. Rahman amended the constitution, giving himself more emergency powers (including the suspension of fundamental rights). The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_famine_of_1974" title="Bangladesh famine of 1974">Bangladesh famine of 1974</a> also worsened the political situation.<sup id="cite_ref-Lewis2011_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011-139">[139]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span id="Presidential_era_and_coups_.281975.E2.80.931991.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidential_era_and_coups_(1975â1991)">Presidential era and coups (1975â1991)</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Military_coups_in_Bangladesh" title="Military coups in Bangladesh">Military coups in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:214px;max-width:214px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:103px;max-width:103px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ziaur_Rahman_1979.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Ziaur Rahman" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ziaur_Rahman_1979.jpg/101px-Ziaur_Rahman_1979.jpg" decoding="async" width="101" height="135" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ziaur_Rahman_1979.jpg/152px-Ziaur_Rahman_1979.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Ziaur_Rahman_1979.jpg/202px-Ziaur_Rahman_1979.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1230" data-file-height="1640"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Ziaur_Rahman" title="Ziaur Rahman">Ziaur Rahman</a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:107px;max-width:107px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Hussain Muhammad Ershad" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad.jpg/105px-Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad.jpg" decoding="async" width="105" height="135" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad.jpg/158px-Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad.jpg/210px-Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad.jpg 2x" data-file-width="760" data-file-height="980"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad" title="Hussain Muhammad Ershad">H. M. Ershad</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Zia and Ershad were the country's strongmen between 1975â1981 and 1982â1990 respectively
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In January 1975, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman introduced <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party socialist rule</a> under <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Krishak_Sramik_Awami_League" title="Bangladesh Krishak Sramik Awami League">BAKSAL</a>. Rahman banned all newspapers except four state-owned publications, and amended the constitution to increase his power. He was <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Assassination of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">assassinated</a> during a coup on 15 August 1975. <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">Martial law</a> was declared, and the presidency passed to the <a href="/wiki/Usurper" title="Usurper">usurper</a> <a href="/wiki/Khondaker_Mostaq_Ahmad" title="Khondaker Mostaq Ahmad">Khondaker Mostaq Ahmad</a> for four months. Ahmad is widely regarded as a traitor by Bangladeshis.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> Tajuddin Ahmad, the nation's first prime minister, and four other independence leaders were assassinated on 4 November 1975. Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Abu_Sadat_Mohammad_Sayem" title="Abu Sadat Mohammad Sayem">Abu Sadat Mohammad Sayem</a> was installed as president by the military on 6 November 1975. Bangladesh was governed by a <a href="/wiki/Military_junta" title="Military junta">military junta</a> led by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Martial_Law_Administrator" title="Chief Martial Law Administrator">Chief Martial Law Administrator</a> for three years. In 1977, the army chief <a href="/wiki/Ziaur_Rahman" title="Ziaur Rahman">Ziaur Rahman</a> became president. Rahman reinstated <a href="/wiki/Multiparty" class="mw-redirect" title="Multiparty">multiparty</a> politics, <a href="/wiki/Privatised" class="mw-redirect" title="Privatised">privatised</a> industries and newspapers, established <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Export_Processing_Zone_Authority" title="Bangladesh Export Processing Zone Authority">BEPZA</a> and held the country's second general election in 1979. A <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-presidential">semi-presidential</a> system evolved, with the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Nationalist_Party" title="Bangladesh Nationalist Party">Bangladesh Nationalist Party</a> (BNP) governing until 1982. Rahman was assassinated in 1981, and was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_Bangladesh" title="Vice President of Bangladesh">Vice-President</a> <a href="/wiki/Abdus_Sattar_(president)" title="Abdus Sattar (president)">Abdus Sattar</a>. Sattar received 65.5 percent of the vote in the <a href="/wiki/1981_Bangladeshi_presidential_election" title="1981 Bangladeshi presidential election">1981 presidential election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Khasru_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khasru-141">[141]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After a year in office, Sattar was overthrown in the <a href="/wiki/1982_Bangladesh_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1982 Bangladesh coup d'Ã©tat">1982 Bangladesh coup d'Ã©tat</a>. Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/A._F._M._Ahsanuddin_Chowdhury" title="A. F. M. Ahsanuddin Chowdhury">A. F. M. Ahsanuddin Chowdhury</a> was installed as president, but army chief <a href="/wiki/Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad" title="Hussain Muhammad Ershad">Hussain Muhammad Ershad</a> became the country's <i>de facto</i> leader and assumed the presidency in 1983. Ershad lifted martial law in 1986. He governed with four successive prime ministers (<a href="/wiki/Ataur_Rahman_Khan" title="Ataur Rahman Khan">Ataur Rahman Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mizanur_Rahman_Chowdhury" title="Mizanur Rahman Chowdhury">Mizanur Rahman Chowdhury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moudud_Ahmed" title="Moudud Ahmed">Moudud Ahmed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kazi_Zafar_Ahmed" title="Kazi Zafar Ahmed">Kazi Zafar Ahmed</a>) and a parliament dominated by his <a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Party_(Ershad)" title="Jatiya Party (Ershad)">Jatiyo Party</a>. General elections were held in 1986 and 1988, although the latter was boycotted by the opposition BNP and Awami League. Ershad pursued administrative decentralisation, dividing the country into 64 districts, and pushed Parliament to make Islam the state religion in 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/1990_Mass_Uprising_in_Bangladesh" title="1990 Mass Uprising in Bangladesh">1990 mass uprising</a> forced him to resign, and Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Shahabuddin_Ahmed" title="Shahabuddin Ahmed">Shahabuddin Ahmed</a> led the country's first caretaker government as part of the transition to parliamentary rule.<sup id="cite_ref-Khasru_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khasru-141">[141]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span id="Current_parliamentary_era_.281991.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_parliamentary_era_(1991âpresent)">Current parliamentary era (1991âpresent)</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/2006-2008_Bangladeshi_political_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="2006-2008 Bangladeshi political crisis">2006-2008 Bangladeshi political crisis</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:208px;max-width:208px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Sheikh Hasina" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg/100px-Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="100" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg/150px-Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg/200px-Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="318" data-file-height="424"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina" title="Sheikh Hasina">Sheikh Hasina</a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Begum_Zia_Book-opening_Ceremony,_1_Mar,_2010_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Khaleda Zia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Begum_Zia_Book-opening_Ceremony%2C_1_Mar%2C_2010_cropped.jpg/100px-Begum_Zia_Book-opening_Ceremony%2C_1_Mar%2C_2010_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="100" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Begum_Zia_Book-opening_Ceremony%2C_1_Mar%2C_2010_cropped.jpg/150px-Begum_Zia_Book-opening_Ceremony%2C_1_Mar%2C_2010_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Begum_Zia_Book-opening_Ceremony%2C_1_Mar%2C_2010_cropped.jpg/200px-Begum_Zia_Book-opening_Ceremony%2C_1_Mar%2C_2010_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2106" data-file-height="2808"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Khaleda_Zia" title="Khaleda Zia">Khaleda Zia</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          The rivalry between Hasina and Zia has been dubbed the <i>Battle of the <a href="/wiki/Begum" title="Begum">Begums</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-The_Economist_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Economist-143">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar,_2017.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG/220px-Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG/330px-Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG/440px-Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1080"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar,_2017.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Rohingya_people" title="Rohingya people">Rohingya</a> refugees entering Bangladesh from Myanmar
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the 1991 general election, the twelfth amendment to the constitution restored the parliamentary republic and <a href="/wiki/Begum_Khaleda_Zia" class="mw-redirect" title="Begum Khaleda Zia">Begum Khaleda Zia</a> became Bangladesh's first female prime minister. Zia, a former first lady, led a BNP government from 1990 to 1996. In 1991 her finance minister, <a href="/wiki/Saifur_Rahman_(Bangladeshi_politician)" title="Saifur Rahman (Bangladeshi politician)">Saifur Rahman</a>, began a major program to liberalise the Bangladeshi economy.<sup id="cite_ref-Lewis2011_139-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011-139">[139]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In February 1996, <a href="/wiki/February_1996_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="February 1996 Bangladeshi general election">a general election</a> was held which was boycotted by all opposition parties giving a 300 (of 300) seat victory for BNP. This election was deemed illegitimate, so a system of a <a href="/wiki/Caretaker_government_of_Bangladesh" title="Caretaker government of Bangladesh">caretaker government</a> was introduced to oversee the transfer of power and a new election was held in June 1996, overseen by Justice <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Habibur_Rahman" title="Muhammad Habibur Rahman">Muhammad Habibur Rahman</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Chief_Adviser_of_Bangladesh" title="Chief Adviser of Bangladesh">Chief Adviser of Bangladesh</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Awami_League" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh Awami League">Awami League</a> won the <a href="/wiki/June_1996_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="June 1996 Bangladeshi general election">seventh general election</a>, marking its leader <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina" title="Sheikh Hasina">Sheikh Hasina's</a> first term as Prime Minister. Hasina's first term was highlighted by the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts_Peace_Accord" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts Peace Accord">Chittagong Hill Tracts Peace Accord</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> water-sharing treaty with India. The second caretaker government, led by Chief Adviser Justice <a href="/wiki/Latifur_Rahman" title="Latifur Rahman">Latifur Rahman</a>, oversaw the <a href="/wiki/2001_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2001 Bangladeshi general election">2001 Bangladeshi general election</a> which returned Begum Zia and the BNP to power. </p>
      <p>The second Zia administration saw improved economic growth, but political turmoil gripped the country between 2004 and 2006. A radical Islamist militant group, the <a href="/wiki/Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen_Bangladesh" title="Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh">JMB</a>, carried out a series of terror attacks. The evidence of staging these attacks by these extremist groups have been found in the investigation, and hundreds of suspected members were detained in numerous security operations in 2006, including the two chiefs of the JMB, <a href="/wiki/Shaykh_Abdur_Rahman" title="Shaykh Abdur Rahman">Shaykh Abdur Rahman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bangla_Bhai" title="Bangla Bhai">Bangla Bhai</a>, who were executed with other top leaders in March 2007, bringing the militant group to an end.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2006, at the end of the term of the BNP administration, there was widespread political unrest related to the handover of power to a caretaker government. As such, the Bangladeshi military urged President <a href="/wiki/Iajuddin_Ahmed" title="Iajuddin Ahmed">Iajuddin Ahmed</a> to impose a <a href="/wiki/State_of_emergency" title="State of emergency">state of emergency</a> and a caretaker government, led by technocrat <a href="/wiki/Fakhruddin_Ahmed" title="Fakhruddin Ahmed">Fakhruddin Ahmed</a>, was installed.<sup id="cite_ref-Lewis2011_139-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011-139">[139]</a></sup> Emergency rule lasted for two years, during which time investigations into members of both Awami League and BNP were conducted, including their leaders <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina" title="Sheikh Hasina">Sheikh Hasina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Khaleda_Zia" title="Khaleda Zia">Khaleda Zia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> In 2008 the <a href="/wiki/2008_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2008 Bangladeshi general election">ninth general election</a> saw a return to power for Sheikh Hasina and the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Awami_League" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh Awami League">Awami League</a> led <a href="/wiki/Grand_Alliance_(Bangladesh)" title="Grand Alliance (Bangladesh)">Grand Alliance</a> in a landslide victory. In 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh" title="Supreme Court of Bangladesh">Supreme Court</a> ruled martial law illegal and affirmed <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular</a> principles in the constitution. The following year, the Awami League abolished the caretaker-government system. </p>
      <p>Citing the lack of caretaker government the <a href="/wiki/2014_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2014 Bangladeshi general election">2014 general election</a> was boycotted by the BNP and other opposition parties, giving the Awami League a decisive victory. The election was controversial with reports of violence and an alleged crackdown on the opposition in the run-up to the election and 153 seats (of 300) went uncontested in the election. Despite the controversy, Hasina went on to form a government that saw her return for a third term as Prime Minister. Due to strong domestic demand, Bangladesh emerged as one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest-growing economies in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_abuses" class="mw-redirect" title="Human rights abuses">human rights abuses</a> increased under the Hasina administration, particularly <a href="/wiki/Forced_disappearance_in_Bangladesh" title="Forced disappearance in Bangladesh">enforced disappearances</a>. Between 2016 and 2017, an estimated 1 million <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_refugees_in_Bangladesh" title="Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh">Rohingya refugees</a> took shelter in <a href="/wiki/Cox%27s_Bazar_District" title="Cox's Bazar District">southeastern Bangladesh</a> amid a military crackdown in neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Rakhine_State" title="Rakhine State">Rakhine State</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>. </p>
      <p>In 2018, the country saw major movements for <a href="/wiki/2018_Bangladesh_quota_reform_movement" title="2018 Bangladesh quota reform movement">government quota reforms</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_Bangladesh_road-safety_protests" title="2018 Bangladesh road-safety protests">road-safety</a>. The <a href="/wiki/2018_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2018 Bangladeshi general election">2018 Bangladeshi general election</a> was marred by allegations of widespread <a href="/wiki/Vote_rigging" class="mw-redirect" title="Vote rigging">vote rigging</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> The Awami League won 259 out of 300 seats and the main opposition alliance <a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Oikya_Front" title="Jatiya Oikya Front">Jatiya Oikya Front</a> secured only 8 seats, with Sheikh Hasina becoming the longest-serving prime minister in Bangladeshi history.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Pro-democracy leader Dr. <a href="/wiki/Kamal_Hossain" title="Kamal Hossain">Kamal Hossain</a> called for an annulment of the election result and for a new election to be held in a free and fair manner.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> The election was also observed by <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> observers.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Bangladesh" title="Geography of Bangladesh">Geography of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg/220px-Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="272" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg/330px-Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg/440px-Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1678" data-file-height="2074"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Physical map of Bangladesh
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh is a small, lush country in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>; located on the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>. It is surrounded almost entirely by neighbouring <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>âand shares a small border with <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> to its southeast, thought it lies very close to <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. The country is divided between three regions. Most of the country is dominated by the fertile <a href="/wiki/Ganges_Delta" title="Ganges Delta">Ganges Delta</a>, the largest river delta in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> The northwest and central parts of the country are formed by the <a href="/wiki/Madhupur_tract" title="Madhupur tract">Madhupur</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Barind_Tract" title="Barind Tract">Barind</a> plateaus. The northeast and southeast are home to <a href="/wiki/Evergreen" title="Evergreen">evergreen</a> hill ranges. </p>
      <p>The Ganges delta is formed by the confluence of the Ganges (local name <a href="/wiki/Padma_River" title="Padma River">Padma</a> or <i>PÃ´dda</i>), <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_River" title="Brahmaputra River">Brahmaputra</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jamuna_River_(Bangladesh)" title="Jamuna River (Bangladesh)">Jamuna</a> or <i>Jomuna</i>), and <a href="/wiki/Meghna_River" title="Meghna River">Meghna</a> rivers and their respective tributaries. The Ganges unites with the Jamuna (main channel of the Brahmaputra) and later joins the Meghna, finally flowing into the Bay of Bengal. Bangladesh is called the "Land of Rivers";<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> as it is home to over 57 <a href="/wiki/Trans-boundary_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Trans-boundary river">trans-boundary rivers</a>. However, this, makes the resolution of water issues politically complicated, in most cases, as the country is a lower <a href="/wiki/Riparian_zone" title="Riparian zone">riparian</a> state to India.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladesh is predominantly rich fertile flat land. Most of it is less than 12&nbsp;m (39&nbsp;ft) above sea level, and it is estimated that about 10% of its land would be flooded if the sea level were to rise by 1&nbsp;m (3.3&nbsp;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-ali_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ali-156">[156]</a></sup> 17% of the country is covered by forests and 12% is covered by hill systems. The country's <a href="/wiki/Haor" title="Haor">haor</a> wetlands are of significance to global environmental science. </p>
      <p>With an elevation of 1,064&nbsp;m (3,491&nbsp;ft), <a href="/wiki/Saka_Haphong" title="Saka Haphong">Saka Haphong</a> (also known as Mowdok Mual) near the border with <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, is claimed to be the highest peak of Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> However, it is not yet widely recognised as the highest point of the country, and most sources give the honor to <a href="/wiki/Keokradong" title="Keokradong">Keokradong</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-158">[158]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_geography">Administrative geography</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_geography_of_Bangladesh" title="Administrative geography of Bangladesh">Administrative geography of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Divisions_of_Bangladesh" title="Divisions of Bangladesh">Divisions of Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Bangladesh" title="Districts of Bangladesh">Districts of Bangladesh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Upazilas_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Upazilas of Bangladesh">Upazilas of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="floatright">
       <div class="noresize" style="height: 416px; width: 300px; ">

coords="117,86,112,92,116,98,108,110,112,128,115,145,122,141,121,133,124,131,126,133,135,131,137,134,143,150,147,164,159,159,171,164,171,158,165,150,174,147,194,142,208,139,206,131,194,120,192,105,177,104,163,104,144,100,128,94,124,94,116,90,113,92" alt="Mymensingh Division" title="Mymensingh Division"><area href="/wiki/Dhaka_Division" shape="poly" coords="135,127,122,136,113,146,111,154,116,167,116,178,109,183,111,194,99,196,90,191,85,199,92,203,105,230,120,259,142,246,146,250,154,250,163,244,164,226,165,211,171,204,177,193,186,189,194,176,193,170,201,164,208,160,207,139,183,146,167,149,172,153,172,160,164,164,160,159,153,164,143,160,144,150,136,141,135,126,116,143" alt="Dhaka Division" title="Dhaka Division"><area href="/wiki/Barisal_Division" shape="poly" coords="153,251,174,260,188,287,190,309,177,326,144,333,126,331,121,304,124,279,124,260,140,247,169,253" alt="Barisal Division" title="Barisal Division"><area href="/wiki/Sylhet_Division" shape="poly" coords="192,100,217,104,244,101,263,101,283,112,289,122,274,125,266,148,256,158,251,169,250,171,240,166,240,172,233,169,233,174,218,175,217,184,212,183,213,165,206,164,209,160,209,145,209,135,206,124,197,119,194,103,210,99" alt="Sylhet Division" title="Sylhet Division"><area href="/wiki/Chittagong_Division" shape="poly" coords="212,167,214,184,205,194,203,210,210,230,216,247,219,246,218,235,223,235,228,253,238,253,243,244,242,231,251,223,255,218,253,203,260,208,268,203,274,208,280,235,281,254,285,265,296,309,294,310,296,329,294,344,299,369,294,372,289,365,286,364,278,357,274,365,270,369,270,379,278,403,277,405,262,379,256,360,251,354,248,355,247,337,247,326,247,316,239,292,228,293,222,300,204,308,179,311,185,287,175,262,164,247,163,226,171,216,171,203,179,194,188,189,194,180,194,171,212,168" alt="Chittagong Division" title="Chittagong Division"></map>
        <img alt="A clickable map of Bangladesh exhibiting its divisions." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg/300px-Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="416" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg/450px-Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg/600px-Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1550" data-file-height="2150" usemap="#ImageMap_7e2ae818281c9310">
        <div style="margin-left: 280px; margin-top: -415px; text-align: left;">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg" title="About this image"><img alt="About this image" src="/w/extensions/ImageMap/resources/desc-20.png?15600" style="border: none;"></a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh is divided into eight administrative divisions,<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CIA_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-158">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> each named after their respective divisional headquarters: <a href="/wiki/Barisal_Division" title="Barisal Division">Barisal</a> (officially <i>Barishal</i><sup id="cite_ref-namechange_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-namechange-161">[161]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Division" title="Chittagong Division">Chittagong</a> (officially <i>Chattogram</i><sup id="cite_ref-namechange_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-namechange-161">[161]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Division" title="Dhaka Division">Dhaka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khulna_Division" title="Khulna Division">Khulna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh_Division" title="Mymensingh Division">Mymensingh</a>, Rajshahi, Rangpur, and Sylhet. </p>
      <p>Divisions are subdivided into districts (<i>zila</i>). There are 64 districts in Bangladesh, each further subdivided into <i>upazila</i> (subdistricts) or <i>thana</i>. The area within each police station, except for those in metropolitan areas, is divided into several <i><a href="/wiki/Union_Councils_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Union Councils of Bangladesh">unions</a></i>, with each union consisting of multiple villages. In the metropolitan areas, police stations are divided into wards, which are further divided into <i>mahallas</i>. </p>
      <p>There are no elected officials at the divisional or district levels, and the administration is composed only of government officials. Direct elections are held in each union (or ward) for a chairperson and a number of members. In 1997, a parliamentary act was passed to reserve three seats (out of 12) in every union for female candidates.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: right">

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Bangladesh#Climate" title="Geography of Bangladesh">Geography of Bangladesh Â§&nbsp;Climate</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Bangladesh" title="Climate change in Bangladesh">Climate change in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1240" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen-Geiger climate classification</a> map for Bangladesh<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg/220px-Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg/330px-Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg/440px-Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2810" data-file-height="1890"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Flooding after the <a href="/wiki/1991_Bangladesh_cyclone" title="1991 Bangladesh cyclone">1991 Bangladesh cyclone</a>, which killed around 140,000&nbsp;people.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Straddling the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Cancer" title="Tropic of Cancer">Tropic of Cancer</a>, Bangladesh's climate is tropical with a mild winter from October to March, and a hot, humid summer from March to June. The country has never recorded an air temperature below 0&nbsp;Â°C (32&nbsp;Â°F), with a record low of 1.1&nbsp;Â°C (34.0&nbsp;Â°F) in the north west city of <a href="/wiki/Dinajpur" title="Dinajpur">Dinajpur</a> on 3 February 1905.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> A warm and humid <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> season lasts from June to October and supplies most of the country's rainfall. </p>
      <p>Natural calamities, such as <a href="/wiki/Floods_in_Bangladesh" title="Floods in Bangladesh">floods</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone">tropical cyclones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tornado" title="Tornado">tornadoes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tidal_bore" title="Tidal bore">tidal bores</a> occur almost every year,<sup id="cite_ref-NatDis_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NatDis-166">[166]</a></sup> combined with the effects of <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">deforestation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soils_retrogression_and_degradation" class="mw-redirect" title="Soils retrogression and degradation">soil degradation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">erosion</a>. The <a href="/wiki/List_of_Bangladesh_tropical_cyclones" title="List of Bangladesh tropical cyclones">cyclones</a> of 1970 and 1991 were particularly devastating, the <a href="/wiki/1991_Bangladesh_cyclone" title="1991 Bangladesh cyclone">latter</a> killing some 140,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 1998, Bangladesh saw <a href="/wiki/1998_Bangladesh_floods" class="mw-redirect" title="1998 Bangladesh floods">the most severe flooding</a> in modern world history. As the Brahmaputra, the Ganges and <a href="/wiki/Meghna" class="mw-redirect" title="Meghna">Meghna</a> spilt over and swallowed 300,000 houses, 9,700&nbsp;km (6,000&nbsp;mi) of road and 2,700&nbsp;km (1,700&nbsp;mi) of embankment, 1,000&nbsp;people were killed and 30&nbsp;million more were made homeless; 135,000 cattle were killed; 50&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (19&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) of land were destroyed; and 11,000&nbsp;km (6,800&nbsp;mi) of roads were damaged or destroyed. Effectively, two-thirds of the country was underwater. The severity of the flooding was attributed to unusually high monsoon rains, the shedding of equally unusually large amounts of melt water from the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a>, and the widespread cutting down of trees (that would have intercepted rain water) for firewood or animal husbandry.<sup id="cite_ref-EWG_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWG-168">[168]</a></sup> As a result of various international and national level initiatives in disaster risk reduction, human toll and economic damage from floods and cyclones have come down over the years.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> A similar country wide flood in 2007, which left five million people displaced, had a death toll around 500.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladesh is recognised to be one of the countries most <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_vulnerability" title="Climate change vulnerability">vulnerable to climate change</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> Over the course of a century, 508 cyclones have affected the Bay of Bengal region, 17 percent of which are believed to have caused landfall in Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> Natural hazards that come from increased rainfall, rising sea levels, and tropical cyclones are expected to increase as the climate changes, each seriously affecting agriculture, water and food security, human health, and shelter.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> It is estimated that by 2050, a 3 feet rise in sea levels will inundate some 20 percent of the land and displace more than 30 million people.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> To address the <a href="/wiki/Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise">sea level rise</a> threat in Bangladesh, the Bangladesh Delta Plan 2100 has been launched.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-176">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Wildlife of Bangladesh">Wildlife of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Bangladesh" title="Fauna of Bangladesh">Fauna of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg/220px-Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg/330px-Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg/440px-Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1067"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a>, the national animal, in the Sundarbans
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh ratified the Rio <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Convention on Biological Diversity</a> on 3 May 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-cbd.int_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbd.int-178">[178]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country was set to revise its <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_action_plan" title="Biodiversity action plan">National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cbd.int_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbd.int-178">[178]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladesh is located in the <a href="/wiki/Indomalayan_realm" title="Indomalayan realm">Indomalayan realm</a>, and lies within four terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Lower_Gangetic_Plains_moist_deciduous_forests" title="Lower Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests">Lower Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mizoram%E2%80%93Manipur%E2%80%93Kachin_rain_forests" title="MizoramâManipurâKachin rain forests">MizoramâManipurâKachin rain forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_freshwater_swamp_forests" class="mw-redirect" title="Sundarbans freshwater swamp forests">Sundarbans freshwater swamp forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_mangroves" class="mw-redirect" title="Sundarbans mangroves">Sundarbans mangroves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-179">[179]</a></sup> Its ecology includes a long sea coastline, numerous <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="List of rivers in Bangladesh">rivers and tributaries</a>, lakes, <a href="/wiki/Wetland" title="Wetland">wetlands</a>, evergreen forests, semi evergreen forests, hill forests, moist <a href="/wiki/Deciduous_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Deciduous forest">deciduous forests</a>, freshwater swamp forests and flat land with tall grass. The Bangladesh Plain is famous for its fertile <a href="/wiki/Alluvial" class="mw-redirect" title="Alluvial">alluvial</a> soil which supports extensive cultivation. The country is dominated by lush vegetation, with villages often buried in groves of <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">mango</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jackfruit" title="Jackfruit">jackfruit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Betel_nut" class="mw-redirect" title="Betel nut">betel nut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">coconut</a> and <a href="/wiki/Date_palm" title="Date palm">date palm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-global.britannica.com_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-global.britannica.com-180">[180]</a></sup> The country has up to 6000 species of plant life, including 5000 flowering plants.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Water bodies and wetland systems provide a habitat for many aquatic plants. <a href="/wiki/Nymphaeaceae" title="Nymphaeaceae">Water lilies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nelumbo_nucifera" title="Nelumbo nucifera">lotuses</a> grow vividly during the monsoon season. The country has <a href="/wiki/List_of_protected_areas_of_Bangladesh" title="List of protected areas of Bangladesh">50 wildlife sanctuaries</a>. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh is home to much of the <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans" title="Sundarbans">Sundarbans</a>, the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Mangrove_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Mangrove forest">mangrove forest</a>, covering an area of 6,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> in the southwest littoral region. It is divided into three protected sanctuariesâthe <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_South_Wildlife_Sanctuary" title="Sundarbans South Wildlife Sanctuary">South</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_East_Wildlife_Sanctuary" title="Sundarbans East Wildlife Sanctuary">East</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_West_Wildlife_Sanctuary" title="Sundarbans West Wildlife Sanctuary">West</a> zones. The forest is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The northeastern Sylhet region is home to haor wetlands, which is a unique ecosystem. It also includes <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_coniferous_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical coniferous forests">tropical and subtropical coniferous forests</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Freshwater_swamp_forest" title="Freshwater swamp forest">freshwater swamp forest</a>, and mixed deciduous forests. The southeastern <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Division" title="Chittagong Division">Chittagong region</a> covers evergreen and semi-evergreen hilly jungles. Central Bangladesh includes the plainland Sal forest running along the districts of Gazipur, <a href="/wiki/Tangail" title="Tangail">Tangail</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh" title="Mymensingh">Mymensingh</a>. <a href="/wiki/St._Martin%27s_Island" title="St. Martin's Island">St. Martin's Island</a> is the only <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reef</a> in the country. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh has an abundance of <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Wildlife in Bangladesh">wildlife</a> in its forests, marshes, woodlands and hills.<sup id="cite_ref-global.britannica.com_180-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-global.britannica.com-180">[180]</a></sup> The vast majority of animals dwell within a habitat of 150,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clouded_leopard" title="Clouded leopard">clouded leopard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saltwater_crocodile" title="Saltwater crocodile">saltwater crocodile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_panther" title="Black panther">black panther</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing_cat" title="Fishing cat">fishing cat</a> are among the chief predators in the Sundarbans.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> Northern and eastern Bangladesh is home to the <a href="/wiki/Asian_elephant" title="Asian elephant">Asian elephant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hoolock_gibbon" title="Hoolock gibbon">hoolock gibbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asian_black_bear" title="Asian black bear">Asian black bear</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oriental_pied_hornbill" title="Oriental pied hornbill">oriental pied hornbill</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bearprojectbd.weebly.com_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bearprojectbd.weebly.com-184">[184]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Chital" title="Chital">Chital</a> deer are widely seen in southwestern woodlands. Other animals include the <a href="/wiki/Black_giant_squirrel" title="Black giant squirrel">black giant squirrel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capped_langur" title="Capped langur">capped langur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bengal_fox" title="Bengal fox">Bengal fox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sambar_deer" title="Sambar deer">sambar deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jungle_cat" title="Jungle cat">jungle cat</a>, <a href="/wiki/King_cobra" title="King cobra">king cobra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongoose" title="Mongoose">mongooses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangolin" title="Pangolin">pangolins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Python_(genus)" title="Python (genus)">pythons</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asian_water_monitor" title="Asian water monitor">water monitors</a>. Bangladesh has one of the largest populations of <a href="/wiki/Irrawaddy_dolphins" class="mw-redirect" title="Irrawaddy dolphins">Irrawaddy dolphins</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_river_dolphin" title="South Asian river dolphin">Ganges dolphins</a>. A 2009 census found 6,000 Irrawaddy dolphins inhabiting the littoral rivers of Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> The country has numerous species of <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibians</a> (53), reptiles (139), <a href="/wiki/Marine_reptile" title="Marine reptile">marine reptiles</a> (19) and <a href="/wiki/Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal">marine mammals</a> (5). It also has <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Bangladesh" title="List of birds of Bangladesh">628 species of birds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Several animals became extinct in Bangladesh during the last century, including the one-horned and two-horned <a href="/wiki/Rhinoceros" title="Rhinoceros">rhinoceros</a> and common <a href="/wiki/Peafowl" title="Peafowl">peafowl</a>. The human population is concentrated in urban areas, hence limiting deforestation to a certain extent. Rapid urban growth has threatened natural habitats. Although many areas are protected under law, a large portion of Bangladeshi wildlife is threatened by this growth. Furthermore, access to <a href="/wiki/Biocapacity" title="Biocapacity">biocapacity</a> in Bangladesh is low. In 2016, Bangladesh had 0.4 global hectares<sup id="cite_ref-GFN_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GFN-187">[187]</a></sup> of biocapacity per person within its territory, or about one fourth of the world average.
