In contrast, in 2016, they used 0.84 global hectares of biocapacity â their <a href="/wiki/Ecological_footprint" title="Ecological footprint">ecological footprint</a> of consumption. As a result, Bangladesh is running a biocapacity deficit.<sup id="cite_ref-GFN_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GFN-187">[187]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Environment_Conservation_Act" title="Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act">Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act</a> was enacted in 1995. The government has designated several regions as <a href="/wiki/Ecologically_Critical_Area" title="Ecologically Critical Area">Ecologically Critical Areas</a>, including wetlands, forests, and rivers. The <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_tiger_project" class="mw-redirect" title="Sundarbans tiger project">Sundarbans tiger project</a> and the Bangladesh Bear Project are among the key initiatives to strengthen conservation.<sup id="cite_ref-bearprojectbd.weebly.com_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bearprojectbd.weebly.com-184">[184]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_government">Politics and government</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Bangladesh" title="Politics of Bangladesh">Politics of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:140px;max-width:140px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Abdul_Hamid_-_2014_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Abdul_Hamid_-_2014_%28cropped%29.jpg/138px-Abdul_Hamid_-_2014_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="138" height="194" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Abdul_Hamid_-_2014_%28cropped%29.jpg/207px-Abdul_Hamid_-_2014_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Abdul_Hamid_-_2014_%28cropped%29.jpg/276px-Abdul_Hamid_-_2014_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="303" data-file-height="427"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hamid_(politician)" title="Abdul Hamid (politician)">Abdul Hamid</a>, President since 2013
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:148px;max-width:148px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg/146px-Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="146" height="195" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg/219px-Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg/292px-Sheikh_Hasina_in_London_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="318" data-file-height="424"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina" title="Sheikh Hasina">Sheikh Hasina</a>, Prime Minister since 2009
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bangabhaban,_Dhaka_April_(33244270994).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Bangabhaban%2C_Dhaka_April_%2833244270994%29.jpg/220px-Bangabhaban%2C_Dhaka_April_%2833244270994%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="126" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Bangabhaban%2C_Dhaka_April_%2833244270994%29.jpg/330px-Bangabhaban%2C_Dhaka_April_%2833244270994%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Bangabhaban%2C_Dhaka_April_%2833244270994%29.jpg/440px-Bangabhaban%2C_Dhaka_April_%2833244270994%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1700" data-file-height="976"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bangabhaban,_Dhaka_April_(33244270994).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bangabhaban" title="Bangabhaban">Bangabhaban</a>, the residence of the President of Bangladesh
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh is a <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a> under its <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Bangladesh" title="Constitution of Bangladesh">constitution</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster</a>-style <a href="/wiki/Unitary_authority" title="Unitary authority">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> that has <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>. The head of government is the Prime Minister, who is invited to form a government every five years by the President. The President invites the leader of the largest party in parliament to become Prime Minister of the world's fifth-largest democracy.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> Bangladesh experienced a <a href="/wiki/Two_party_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Two party system">two party system</a> between 1990 and 2014, when the <a href="/wiki/Awami_League" title="Awami League">Awami League</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Nationalist_Party" title="Bangladesh Nationalist Party">Bangladesh Nationalist Party</a> (BNP) alternated in power. During this period, elections were managed by a neutral <a href="/wiki/Caretaker_government_of_Bangladesh" title="Caretaker government of Bangladesh">caretaker government</a>. But the caretaker government was abolished by the Awami League government in 2011. The BNP boycotted the next election in 2014, arguing that it would not be fair without a caretaker government. The BNP-led <a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Oikya_Front" title="Jatiya Oikya Front">Jatiya Oikya Front</a> participated in the 2018 election and lost. The election saw many allegations of irregularities. Bangladesh has a prominent <a href="/wiki/Civil_society" title="Civil society">civil society</a> since the colonial period. There are various special interest groups, including <a href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organisations" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-governmental organisations">non-governmental organisations</a>, human rights organisations, professional associations, <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_commerce" title="Chamber of commerce">chambers of commerce</a>, employers' associations and <a href="/wiki/Trade_unions" class="mw-redirect" title="Trade unions">trade unions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>One of the key aspects of Bangladeshi politics is the "spirit of the liberation war" which refers to the ideals of the liberation movement during the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> The Proclamation of Independence enunciated the values of "equality, human dignity and social justice". In 1972, the constitution included a <a href="/wiki/Bill_of_rights" title="Bill of rights">bill of rights</a> and declared "nationalism, socialism, democracy and <a href="/wiki/Secularity" title="Secularity">secularity</a>" as the principles of government policy. Socialism was later de-emphasised and neglected by successive governments. Bangladesh has a market-based economy. To many Bangladeshis, especially in the younger generation, the spirit of the liberation war is a vision for a society based on civil liberties, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Executive_branch">Executive branch</span></h3> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of Bangladesh">Government of Bangladesh</a> is overseen by a <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Bangladesh" title="Cabinet of Bangladesh">cabinet</a> headed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bangladesh" title="Prime Minister of Bangladesh">Prime Minister of Bangladesh</a>. The tenure of a parliamentary government is five years. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Civil_Service" title="Bangladesh Civil Service">Bangladesh Civil Service</a> assists the cabinet in running the government. Recruitment for the civil service is based on a public examination. In theory, the civil service should be a meritocracy. But a disputed quota system coupled with politicisation and preference for seniority have allegedly affected the civil service's meritocracy.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Bangladesh" title="President of Bangladesh">President of Bangladesh</a> is the ceremonial head of state<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> whose powers include signing bills passed by parliament into law. The President is elected by the parliament and has a five-year term. Under the constitution, the president acts on the advice of the prime minister. The President is the Supreme Commander of the Bangladesh Armed Forces and the chancellor of all universities. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legislative_branch">Legislative branch</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_(06).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%2806%29.jpg/220px-National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%2806%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%2806%29.jpg/330px-National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%2806%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%2806%29.jpg/440px-National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%2806%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6816" data-file-height="4401"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_(06).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Sangsad_Bhaban" title="Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban">The National Assembly of Bangladesh</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Sangshad" class="mw-redirect" title="Jatiya Sangshad">Jatiya Sangshad</a> (National Assembly) is the <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> parliament. It has 350 <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament" title="Member of parliament">Members of Parliament</a> (MPs), including 300 MPs elected on the <a href="/wiki/First_past_the_post" class="mw-redirect" title="First past the post">first past the post</a> system and 50 MPs appointed to reserved seats for <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_empowerment" title="Women's empowerment">women's empowerment</a>. <a href="/wiki/Article_70_of_the_Constitution_of_Bangladesh" title="Article 70 of the Constitution of Bangladesh">Article 70 of the Constitution of Bangladesh</a> forbids MPs from voting against their party. However, several laws proposed independently by MPs have been transformed into legislation, including the anti-torture law.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> The parliament is presided over by the <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Jatiya_Sangsad" title="Speaker of the Jatiya Sangsad">Speaker of the Jatiya Sangsad</a>, who is second in line to the president as per the constitution. There is also a Deputy Speaker. When a president is incapable of performing duties (i.e. due to illness), the Speaker steps in as <a href="/wiki/Acting_President" class="mw-redirect" title="Acting President">Acting President</a> and the Deputy Speaker becomes Acting Speaker. A recurring proposal suggests that the Deputy Speaker should be a member of the opposition.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">Legal system</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Laws_in_Bangladesh" title="Laws in Bangladesh">Laws in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Long, white, domed building" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg/220px-Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg/330px-Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg/440px-Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4772" data-file-height="3181"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh_12.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh" title="Supreme Court of Bangladesh">Supreme Court of Bangladesh</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh" title="Supreme Court of Bangladesh">Supreme Court of Bangladesh</a> is the highest court of the land followed by the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_Division" title="High Court Division">High Court</a> and Appellate Divisions. The head of the judiciary is the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Bangladesh" title="Chief Justice of Bangladesh">Chief Justice of Bangladesh</a>, who sits on the Supreme Court. The courts have wide latitude in <a href="/wiki/Judicial_review_in_Bangladesh" title="Judicial review in Bangladesh">judicial review</a> and judicial <a href="/wiki/Precedent" title="Precedent">precedent</a> is supported by Article 111 of the constitution. The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Bangladesh" title="Judiciary of Bangladesh">judiciary</a> includes district and metropolitan courts, which are divided into civil and criminal courts. Due to a shortage of judges, the judiciary has a large backlog. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Judicial_Service_Commission" title="Bangladesh Judicial Service Commission">Bangladesh Judicial Service Commission</a> is an independent body responsible for judicial appointments, salaries, and discipline. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh's legal system is based on <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common law</a> and its principal source of laws are <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Acts of Parliament">acts of Parliament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Code" title="Bangladesh Code">Bangladesh Code</a> includes a list of all laws in force in the country. The code begins in 1836 and most of its listed laws were crafted under the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Legislative_Council" title="Bengal Legislative Council">Bengal Legislative Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Legislative_Assembly" title="Bengal Legislative Assembly">Bengal Legislative Assembly</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_and_Assam_Legislative_Council" title="Eastern Bengal and Assam Legislative Council">Eastern Bengal and Assam Legislative Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Legislative_Council" title="Imperial Legislative Council">Imperial Legislative Council</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">Parliament of the United Kingdom</a>. One example is the <a href="/wiki/The_Penal_Code,_1860_(Bangladesh)" title="The Penal Code, 1860 (Bangladesh)">1860 Penal Code</a>. From 1947 to 1971, laws were enacted by Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="National Assembly of Pakistan">national assembly</a> and the <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan_Provincial_Assembly" title="East Pakistan Provincial Assembly">East Pakistani legislature</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Bangladesh" title="Constituent Assembly of Bangladesh">Constituent Assembly of Bangladesh</a> was the country's provisional parliament until 1973, when the first elected Jatiyo Sangshad (National Parliament) was sworn in. Although most of Bangladesh's laws were compiled in English, after a 1987 government directive laws are now primarily written in <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>. While most of Bangladeshi law is <a href="/wiki/Secular" class="mw-redirect" title="Secular">secular</a>; marriage, divorce, and inheritance are governed by <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Islamic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_law" title="Hindu law">Hindu</a> and Christian <a href="/wiki/Family_law" title="Family law">family law</a>. The judiciary is often influenced by legal developments in the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Legitimate_expectation" title="Legitimate expectation">doctrine of legitimate expectation</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Armed_Forces" title="Bangladesh Armed Forces">Bangladesh Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg" class="image"><img alt="World map, indicating where the Bangladeshi UN peacekeeping force is stationed" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg/220px-BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg/330px-BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg/440px-BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1178" data-file-height="738"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_UN_Peacekeeping_Force" title="Bangladesh UN Peacekeeping Force">Bangladesh UN Peacekeeping Force</a> deployments
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Bangladesh Armed Forces have inherited the institutional framework of the <a href="/wiki/British_military" class="mw-redirect" title="British military">British military</a> and the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Army" title="British Indian Army">British Indian Army</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> It was formed in 1971 from the military regiments of East Pakistan. In 2018 the active personnel strength of the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Army" title="Bangladesh Army">Bangladesh Army</a> was around 157,500,<sup id="cite_ref-IISS_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IISS-198">[198]</a></sup> excluding the Air Force and the Navy (24,000).<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> In addition to traditional defence roles, the military has supported civil authorities in disaster relief and provided internal security during periods of political unrest. For many years, Bangladesh has been the world's largest contributor to <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping" title="United Nations peacekeeping">UN peacekeeping forces</a>. In February 2015, the country made major deployments to <a href="/wiki/Cote_d%27Ivoire" class="mw-redirect" title="Cote d'Ivoire">CÃ´te d'Ivoire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Darfur" title="Darfur">Darfur</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Congo" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic Republic of Congo">Democratic Republic of Congo</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Sudan" title="South Sudan">South Sudan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Navy" title="Bangladesh Navy">Bangladesh Navy</a> has the third-largest fleet of <a href="/wiki/Countries_dependent_on_the_Bay_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Countries dependent on the Bay of Bengal">countries dependent on the Bay of Bengal</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Guided-missile_frigate" class="mw-redirect" title="Guided-missile frigate">guided-missile frigates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cutter_(boat)" title="Cutter (boat)">cutters</a> and aircraft. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Air_Force" title="Bangladesh Air Force">Bangladesh Air Force</a> is equipped with several Russian multi-role fighter jets. Bangladesh cooperates defensively with the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">United States Armed Forces</a>, participating in the <a href="/wiki/Cooperation_Afloat_Readiness_and_Training" title="Cooperation Afloat Readiness and Training">Cooperation Afloat Readiness and Training</a> (CARAT) exercises. Ties between the Bangladeshi and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_military" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian military">Indian military</a> exist with high-level visits by the military chiefs of both countries.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> Most of Bangladesh's military equipment comes from China.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> In 2019, Bangladesh ratified the UN <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bangladesh" title="Foreign relations of Bangladesh">Foreign relations of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:1st_Saarc_summit.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Leaders seated at a dais" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/1st_Saarc_summit.jpg/220px-1st_Saarc_summit.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="89" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/1st_Saarc_summit.jpg/330px-1st_Saarc_summit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/1st_Saarc_summit.jpg/440px-1st_Saarc_summit.jpg 2x" data-file-width="497" data-file-height="200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:1st_Saarc_summit.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>First South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (<a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation" title="South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation">SAARC</a>) meeting in 1985 in <a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a> (<i>l-r, top row</i>: the presidents of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Maldives" title="Maldives">Maldives</a>, the king of <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, the president of Bangladesh, the prime minister of <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, the king of <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and the president of <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The first major intergovernmental organisation joined by Bangladesh was the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a> in 1972. The country joined the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> in 1974, and has been elected twice to the <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a>. Ambassador <a href="/wiki/Humayun_Rashid_Choudhury" title="Humayun Rashid Choudhury">Humayun Rashid Choudhury</a> was elected president of the <a href="/wiki/UN_General_Assembly" class="mw-redirect" title="UN General Assembly">UN General Assembly</a> in 1986. Bangladesh relies on <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateral</a> diplomacy in the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>. It is a major contributor to <a href="/wiki/UN_peacekeeping" class="mw-redirect" title="UN peacekeeping">UN peacekeeping</a>, providing 113,000 personnel to 54 UN missions in the Middle East, the Balkans, Africa and the Caribbean in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In addition to membership in the Commonwealth of Nations and the United Nations, Bangladesh pioneered regional co-operation in South Asia. Bangladesh is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation" title="South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation">South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation</a> (SAARC), an organisation designed to strengthen relations and promote economic and cultural growth among its members. It has hosted several summits and two Bangladeshi diplomats were the organisation's secretary-general. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh joined the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Islamic_Cooperation" class="mw-redirect" title="Organization of Islamic Cooperation">Organization of Islamic Cooperation</a> (OIC) in 1973. It has hosted the summit of OIC foreign ministers, which addresses issues, conflicts and disputes affecting <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim-majority countries</a>. Bangladesh is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Developing_8_Countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developing 8 Countries">Developing 8 Countries</a>, which is a bloc of eight Muslim-majority republics. </p>
      <p>The neighbouring country of <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> (Burma) was one of the first countries to recognise Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> Despite common regional interests, Bangladesh-Myanmar relations have been strained by the <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_genocide" title="Rohingya genocide">Rohingya refugee crisis</a> and the isolationist policies of the Myanmar military. In 2012, both countries came to terms at the <a href="/wiki/International_Tribunal_for_the_Law_of_the_Sea" title="International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea">International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea</a> over maritime boundaries in the Bay of Bengal.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> In 2016 and 2017, relations with Myanmar were strained once again as over 700,000 <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_refugees_in_Bangladesh" title="Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh">Rohingya refugees</a> illegally entered Bangladesh fleeing persecution, ethnic cleansing, genocide, and other atrocities in Myanmar. The parliament, government, and civil society of Bangladesh have been at the forefront of <a href="/wiki/International_reaction_to_the_2016%E2%80%9317_Rohingya_exodus" class="mw-redirect" title="International reaction to the 2016â17 Rohingya exodus">international criticism</a> against Myanmar for military operations against the Rohingya, which the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> has described as <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:US_President_Clinton_and_Prime_Minister_Sheikh_Hasina_make_a_joint_statement,_Prime_Minister%27s_office,_Bangladesh,_March_20,_2000.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/US_President_Clinton_and_Prime_Minister_Sheikh_Hasina_make_a_joint_statement%2C_Prime_Minister%27s_office%2C_Bangladesh%2C_March_20%2C_2000.jpg/220px-US_President_Clinton_and_Prime_Minister_Sheikh_Hasina_make_a_joint_statement%2C_Prime_Minister%27s_office%2C_Bangladesh%2C_March_20%2C_2000.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/US_President_Clinton_and_Prime_Minister_Sheikh_Hasina_make_a_joint_statement%2C_Prime_Minister%27s_office%2C_Bangladesh%2C_March_20%2C_2000.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="288" data-file-height="192"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:US_President_Clinton_and_Prime_Minister_Sheikh_Hasina_make_a_joint_statement,_Prime_Minister%27s_office,_Bangladesh,_March_20,_2000.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>PM Sheikh Hasina with US President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> at the Prime Minister's Office in Dhaka, 2000.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh's most politically important bilateral relationship is with neighbouring <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. In 2015, major Indian newspapers called Bangladesh a "trusted friend".<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> Bangladesh and India are South Asia's largest trading partners. The countries are collaborating in regional economic and infrastructure projects, such as a regional motor-vehicle agreement in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_South_Asia" title="Eastern South Asia">eastern South Asia</a> and a coastal shipping agreement in the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh-India_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh-India relations">Indo-Bangladesh relations</a> often emphasise a shared cultural heritage, democratic values and a history of support for <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladeshi independence</a>. Despite political goodwill, <a href="/wiki/Deaths_along_the_Bangladesh%E2%80%93India_border" title="Deaths along the BangladeshâIndia border">border killings of Bangladeshi civilians</a> and the lack of a comprehensive water-sharing agreement for 54 trans-boundary rivers are major issues. In 2017, India joined Russia and China in refusing to condemn Myanmar's atrocities against the <a href="/wiki/Rohingya" class="mw-redirect" title="Rohingya">Rohingya</a>, which contradicted with Bangladesh's demand for recognising Rohingya human rights.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> However, the Indian air force delivered aid shipments for Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> The crackdown against cattle smuggling in India has also affected Bangladesh. The Bangladeshi <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leather" title="Leather">leather</a> industries have seen increased prices due to the Indian <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">BJP</a> government's campaign against the export of beef and cattle skin.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan and Bangladesh have a US$550 million trade relationship,<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> particularly in Pakistani <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a> imports for the Bangladeshi textile industry. Although Bangladeshi and Pakistani businesses have invested in each other, diplomatic relations are strained because of Pakistani denial of the <a href="/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide">1971 Bangladesh genocide</a>. The execution of a <a href="/wiki/Jamaat-e-Islami" title="Jamaat-e-Islami">Jamaat-e-Islami</a> leader in 2013 on committing of <a href="/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide">war crimes</a> during the liberation war was opposed in Pakistan and led to further strained ties.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Bangladesh-China_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh-China relations">Sino-Bangladesh relations</a> date to the 1950s and are relatively warm, despite the Chinese leadership siding with Pakistan during Bangladesh's war of independence. China and Bangladesh established bilateral relations in 1976 which have significantly strengthened and the country is considered a cost-effective source of arms for the Bangladeshi military.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> Since the 1980s 80 percent of Bangladesh's military equipment has been supplied by China (often with generous credit terms), and China is Bangladesh's largest trading partner. Both countries are part of the <a href="/wiki/BCIM_Forum" class="mw-redirect" title="BCIM Forum">BCIM Forum</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg/220px-44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg/330px-44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg/440px-44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1203"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:44th_G7_summit_Photo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Bangladeshi Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina" title="Sheikh Hasina">Sheikh Hasina</a> (second from left on back row) with leaders of the <a href="/wiki/G7" class="mw-redirect" title="G7">G7</a> industrialised countries and other invitees during the 44th G7 summit in La Malbaie, Canada
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Japan is Bangladesh's largest economic-aid provider in the form of loans and the countries have common political goals.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.com.bd_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com.bd-217">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> has longstanding <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh-United_Kingdom_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh-United Kingdom relations">economic, cultural and military links</a> with Bangladesh. The United States is a major <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh-United_States_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh-United States relations">economic and security partner</a>, its largest export market and foreign investor. Seventy-six percent of <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshis" title="Bangladeshis">Bangladeshis</a> viewed the United States favourably in 2014, one of the highest ratings among <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asian</a> countries.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> The United States views Bangladesh as a key partner in the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pacific" title="Indo-Pacific">Indo-Pacific</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> is Bangladesh's largest regional market, conducting <a href="/wiki/Public_diplomacy" title="Public diplomacy">public diplomacy</a> and providing development assistance. </p>
      <p>Relations with other countries are generally positive. Shared democratic values ease relations with Western countries and similar economic concerns forge ties to other <a href="/wiki/Developing_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developing countries">developing countries</a>. Despite poor working conditions and war affecting overseas <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshis_in_the_Middle_East" title="Bangladeshis in the Middle East">Bangladeshi workers</a>, relations with <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle Eastern</a> countries are friendly and bounded by religion and culture. More than a million Bangladeshis are employed in the region. In 2016, the <a href="/wiki/King_of_Saudi_Arabia" title="King of Saudi Arabia">king of Saudi Arabia</a> called Bangladesh "one of the most important Muslim countries".<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> However, Bangladesh has not established diplomatic relationship with <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="BangladeshâIsrael relations">Israel</a><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> in support of a sovereign <a href="/wiki/Proposals_for_a_Palestinian_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Proposals for a Palestinian state">Palestinian state</a> and "an end to Israel's illegal occupation of Palestine".<sup id="cite_ref-mofabd_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mofabd-224">[224]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladeshi aid agencies work in many developing countries. An example is <a href="/wiki/BRAC_(NGO)" class="mw-redirect" title="BRAC (NGO)">BRAC</a> in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, which benefits 12 million people in that country.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> Bangladesh has a record of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_nonproliferation" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear nonproliferation">nuclear nonproliferation</a> as a party to the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Nonproliferation_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty">Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty</a> (NPT) and the <a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_Test_Ban_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty">Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty</a> (CTBT),<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> and is also a member of <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> since 1973. It is a state party to the <a href="/wiki/Rome_Statute_of_the_International_Criminal_Court" title="Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court">Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court</a>. Bangladeshi foreign policy is influenced by the principle of "friendship to all and malice to none", first articulated by Bengali statesman <a href="/wiki/H._S._Suhrawardy" class="mw-redirect" title="H. S. Suhrawardy">H. S. Suhrawardy</a> in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.com.bd_217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com.bd-217">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> Suhrawardy led East and West Pakistan to join the <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia_Treaty_Organization" title="Southeast Asia Treaty Organization">Southeast Asia Treaty Organization</a>, <a href="/wiki/CENTO" class="mw-redirect" title="CENTO">CENTO</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Regional_Cooperation_for_Development" title="Regional Cooperation for Development">Regional Cooperation for Development</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Bangladesh" title="Human rights in Bangladesh">Human rights in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_(8459696133).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_%288459696133%29.jpg/220px-Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_%288459696133%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_%288459696133%29.jpg/330px-Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_%288459696133%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_%288459696133%29.jpg/440px-Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_%288459696133%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5616" data-file-height="3744"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Protest_against_War_Crimes_at_Shahabag_Square_(8459696133).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/2013_Shahbag_protests" title="2013 Shahbag protests">2013 Shahbag protests</a> demanding the death penalty for the war criminals of the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">1971 war</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A list of <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_rights" title="Fundamental rights">fundamental rights</a> is enshrined in the country's constitution. The drafter of the constitution in 1972, Dr. <a href="/wiki/Kamal_Hossain" title="Kamal Hossain">Kamal Hossain</a>, was influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights" title="Universal Declaration of Human Rights">Universal Declaration of Human Rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> Bangladesh also recognises the <a href="/wiki/Third_gender" title="Third gender">third gender</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Bangladesh" title="LGBT rights in Bangladesh">Homosexuality</a> is outlawed by section 377 of the criminal code (a legacy of the colonial period), and is punishable by a maximum of life imprisonment.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Judicial_activism" title="Judicial activism">Judicial activism</a> has often upheld human rights. In the 1970s, judges invalidated detentions under the <a href="/wiki/Special_Powers_Act,_1974" class="mw-redirect" title="Special Powers Act, 1974">Special Powers Act, 1974</a> through cases such as <i><a href="/wiki/Aruna_Sen_v._Government_of_Bangladesh" title="Aruna Sen v. Government of Bangladesh">Aruna Sen v. Government of Bangladesh</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Abdul_Latif_Mirza_v._Government_of_Bangladesh" title="Abdul Latif Mirza v. Government of Bangladesh">Abdul Latif Mirza v. Government of Bangladesh</a></i>. In 2008, the Supreme Court paved the way for citizenship for the <a href="/wiki/Stranded_Pakistanis" class="mw-redirect" title="Stranded Pakistanis">Stranded Pakistanis</a>, who were an estimated 300,000 stateless people.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> Despite being a non-signatory of the UN Refugee Convention, Bangladesh has taken in <a href="/wiki/Rohingya" class="mw-redirect" title="Rohingya">Rohingya</a> refugees since 1978 and the country is now home to a million refugees. Bangladesh is an active member of the <a href="/wiki/International_Labour_Organization" title="International Labour Organization">International Labour Organization</a> (ILO) since 1972. It has ratified 33 ILO conventions, including the seven fundamental ILO conventions.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup> Bangladesh has ratified the <a href="/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Civil_and_Political_Rights" title="International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights">International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Economic,_Social_and_Cultural_Rights" title="International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights">International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> In 2018, Bangladesh came under heavy criticism for its repressive Digital Security Act which threatened <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a>. The photojournalist <a href="/wiki/Shahidul_Alam" title="Shahidul Alam">Shahidul Alam</a> was jailed and tortured for criticising the government.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> Alam was featured in the 2018 <i><a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year">Time Person of the Year</a></i> issue. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Human_Rights_Commission_of_Bangladesh" title="National Human Rights Commission of Bangladesh">National Human Rights Commission of Bangladesh</a> was set up in 2007. Notable human rights organisations and initiatives include the <a href="/wiki/Centre_for_Law_and_Mediation_(Bangladesh)" class="mw-redirect" title="Centre for Law and Mediation (Bangladesh)">Centre for Law and Mediation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odhikar" title="Odhikar">Odhikar</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_for_Bangladesh_Worker_Safety" title="Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety">Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Environmental_Lawyers_Association" title="Bangladesh Environmental Lawyers Association">Bangladesh Environmental Lawyers Association</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Hindu_Buddhist_Christian_Unity_Council" title="Bangladesh Hindu Buddhist Christian Unity Council">Bangladesh Hindu Buddhist Christian Unity Council</a> and the <a href="/wiki/War_Crimes_Fact_Finding_Committee" title="War Crimes Fact Finding Committee">War Crimes Fact Finding Committee</a>. </p>
      <p>Successive governments and their security forces have flouted constitutional principles and have been accused of <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a> abuses. Bangladesh is ranked "partly free" in <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a></i> report,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> but its press is ranked "not free".<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> According to the British <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a>, the country has a <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_regime" title="Hybrid regime">hybrid regime</a>: the third of four rankings in its <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> Bangladesh was the third-most-peaceful South Asian country in the 2015 <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Civil_society" title="Civil society">Civil society</a> and <a href="/wiki/Media_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Media in Bangladesh">media in Bangladesh</a> have been attacked by the ruling <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Awami_League" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh Awami League">Awami League</a> government and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_extremist" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic extremist">Islamic extremists</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thedailystar.net_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thedailystar.net-241">[241]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:R.A.B.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Armed men in black uniforms on a street" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/R.A.B.jpg/220px-R.A.B.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="329" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a9/R.A.B.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="306" data-file-height="458"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:R.A.B.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Bangladeshi law-enforcement agencies, including the <a href="/wiki/Rapid_Action_Battalion" title="Rapid Action Battalion">Rapid Action Battalion</a> <i>(pictured)</i>, have been accused of human-rights abuses
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to National Human Rights Commission, 70% of alleged human-rights violations are committed by law-enforcement agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> Targets have included <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> winner <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Yunus" title="Muhammad Yunus">Muhammad Yunus</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Grameen_Bank" title="Grameen Bank">Grameen Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Attacks_on_secularists_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Attacks on secularists in Bangladesh">secularist bloggers</a> and independent and pro-opposition newspapers and television networks. The United Nations is concerned about government "measures that restrict freedom of expression and democratic space".<sup id="cite_ref-thedailystar.net_241-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thedailystar.net-241">[241]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladeshi security forces, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Rapid_Action_Battalion" title="Rapid Action Battalion">Rapid Action Battalion</a> (RAB), have received international condemnation for human-rights abuses (including <a href="/wiki/Enforced_disappearances" class="mw-redirect" title="Enforced disappearances">enforced disappearances</a>, <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Extrajudicial_killing" title="Extrajudicial killing">extrajudicial killings</a>). Over 1,000 people have been said to have been victims of extrajudicial killings by RAB since its inception under the last <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Nationalist_Party" title="Bangladesh Nationalist Party">Bangladesh Nationalist Party</a> government.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> The RAB has been called a "<a href="/wiki/Death_squad" title="Death squad">death squad</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-hrw.org_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw.org-244">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dw.com_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dw.com-245">[245]</a></sup> which have called for the force to be disbanded.<sup id="cite_ref-hrw.org_244-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw.org-244">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dw.com_245-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dw.com-245">[245]</a></sup> The British and American governments have been criticised for funding and engaging the force in counter-terrorism operations.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Bangladeshi government has not fully implemented the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts_Peace_Accord" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts Peace Accord">Chittagong Hill Tracts Peace Accord</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> The Hill Tracts region remains heavily militarised, despite a peace treaty with <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Indigenous people">indigenous people</a> forged by the <a href="/wiki/Parbatya_Chattagram_Jana_Samhati_Samiti" title="Parbatya Chattagram Jana Samhati Samiti">United People's Party of the Chittagong Hill Tracts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Secularism is protected by the constitution of Bangladesh and religious parties are barred from contesting elections; however, the government is accused of courting religious extremist groups. Islam's ambiguous position as the <i>de facto</i> <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> has been criticised by the United Nations.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> Despite relative harmony, religious minorities have faced occasional persecution. The <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> communities have experienced <a href="/wiki/Religious_violence" title="Religious violence">religious violence</a> from Islamic groups â notably the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Jamaat-e-Islami" title="Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami">Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami</a> and its student wing (<a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Islami_Chhatra_Shibir" title="Bangladesh Islami Chhatra Shibir">Shibir</a>). However, Islamic groups are losing popular support - Islamic far-right candidates peaked at 12 percent of the vote in 2001, falling to four percent in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the 2016 Global Slavery Index, an estimated 1,531,300 people are enslaved in modern-day Bangladesh, or 0.95% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> A number of slaves in Bangladesh are forced to work in the fish and shrimp industries.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corruption">Corruption</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Bangladesh" title="Corruption in Bangladesh">Corruption in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Like for many developing countries, institutional corruption is a serious concern for Bangladesh. Bangladesh was ranked 146th among 180 countries on <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s 2018 <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup> According to survey conducted by the Bangladesh chapter of TI, in 2015 bribes made up 3.7 percent of the national budget.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-256">[256]</a></sup> Land administration was the sector with the most bribery in 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-:3_256-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-256">[256]</a></sup> followed by education,<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> police<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> and water supply.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Anti_Corruption_Commission_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti Corruption Commission Bangladesh">Anti Corruption Commission</a> was formed in 2004, and it was active during the <a href="/wiki/2006%E2%80%9308_Bangladeshi_political_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="2006â08 Bangladeshi political crisis">2006â08 Bangladeshi political crisis</a>, indicting many leading politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen for <a href="/wiki/Graft_(politics)" title="Graft (politics)">graft</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Bangladesh" title="Economy of Bangladesh">Economy of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Bangladesh" title="List of companies of Bangladesh">List of companies of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:GulshanDhaka.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/GulshanDhaka.jpg/220px-GulshanDhaka.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="128" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/GulshanDhaka.jpg/330px-GulshanDhaka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/GulshanDhaka.jpg/440px-GulshanDhaka.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1047"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:GulshanDhaka.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a>, the commercial and financial hub of the country, is a major business center in South Asia and the largest economic centre in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_South_Asia" title="Eastern South Asia">Eastern South Asia</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">39th largest economy</a> in terms of market <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rates" class="mw-redirect" title="Exchange rates">exchange rates</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">29th largest</a> in terms of <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>, which ranks second in South Asia after India.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup> Bangladesh is also one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest-growing economies</a> and one of the fastest growing middle-income countries.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank.org_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank.org-264">[264]</a></sup> The country has a market-based <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a>. A <a href="/wiki/Developing_nation" class="mw-redirect" title="Developing nation">developing nation</a>, Bangladesh is one of the <a href="/wiki/Next_Eleven" class="mw-redirect" title="Next Eleven">Next Eleven</a> <a href="/wiki/Emerging_markets" class="mw-redirect" title="Emerging markets">emerging markets</a>. According to the IMF, its per-capita income was <span style="white-space: nowrap"><a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>1,906</span> in 2019, with a <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> of $317 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup> Bangladesh has the second-highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign_exchange_reserves" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by foreign exchange reserves">foreign-exchange reserves</a> in South Asia (after India). The <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_diaspora" title="Bangladeshi diaspora">Bangladeshi diaspora</a> contributed $15.31&nbsp;billion in <a href="/wiki/Remittance_to_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Remittance to Bangladesh">remittances</a> in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> Bangladesh's largest trading partners are the European Union, the United States, Japan, India, Australia, China and ASEAN. Expat workers in the Middle East and Southeast Asia send back a large chunk of remittances. The economy is driven by strong domestic demand.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank.org_264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank.org-264">[264]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During its first five years of independence, Bangladesh adopted socialist policies. The subsequent military regime and BNP and Jatiya Party governments restored free markets and promoted the country's private sector. In 1991, finance minister <a href="/wiki/Saifur_Rahman_(Bangladeshi_politician)" title="Saifur Rahman (Bangladeshi politician)">Saifur Rahman</a> introduced a programme of <a href="/wiki/Economic_liberalisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic liberalisation">economic liberalisation</a>. The Bangladeshi private sector has rapidly expanded, with a number of <a href="/wiki/List_of_conglomerates_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="List of conglomerates in Bangladesh">conglomerates</a> driving the economy. Major industries include textiles, <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" class="mw-redirect" title="Pharmaceuticals">pharmaceuticals</a>, shipbuilding, steel, electronics, energy, construction materials, chemicals, ceramics, food processing, and leather goods. <a href="/wiki/Export-oriented_industrialisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Export-oriented industrialisation">Export-oriented industrialisation</a> has increased with <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">fiscal year</a> 2018â19 exports increasing by 10.1% over the previous year to $40 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-bbbop_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbbop-267">[267]</a></sup> Most export earnings are from the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_textile_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh textile industry">garment-manufacturing industry</a>. </p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;" colspan="2">Share of world GDP (PPP)<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Year </th> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Share </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1980</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.31% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1990</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.33% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2000 </td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.36% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2010 </td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.44% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">2019</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.58% </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bangabandhu_Bridge_(Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bangabandhu_Bridge_%28Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge%29.jpg/220px-Bangabandhu_Bridge_%28Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bangabandhu_Bridge_%28Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge%29.jpg/330px-Bangabandhu_Bridge_%28Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bangabandhu_Bridge_%28Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge%29.jpg/440px-Bangabandhu_Bridge_%28Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3600" data-file-height="2397"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bangabandhu_Bridge_(Jamuna_Multi-purpose_Bridge).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu_Bridge" title="Bangabandhu Bridge">Bangabandhu Bridge</a>, commonly called the Jamuna Multi-purpose Bridge, was the 11th longest bridge in the world and the 6th longest bridge in South Asia when constructed in 1998.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>However, an insufficient power supply is a significant obstacle to Bangladesh's economic development. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, poor governance, corruption and weak public institutions are also major challenges.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank-brief_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-brief-269">[269]</a></sup> In April 2010, <a href="/wiki/Standard_%26_Poor%27s" class="mw-redirect" title="Standard &amp; Poor's">Standard &amp; Poor's</a> gave Bangladesh a BB- long-term <a href="/wiki/Credit_rating" title="Credit rating">credit rating</a>, below India's but above those of Pakistan and Sri Lanka.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladesh is the seventh-largest <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas in Bangladesh">natural gas producer</a> in Asia, ahead of neighbouring Myanmar, and 56 percent of the country's electricity is generated by natural gas. Major gas fields are located in the northeastern (particularly Sylhet) and southern (including Barisal and Chittagong) regions. <a href="/wiki/Petrobangla" title="Petrobangla">Petrobangla</a> is the national energy company. The American multinational corporation <a href="/wiki/Chevron_Corporation" title="Chevron Corporation">Chevron</a> produces 50 percent of Bangladesh's natural gas.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> According to geologists, the Bay of Bengal contains large, untapped gas reserves in Bangladesh's <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> Bangladesh has substantial coal reserves, with several coal mines operating in the northwest. Jute exports remain significant, although the global jute trade has shrunk considerably since its World War II peak. Bangladesh has one of the world's oldest tea industries, and is a major exporter of fish and seafood. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg/220px-Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg/330px-Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg/440px-Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4096" data-file-height="2822"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Muhammad_yunus_at_weforum.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Nobel laureate Yunus at the 2009 meeting of the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Davos" title="Davos">Davos</a>, Switzerland
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg/220px-Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg/330px-Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg/440px-Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="3747"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Remi_Holdings_LEED_certified_factories_in_Bangladesh.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Remi Holdings highest scoring <a href="/wiki/Leadership_in_Energy_and_Environmental_Design" title="Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design">LEED</a> certified Garment factory in Bangladesh and highest in the world.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh's textile and <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_RMG_Sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladeshi RMG Sector">ready-made garment</a> industries are the country's largest manufacturing sector, with 2017 exports of $34.1 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-bbbop_267-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbbop-267">[267]</a></sup> Leather-goods manufacturing, particularly footwear, is the second-largest export sector. The <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Pharmaceutical industry in Bangladesh">pharmaceutical industry</a> meets 97 percent of domestic demand, and exports to many countries.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding_in_Bangladesh" title="Shipbuilding in Bangladesh">Shipbuilding</a> has grown rapidly, with exports to Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Steel_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Steel industry in Bangladesh">Steel</a> is concentrated in the port city of Chittagong, and the <a href="/wiki/Ceramics_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Ceramics industry in Bangladesh">ceramics industry</a> is prominent in international trade. In 2005 Bangladesh was the world's 20th-largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_cement_production" title="List of countries by cement production">cement</a> producer, an industry dependent on <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a> imports from <a href="/wiki/Northeast_India" title="Northeast India">northeast India</a>. <a href="/wiki/Food_processing" title="Food processing">Food processing</a> is a major sector, with local brands such as <a href="/wiki/PRAN" class="mw-redirect" title="PRAN">PRAN</a> increasing their international presence. The <a href="/wiki/Electronics_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Electronics industry in Bangladesh">electronics industry</a> is growing rapidly with contributions from companies like the <a href="/wiki/Walton_Group" title="Walton Group">Walton Group</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> Bangladesh's defense industry includes the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Ordnance_Factories" title="Bangladesh Ordnance Factories">Bangladesh Ordnance Factories</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Khulna_Shipyard" title="Khulna Shipyard">Khulna Shipyard</a>. </p>
      <p>The service sector accounts for 51 percent of the country's GDP. Bangladesh ranks with Pakistan as South Asia's second-largest banking sector.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Stock_Exchange" title="Dhaka Stock Exchange">Dhaka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Stock_Exchange" title="Chittagong Stock Exchange">Chittagong Stock Exchanges</a> are the country's twin financial markets. Bangladesh's <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Bangladesh" title="Telecommunications in Bangladesh">telecommunications industry</a> is one of the world's fastest-growing, with 114 million cellphone subscribers in December 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Grameenphone" title="Grameenphone">Grameenphone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banglalink" title="Banglalink">Banglalink</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robi_(company)" title="Robi (company)">Robi</a> and <a href="/wiki/BTTB" class="mw-redirect" title="BTTB">BTTB</a> are major companies. <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Bangladesh" title="Tourism in Bangladesh">Tourism</a> is developing, with the beach resort of <a href="/wiki/Cox%27s_Bazar" title="Cox's Bazar">Cox's Bazar</a> at the center of the industry. The Sylhet region, home to Bangladesh's tea gardens, also hosts a large number of visitors. The country has <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Bangladesh" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Bangladesh">three UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> (<a href="/wiki/Historic_Mosque_City_of_Bagerhat" class="mw-redirect" title="Historic Mosque City of Bagerhat">the Mosque City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ruins_of_the_Buddhist_Vihara_at_Paharpur" class="mw-redirect" title="Ruins of the Buddhist Vihara at Paharpur">the Buddhist Vihara</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans" title="Sundarbans">Sundarbans</a>) and five <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site#Nominating_process" title="World Heritage Site">tentative-list</a> sites.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following the pioneering work of <a href="/wiki/Akhter_Hameed_Khan" class="mw-redirect" title="Akhter Hameed Khan">Akhter Hameed Khan</a> on rural development at <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Academy_for_Rural_Development" title="Bangladesh Academy for Rural Development">Bangladesh Academy for Rural Development</a>, several <a href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-governmental organisation">NGOs</a> in Bangladesh including <a href="/wiki/BRAC_(NGO)" class="mw-redirect" title="BRAC (NGO)">BRAC</a> (the world's largest NGO),<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Grameen_Bank" title="Grameen Bank">Grameen Bank</a>, focused on rural development and poverty alleviation in the country. <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Yunus" title="Muhammad Yunus">Muhammad Yunus</a> successfully pioneered <a href="/wiki/Microfinance" title="Microfinance">microfinance</a> as a sustainable tool for poverty alleviation and others followed suit. As of 2015, the country had over 35&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Microcredit" title="Microcredit">microcredit</a> borrowers.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup> In recognition of their tangible contribution to poverty alleviation, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Yunus" title="Muhammad Yunus">Muhammad Yunus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Grameen_Bank" title="Grameen Bank">Grameen Bank</a> were jointly awarded the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3> 
      <div class="excerpt-block">
       <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r952607947">.mw-parser-output .excerpt .selflink{font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .excerpt-indicator{border-left:3px solid #c8ccd1;margin:1em 0;padding-left:1em}</style>
       <div class="dablink excerpt-hat">
        <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink selfref">
         This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Bangladesh" title="Agriculture in Bangladesh">Agriculture in Bangladesh</a><i><span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Agriculture_in_Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></i>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="excerpt"> 
        <p><a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">Agriculture</a> is the largest <a href="/wiki/Employment" title="Employment">employment</a> sector in Bangladesh, making up 14.2 percent of Bangladesh's GDP in 2017 and employing about 42.7 percent of the workforce.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_factbook_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_factbook-283">[283]</a></sup> The performance of this sector has an overwhelming impact on major macroeconomic objectives like employment generation, poverty alleviation, <a href="/wiki/Human_resources" title="Human resources">human resources</a> development, <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">food security</a>, and other economic and social forces. A plurality of Bangladeshis earn their living from agriculture. Due to a number of factors, Bangladesh's labour-intensive agriculture has achieved steady increases in food grain production despite the often unfavorable weather conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn3_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn3-284">[284]</a></sup> These include better flood control and irrigation, a generally more efficient use of fertilisers, and the establishment of better distribution and rural credit networks.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn3_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn3-284">[284]</a></sup> </p> Although rice and jute are the primary crops, maize and vegetables are assuming greater importance.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2-285">[285]</a></sup> Due to the expansion of irrigation networks, some wheat producers have switched to cultivation of maize which is used mostly as poultry feed.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2-285">[285]</a></sup> Tea is grown in the northeast.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2_285-2" class="reference"><a
