href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2-285">[285]</a></sup> Because of Bangladesh's fertile soil and normally ample water supply, rice can be grown and harvested three times a year in many areas.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2_285-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_bn2-285">[285]</a></sup> The country is among the top producers of <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> (fourth), <a href="/wiki/Potatoes" class="mw-redirect" title="Potatoes">potatoes</a> (seventh), <a href="/wiki/Tropical_fruits" class="mw-redirect" title="Tropical fruits">tropical fruits</a> (sixth), jute (second), and farmed fish (fifth).<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_FAOSTAT_Production_statistics_2008_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture_in_Bangladesh_FAOSTAT_Production_statistics_2008-286">[286]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup> With 35.8&nbsp;million metric tons produced in 2000, rice is Bangladesh's principal crop. In comparison to rice, wheat output in 1999 was 1.9&nbsp;million tonnes (1,900,000 long tons; 2,100,000 short tons).
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Bangladesh" title="Transport in Bangladesh">Transport in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_(10497235545).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_%2810497235545%29.jpg/220px-Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_%2810497235545%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_%2810497235545%29.jpg/330px-Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_%2810497235545%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_%2810497235545%29.jpg/440px-Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_%2810497235545%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5126" data-file-height="3417"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Boeing_777-3E9ER_S2-AFO_Bangladesh_Biman_Airlines_(10497235545).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Boeing_777" title="Boeing 777">Boeing 777</a> of the national <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> <a href="/wiki/Biman_Bangladesh_Airlines" title="Biman Bangladesh Airlines">Biman Bangladesh Airlines</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Transport is a major sector of the economy. Aviation has grown rapidly, and is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> <a href="/wiki/Biman_Bangladesh_Airlines" title="Biman Bangladesh Airlines">Biman Bangladesh Airlines</a> and other <a href="/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_Bangladesh" title="List of airlines of Bangladesh">privately owned airlines</a>. Bangladesh has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Bangladesh" title="List of airports in Bangladesh">number of airports</a> including three international and several domestic <a href="/wiki/STOL" title="STOL">STOL</a> (short takeoff and landing) airports. The busiest, <a href="/wiki/Shahjalal_International_Airport" title="Shahjalal International Airport">Shahjalal International Airport</a> connects Dhaka with major destinations. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh has a 2,706-kilometre (1,681-mile) long rail network operated by the state-owned <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Railway" title="Bangladesh Railway">Bangladesh Railway</a>. The total length of the country's <a href="/wiki/List_of_roads_in_Bangladesh" title="List of roads in Bangladesh">road and highway network</a> is nearly 21,000 kilometers (13,000 miles). </p>
      <p>With 8,046 kilometres (5,000 miles) of navigable waters, Bangladesh has one of the largest inland <a href="/wiki/Waterway" title="Waterway">waterway</a> networks in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup> The southeastern port of Chittagong is its busiest seaport, handling over $60 billion in annual trade (more than 80 percent of the country's export-import commerce).<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup> The second-busiest seaport is <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Mongla" title="Port of Mongla">Mongla</a>. Bangladesh has three <a href="/wiki/Seaport" class="mw-redirect" title="Seaport">seaports</a> and 22 <a href="/wiki/River_port" class="mw-redirect" title="River port">river ports</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_and_infrastructure">Energy and infrastructure</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy in Bangladesh">Energy in Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_and_petroleum_in_Bangladesh" title="Natural gas and petroleum in Bangladesh">Natural gas and petroleum in Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Bangladesh" title="Telecommunications in Bangladesh">Telecommunications in Bangladesh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Bangladesh" title="Water supply and sanitation in Bangladesh">Water supply and sanitation in Bangladesh</a>
      </div>
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">December 2020</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png" class="image"><img alt="Map of Bangladesh, illustrating coal and gas deposits" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png/220px-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="283" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png/330px-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png/440px-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png 2x" data-file-width="454" data-file-height="584"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%93_%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B8_%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A1.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Coal and natural-gas fields in Bangladesh, 2011
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh had an installed electrical capacity of 20,000 megawatts in 2018, reaching 23,548 MW in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup> About 56 percent of the country's commercial energy is generated by natural gas, followed by oil, <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a> and coal. Bangladesh has planned to import hydropower from <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Bhutan" title="Energy in Bhutan">Bhutan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Nepal" title="Energy in Nepal">Nepal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup> A nuclear power plant is under construction with Russian support in the <a href="/wiki/Ruppur_Nuclear_Power_Plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Ruppur Nuclear Power Plant">Ruppur Nuclear Power Plant</a> project which will add 2160 MW when fully operational.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> The country ranks fifth worldwide in the number of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> <a href="/wiki/Green_job" title="Green job">green jobs</a>, and solar panels are increasingly used to power urban and off-grid rural areas.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>An estimated 98 percent of the country's population had access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_water_source" title="Improved water source">improved water sources</a> by 2004<sup id="cite_ref-JMP_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JMP-296">[296]</a></sup> (a high percentage for a low-income country), achieved largely through the construction of <a href="/wiki/Hand_pump" title="Hand pump">hand pumps</a> with support from external donors. However, in 1993 it was discovered that much of Bangladesh's groundwater (the source of drinking water for 97 percent of the rural population and a significant share of the urban population) is naturally contaminated with arsenic. </p>
      <p>Another challenge is low cost recovery due to low tariffs and poor <a href="/wiki/Economic_efficiency" title="Economic efficiency">economic efficiency</a>, especially in urban areas (where water revenue does not cover operating costs). An estimated 56 percent of the population had access to adequate sanitation facilities in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_158-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-158">[158]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Community-led_total_sanitation" title="Community-led total sanitation">Community-led total sanitation</a>, addressing the problem of <a href="/wiki/Open_defecation" title="Open defecation">open defecation</a> in rural areas, is credited with improving public health since its introduction in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Bangladesh" title="Science and technology in Bangladesh">Science and technology in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Information_technology_in_Bangladesh" title="Information technology in Bangladesh">Information technology in Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology_and_genetic_engineering_in_Bangladesh" title="Biotechnology and genetic engineering in Bangladesh">Biotechnology and genetic engineering in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_(42025498972).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_%2842025498972%29.jpg/220px-Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_%2842025498972%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_%2842025498972%29.jpg/330px-Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_%2842025498972%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_%2842025498972%29.jpg/440px-Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_%2842025498972%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bangabandhu_Satellite-1_Mission_(42025498972).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>In 2018, the first payload of <a href="/wiki/SpaceX" title="SpaceX">SpaceX</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Falcon_9_Block_5" title="Falcon 9 Block 5">Falcon 9 Block 5</a> rocket was the <a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu-1" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangabandhu-1">Bangabandhu-1</a> satellite built by <a href="/wiki/Thales_Alenia_Space" title="Thales Alenia Space">Thales Alenia Space</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Council_of_Scientific_and_Industrial_Research" title="Bangladesh Council of Scientific and Industrial Research">Bangladesh Council of Scientific and Industrial Research</a>, founded in 1973, traces its roots to the East Pakistan Regional Laboratories established in Dhaka (1955), <a href="/wiki/Rajshahi" title="Rajshahi">Rajshahi</a> (1965) and Chittagong (1967). Bangladesh's <a href="/wiki/Space_agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Space agency">space agency</a>, <a href="/wiki/SPARRSO" class="mw-redirect" title="SPARRSO">SPARRSO</a>, was founded in 1983 with assistance from the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> The country's first communications satellite, <a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu-1" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangabandhu-1">Bangabandhu-1</a>, was launched from the United States in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Atomic_Energy_Commission" title="Bangladesh Atomic Energy Commission">Bangladesh Atomic Energy Commission</a> operates a <a href="/wiki/TRIGA" title="TRIGA">TRIGA</a> research reactor at its atomic-energy facility in <a href="/wiki/Savar" title="Savar">Savar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> In 2015, Bangladesh was ranked the 26th global IT outsourcing destination.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Bangladesh" title="Tourism in Bangladesh">Tourism in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg/220px-One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg/330px-One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg/440px-One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="3024"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:One_of_the_famous_beach_in_the_world_%22Cox%27s_Bazaar.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The beach in <a href="/wiki/Cox%27s_Bazar" title="Cox's Bazar">Cox's Bazar</a>, with an unbroken length of 120&nbsp;km (75&nbsp;mi), is often credited as the longest natural sea beach in the world.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG/220px-WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG/330px-WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG/440px-WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1975"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:WALK_IN_THE_CLOUDS.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Mountain trekking is a popular activity in the <a href="/wiki/Bandarban_District" title="Bandarban District">Bandarban District</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh's tourist attractions include historical sites and monuments, resorts, beaches, picnic spots, forests and wildlife of various species. Activities for tourists include <a href="/wiki/Angling" title="Angling">angling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_skiing" title="Water skiing">water skiing</a>, river cruising, hiking, <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yachting" title="Yachting">yachting</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sea_bathing" title="Sea bathing">sea bathing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-lp_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lp-302">[302]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lp_web_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lp_web-303">[303]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Travel_and_Tourism_Council" title="World Travel and Tourism Council">World Travel and Tourism Council</a> (WTTC) reported in 2019 that the travel and tourism industry in Bangladesh directly generated 1,180,500 jobs in 2018 or 1.9 percent of the country's total employment.<sup id="cite_ref-2019_report_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2019_report-304">[304]</a></sup> According to the same report, Bangladesh experiences around 125,000 international tourist arrivals per year.<sup id="cite_ref-2019_report_304-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2019_report-304">[304]</a></sup> Domestic spending generated 97.7 percent of direct travel and tourism gross domestic product (GDP) in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-2013_report_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013_report-305">[305]</a></sup> Bangladesh's world ranking in 2012 for travel and tourism's direct contribution to GDP, as a percentage of GDP, was 120 out of 140.<sup id="cite_ref-2013_report_305-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013_report-305">[305]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Bangladesh" title="Demographics of Bangladesh">Demographics of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bengalis" title="Bengalis">Bengalis</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-top-width:0;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;">
       <caption style="border-top:1px #aaa solid;border-left:1px #aaa solid;border-right:1px #aaa solid;background-color:lavender;padding:0.25em;font-weight:bold">
        Population (millions)
       </caption>
       <tbody>
        <tr style="font-size:95%">
         <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;width:3em">Year</th>
         <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px 2px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Population">Pop.</abbr></th>
         <th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Per annum growth rate">Â±% p.a.</abbr></th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1971 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">67.8</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">â&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1980 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">80.6</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.94%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1990 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">105.3</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.71%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2000 </th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">129.6</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.10%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">2010</th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">148.7</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+1.38%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2012</th>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">161.1</td>
         <td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+4.09%</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">Source: OECD/World Bank<sup id="cite_ref-IEApop2011_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IEApop2011-306">[306]</a></sup></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Estimates of the Bangladeshi population vary, but UN data suggests 161,376,708 (162.9 million) in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2019_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2019-10">[10]</a></sup> The 2011 census estimated 142.3 million,<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup> much less than 2007â2010 estimates of Bangladesh's population (150â170&nbsp;million). Bangladesh is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population">eighth-most-populous</a> nation and the most densely-populated large country in the world, ranking 7th in population density even when small countries and city-states are included.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country's population-growth rate was among the highest in the world in the 1960s and 1970s, when its population grew from 65 to 110&nbsp;million. With the promotion of <a href="/wiki/Birth_control" title="Birth control">birth control</a> in the 1980s, Bangladesh's growth rate began to slow. Its <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> is now 2.05,<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup> lower than India's (2.58) and Pakistan's (3.07). The population is relatively young, with 34 percent aged 15 or younger and five percent 65 or older. Life expectancy at birth was estimated at 72.49 years in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_158-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-158">[158]</a></sup> According to the World Bank, as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> 14.8% of the country lives below the <a href="/wiki/International_poverty_line" class="mw-redirect" title="International poverty line">international poverty line</a> on less than $1.90 per day.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Bengali_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali people">Bengalis</a> are 98 percent of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-bn_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bn-312">[312]</a></sup> Of Bengalis, <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslims" title="Bengali Muslims">Muslims</a> are the majority, followed by <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Hindus" title="Bengali Hindus">Hindus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Christians" title="Bengali Christians">Christians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Buddhists" title="Bengali Buddhists">Buddhists</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Adivasi" title="Adivasi">Adivasi</a> population includes the <a href="/wiki/Chakma_people" title="Chakma people">Chakma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marma_people" title="Marma people">Marma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanchangya_people" title="Tanchangya people">Tanchangya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tripuri_people" title="Tripuri people">Tripuri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuki_people" title="Kuki people">Kuki</a>, Khiang, Khumi, <a href="/wiki/Murang_people" title="Murang people">Murang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mru_people_(Mrucha)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mru people (Mrucha)">Mru</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chak_people" title="Chak people">Chak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lushei" class="mw-redirect" title="Lushei">Lushei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bawm_people" title="Bawm people">Bawm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bisnupriya_Manipuri_Society" class="mw-redirect" title="Bisnupriya Manipuri Society">Bishnupriya Manipuri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khasi_people" title="Khasi people">Khasi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Synteng" class="mw-redirect" title="Synteng">Jaintia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Garo_people" title="Garo people">Garo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santal" class="mw-redirect" title="Santal">Santal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Munda_people" title="Munda people">Munda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oraon" class="mw-redirect" title="Oraon">Oraon</a> tribes. The Chittagong Hill Tracts region experienced unrest and an <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts_conflict" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts conflict">insurgency</a> from 1975 to 1997 in an autonomy movement by its indigenous people. Although a peace accord was signed in 1997, the region remains militarised.<sup id="cite_ref-rashiduzzaman_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rashiduzzaman-313">[313]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladesh is home to a significant <a href="/wiki/Ismaili" class="mw-redirect" title="Ismaili">Ismaili</a> community.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> It hosts many <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>-speaking immigrants, who migrated there after the partition of India. <a href="/wiki/Stranded_Pakistanis" class="mw-redirect" title="Stranded Pakistanis">Stranded Pakistanis</a> were given citizenship by the Supreme Court in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Rohingya_refugees_in_Bangladesh" title="Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh">Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh</a> number at around 1 million, making Bangladesh one of the countries with the largest refugee populations in the world. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_centres">Urban centres</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Bangladesh" title="List of cities and towns in Bangladesh">List of cities and towns in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Dhaka is Bangladesh's capital and largest city and is overseen by two city corporations who manage between them the northern and southern part of the city. There are 12 <a href="/wiki/List_of_City_Corporations_of_Bangladesh" title="List of City Corporations of Bangladesh">city corporations</a> which hold mayoral elections: Dhaka South, Dhaka North, Chittagong, <a href="/wiki/Comilla" title="Comilla">Comilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khulna" title="Khulna">Khulna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh" title="Mymensingh">Mymensingh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sylhet" title="Sylhet">Sylhet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rajshahi" title="Rajshahi">Rajshahi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barisal" title="Barisal">Barisal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rangpur,_Bangladesh" title="Rangpur, Bangladesh">Rangpur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gazipur,_Dhaka_Division" class="mw-redirect" title="Gazipur, Dhaka Division">Gazipur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Narayanganj" title="Narayanganj">Narayanganj</a>. Mayors are elected for five-year terms. Altogether there are 506 urban centres in Bangladesh among which 43 cities have a population of more than 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">

         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Dhaka_14th_March_(32624769393).jpg" class="image" title="Dhaka"><img alt="Dhaka" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dhaka_14th_March_%2832624769393%29.jpg/120px-Dhaka_14th_March_%2832624769393%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="75" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dhaka_14th_March_%2832624769393%29.jpg/180px-Dhaka_14th_March_%2832624769393%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dhaka_14th_March_%2832624769393%29.jpg/240px-Dhaka_14th_March_%2832624769393%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1124"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Chittagong_city_skyline.jpg" class="image" title="Chittagong"><img alt="Chittagong" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Chittagong_city_skyline.jpg/120px-Chittagong_city_skyline.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Chittagong_city_skyline.jpg/180px-Chittagong_city_skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Chittagong_city_skyline.jpg/240px-Chittagong_city_skyline.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Chittagong" title="Chittagong">Chittagong</a> </td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">1</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Division" title="Dhaka Division">Dhaka</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">8,906,039</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">11</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Savar" title="Savar">Savar</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Division" title="Dhaka Division">Dhaka</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">296,851 </td> 
         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Khulna_City_View.jpg" class="image" title="Khulna"><img alt="Khulna" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Khulna_City_View.jpg/120px-Khulna_City_View.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="57" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Khulna_City_View.jpg/180px-Khulna_City_View.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Khulna_City_View.jpg/240px-Khulna_City_View.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5700" data-file-height="2700"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Khulna" title="Khulna">Khulna</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Sylhet,_by_Murshed.jpg" class="image" title="Sylhet"><img alt="Sylhet" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Sylhet%2C_by_Murshed.jpg/120px-Sylhet%2C_by_Murshed.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="69" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Sylhet%2C_by_Murshed.jpg/180px-Sylhet%2C_by_Murshed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Sylhet%2C_by_Murshed.jpg/240px-Sylhet%2C_by_Murshed.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3191" data-file-height="1845"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Sylhet" title="Sylhet">Sylhet</a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Bangladesh" title="Languages of Bangladesh">Languages of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG/220px-Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG/330px-Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG/440px-Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rajshahi_College_Library_Inside_02.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Charyapada" class="mw-redirect" title="Charyapada">Charyapada</a></i> scrolls are the oldest surviving text of the Bengali language. The photograph was taken at the <a href="/wiki/Rajshahi_College" title="Rajshahi College">Rajshahi College</a> Library
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The predominant language of Bangladesh is <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a> (also known as Bangla). Bengali is one of the easternmost branches of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-European language">Indo-European language</a> family. It is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Eastern Indo-Aryan languages">Eastern Indo-Aryan languages</a> in South Asia, which developed between the 10th and 13th centuries. Bengali is written using the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_alphabet" title="Bengali alphabet">Bengali script</a>. In ancient Bengal, <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> was the language of written communication, especially by priests. During the Islamic period, Sanskrit was replaced by Bengali as the <a href="/wiki/Vernacular_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Vernacular language">vernacular language</a>. The Sultans of Bengal promoted the production of Bengali literature instead of Sanskrit. Bengali also received <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> loanwords during the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Sultanate of Bengal">Sultanate of Bengal</a>. Under <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">British rule</a>, Bengali was significantly modernised by Europeans. Modern Standard Bengali emerged as the <i><a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a></i> of the region. A heavily Sanskritized version of Bengali was employed by Hindu scholars during the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance" title="Bengali Renaissance">Bengali Renaissance</a>. Muslim writers such as <a href="/wiki/Kazi_Nazrul_Islam" title="Kazi Nazrul Islam">Kazi Nazrul Islam</a> gave attention to the Persian and Arabic vocabulary of the language. </p>
      <p>Today, the Bengali language standard is prescribed by the <a href="/wiki/Bangla_Academy" title="Bangla Academy">Bangla Academy</a> in Bangladesh. More than 98 percent of people in Bangladesh speak Bengali as their native language.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-constitution-I-5_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitution-I-5-318">[318]</a></sup> Bengali is described as a <a href="/wiki/Dialect_continuum" title="Dialect continuum">dialect continuum</a> where there are various <a href="/wiki/Bengali_dialects" title="Bengali dialects">dialects</a> spoken throughout the country. Currently there is a <a href="/wiki/Diglossia" title="Diglossia">diglossia</a> in which much of the population are able to understand or speak Standard Colloquial Bengali and in their regional dialect, such as <a href="/wiki/Chittagonian_language" title="Chittagonian language">Chittagonian</a> or <a href="/wiki/Sylheti_language" title="Sylheti language">Sylheti</a>, which some linguists consider as separate languages.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bangla_Bhasha_Prachalan_Ain,_1987" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangla Bhasha Prachalan Ain, 1987">Bengali Language Implementation Act, 1987</a> made it mandatory to use Bengali in all government affairs in Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup> Although laws were historically written in English, they were not translated into Bengali until the act. All subsequent acts, ordinances and laws have been promulgated in Bengali since 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup> English is often used in the verdicts delivered by the Supreme Court of Bangladesh, and is also used in higher education. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Chakma_language" title="Chakma language">Chakma language</a> is another native Eastern Indo-Aryan language of Bangladesh. It is written using the <a href="/wiki/Chakma_script" title="Chakma script">Chakma script</a>. The unique aspect of the language is that it is used by the Chakma people, who are a population with similarities to the people of East Asia, rather than the Indian subcontinent. The Chakma language is endangered due to its decreasing use in schools and institutions. </p>
      <p>Other tribal languages include <a href="/wiki/Garo_language" title="Garo language">Garo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meitei_language" title="Meitei language">Meitei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kokborok" title="Kokborok">Kokborok</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rakhine_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Rakhine language">Rakhine</a>. Among the <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic languages</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Santali_language" title="Santali language">Santali language</a> is spoken by the Santali tribe. Many of these languages are written in the Bengali script; while there is also some usage of the Latin script. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> has a significant heritage in Bangladesh, in particular <a href="/wiki/Old_Dhaka" title="Old Dhaka">Old Dhaka</a>. The language was introduced to Bengal in the 17th-century. Traders and migrants from North India often spoke the language in Bengal, as did sections of the Bengali upper class. Urdu poets lived in many parts of Bangladesh. The use of Urdu became controversial during the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Language_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Language Movement">Bengali Language Movement</a>, when the people of East Bengal resisted attempts to impose Urdu as the main official language. In modern Bangladesh, the Urdu-speaking community is restricted to the country's <a href="/wiki/Biharis_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Biharis in Bangladesh">Bihari</a> community (formerly Stranded Pakistanis); and some sections of the <a href="/wiki/Dhakaiyas" title="Dhakaiyas">Old Dhakaiya</a> population.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Bangladesh" title="Religion in Bangladesh">Religion in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:250px; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Religions in Bangladesh (2011) <sup id="cite_ref-census2011_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census2011-323">[323]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">Religion</td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">Percent</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Bangladesh" title="Islam in Bangladesh">Islam</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:MediumSeaGreen; width:90.4%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">90.4%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bangladesh" title="Hinduism in Bangladesh">Hinduism</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:DarkOrange; width:8.5%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">8.5%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bangladesh" title="Buddhism in Bangladesh">Buddhism</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:Gold; width:0.6%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.6%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Bangladesh" title="Christianity in Bangladesh">Christianity</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:0.4%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.4%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Others</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:black; width:0.1%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.1%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The constitution grants <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a> and officially makes Bangladesh a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a>, while establishing Islam as the "religion of the Republic".<sup id="cite_ref-Secularism_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Secularism-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-constituteproject_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constituteproject-324">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-aljazeera:1_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aljazeera:1-325">[325]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Bangladesh" title="Islam in Bangladesh">Islam</a> is followed by 90 percent of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-kbrs_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kbrs-326">[326]</a></sup> Most Bangladeshis are <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslims" title="Bengali Muslims">Bengali Muslims</a>, who form the largest Muslim ethnoreligious group in South Asia and the second largest in the world after the Arabs. There is also a minority of non-Bengali Muslims. The vast majority of Bangladeshi Muslims are <a href="/wiki/Sunni" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunni">Sunni</a>, followed by minorities of <a href="/wiki/Shia" class="mw-redirect" title="Shia">Shia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiya" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmadiya">Ahmadiya</a>. About four percent are <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslims" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-denominational Muslims">non-denominational Muslims</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup> Bangladesh has the fourth-largest Muslim population in the world, and is the third-largest Muslim-majority country (after Indonesia and Pakistan).<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufism</a> has an extensive heritage in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup> Liberal Bengali Islam sometimes clashes with orthodox movements. The largest gathering of Muslims in Bangladesh is the apolitical <a href="/wiki/Bishwa_Ijtema" title="Bishwa Ijtema">Bishwa Ijtema</a>, held annually by the orthodox <a href="/wiki/Tablighi_Jamaat" title="Tablighi Jamaat">Tablighi Jamaat</a>. The Ijtema is the second-largest Muslim congregation in the world, after the <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Hajj</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Foundation_Bangladesh" title="Islamic Foundation Bangladesh">Islamic Foundation</a> is an autonomous government agency responsible for some religious matters under state guidance, including monitoring of sighting of the moon in accordance with the lunar <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Islamic calendar</a> in order to set festival dates; as well as the charitable tradition of <i><a href="/wiki/Zakat" title="Zakat">zakat</a></i>. Public holidays include the Islamic observances of Eid-ul-Fitr, Eid-al-Adha, the Prophet's Birthday, Ashura and Shab-e-Barat. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Religions_of_bangladesh.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Religions_of_bangladesh.png/220px-Religions_of_bangladesh.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Religions_of_bangladesh.png/330px-Religions_of_bangladesh.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Religions_of_bangladesh.png/440px-Religions_of_bangladesh.png 2x" data-file-width="774" data-file-height="599"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Religions_of_bangladesh.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Montage of religions of Bangladesh. Clockwise from top left: Muslims praying in <a href="/wiki/Baitul_Mukarram" class="mw-redirect" title="Baitul Mukarram">Baitul Mukarram</a>; a Hindu monk in <a href="/wiki/Dhakeshwari_Temple" title="Dhakeshwari Temple">Dhakeshwari Temple</a>; a Buddhist monk in <a href="/wiki/Buddha_Dhatu_Jadi" title="Buddha Dhatu Jadi">Buddha Dhatu Jadi</a>; a Bangladeshi Christian cardinal with other cardinals at the Vatican
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bangladesh" title="Hinduism in Bangladesh">Hinduism</a> is followed by 8.5 percent of the population;<sup id="cite_ref-kbrs_326-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kbrs-326">[326]</a></sup> most are <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Hindu">Bengali Hindus</a>, and some are members of <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic groups in Bangladesh">ethnic minority groups</a>. Bangladeshi Hindus are the country's second-largest religious group and the third-largest Hindu community in the world, after those in India and Nepal. Hindus in Bangladesh are evenly distributed, with concentrations in <a href="/wiki/Gopalganj_District,_Bangladesh" title="Gopalganj District, Bangladesh">Gopalganj</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dinajpur_District_(Bangladesh)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dinajpur District (Bangladesh)">Dinajpur</a>, Sylhet, <a href="/wiki/Sunamganj" title="Sunamganj">Sunamganj</a>, Mymensingh, Khulna, Jessore, Chittagong and parts of the Chittagong Hill Tracts. The festivals of Durga's Return and Krishna's Birthday are public holidays. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bangladesh" title="Buddhism in Bangladesh">Buddhism</a> is the third-largest religion, at 0.6 percent. Bangladeshi Buddhists are concentrated among ethnic groups in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (particularly the Chakma, Marma and Tanchangya peoples), while coastal Chittagong is home to a large number of <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Buddhist">Bengali Buddhists</a>. Although the Mahayana school of Buddhism was historically prevalent in the region, Bangladeshi Buddhists today adhere to the Theravada school. Buddha's Birthday is a public holiday. The chief Buddhist priests are based at a monastery in Chittagong. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar,_Debidwar,_Comilla.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg/220px-Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg/330px-Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg/440px-Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar,_Debidwar,_Comilla.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Eid_prayers" title="Eid prayers">Eid prayers</a> for Muslims at Barashalghar, <a href="/wiki/Debidwar_Upazila" title="Debidwar Upazila">Debidwar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Comilla" title="Comilla">Comilla</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Christianity is the fourth-largest religion, at 0.4 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup> Roman Catholicism is the largest denomination among Bangladeshi Christians. <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Christians" title="Bengali Christians">Bengali Christians</a> are spread across the country; while there are many Christians among minority ethnic groups in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (southeastern Bangladesh) and within the Garo tribe of Mymensingh (north-central Bangladesh). The country also has Protestant, Baptist, and Oriental Orthodox churches. Christmas is a public holiday. </p>
      <p>The Constitution of Bangladesh declares Islam the state religion, but bans religion-based politics. It proclaims equal recognition of Hindus, Buddhists, Christians and people of all faiths.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup> In 1972, Bangladesh was South Asia's first constitutionally-secular country.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> Article 12 of the constitution continues to call for secularism, the elimination of interfaith tensions and prohibits the abuse of religion for political purposes and any discrimination against, or persecution of, persons practising a particular religion.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> Article 41 of the constitution subjects religious freedom to public order, law and morality; it gives every citizen the right to profess, practice or propagate any religion; every religious community or denomination the right to establish, maintain and manage its religious institutions; and states that no person attending any educational institution shall be required to receive religious instruction, or to take part in or to attend any religious ceremony or worship, if that instruction, ceremony or worship relates to a religion other than his own.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Bangladesh" title="Education in Bangladesh">Education in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Bangladesh has a <a href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> of 74.7% percent as of 2019: 77.4% for males and 71.9% for females.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup> The country's educational system is three-tiered and heavily subsidised, with the government operating many schools at the primary, secondary and higher secondary levels and subsidising many private schools. In the tertiary education sector, the Bangladeshi government funds over 45 state universities<sup id="cite_ref-ugc-universities.gov.bd_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ugc-universities.gov.bd-337">[337]</a></sup> through the <a href="/wiki/University_Grants_Commission_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="University Grants Commission of Bangladesh">University Grants Commission</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png/220px-Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="223" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png/330px-Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png/440px-Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png 2x" data-file-width="464" data-file-height="471"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Literacy rates in Bangladesh districts
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The education system is divided into five levels: primary (first to fifth grade), junior secondary (sixth to eighth grade), secondary (ninth and tenth grade), higher secondary (11th and 12th grade), and tertiary.<sup id="cite_ref-CompEd_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CompEd-338">[338]</a></sup> Five years of secondary education (including junior secondary) ends with a <a href="/wiki/Secondary_School_Certificate" title="Secondary School Certificate">Secondary School Certificate</a> (SSC) examination. Since 2009, the Primary Education Closing (PEC) examination has also been introduced. Students who pass the PEC examination proceed to secondary or matriculation training, culminating in the SSC examination.<sup id="cite_ref-CompEd_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CompEd-338">[338]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Students who pass the PEC examination proceed to three years of junior secondary education, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Junior_School_Certificate" title="Junior School Certificate">Junior School Certificate</a> (JSC) examination. Students who pass this examination proceed to two years of secondary education, culminating in the SSC examination. Students who pass this examination proceed to two years of higher secondary education, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Higher_Secondary_School_Certificate" title="Higher Secondary School Certificate">Higher Secondary School Certificate</a> (HSC) examination.<sup id="cite_ref-CompEd_338-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CompEd-338">[338]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Education is primarily in Bengali, but English is commonly taught and used. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh conforms with <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO's</a> <a href="/wiki/Education_For_All" title="Education For All">Education For All</a> (EFA) objectives, the UN <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Development_Goals" title="Millennium Development Goals">Millennium Development Goals</a> (MDG) and other international declarations. Article 17 of the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh Constitution">Bangladesh Constitution</a> provides that all children between the ages of six and ten years receive a basic education free of charge. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Department_of_chemistry,_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Department_of_chemistry%2C_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg/220px-Department_of_chemistry%2C_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="177" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Department_of_chemistry%2C_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg/330px-Department_of_chemistry%2C_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Department_of_chemistry%2C_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg/440px-Department_of_chemistry%2C_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3005" data-file-height="2423"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Department_of_chemistry,_University_of_Dhaka_.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/University_of_Dhaka" title="University of Dhaka">University of Dhaka</a>, is the oldest university in Bangladesh
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Universities_in_Bangladesh" title="Universities in Bangladesh">Universities in Bangladesh</a> are of three general types: public (government-owned and subsidised), private (privately owned universities) and international (operated and funded by international organisations). They are accredited by and affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/University_Grants_Commission_(Bangladesh)" title="University Grants Commission (Bangladesh)">University Grants Commission</a> (UGC), created by Presidential Order 10 in 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup> The country has 47 public,<sup id="cite_ref-ugc-universities.gov.bd_337-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ugc-universities.gov.bd-337">[337]</a></sup> 105 private<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup> and two international <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Bangladesh" title="List of universities in Bangladesh">universities</a>; <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_National_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh National University">Bangladesh National University</a> has the largest enrollment, and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Dhaka" title="University of Dhaka">University of Dhaka</a> (established in 1921) is the oldest. <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chittagong" title="University of Chittagong">University of Chittagong</a> (established in 1966) is the largest University (Campus: Rural, 2,100 acres (8.5 km2)). <a href="/wiki/Islamic_University_of_Technology" title="Islamic University of Technology">Islamic University of Technology</a>, commonly known as IUT, is a subsidiary of the Organisation of the Islamic Cooperation (OIC, representing 57 countries in Asia, Africa, Europe and South America). <a href="/wiki/Asian_University_for_Women" title="Asian University for Women">Asian University for Women</a> in Chittagong is the preeminent South Asian liberal-arts university for women, representing 14 Asian countries; its faculty hails from notable academic institutions in North America, Europe, Asia, Australia and the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As in Bangladesh, the agriculture sector is the largest contributor (more than 20%) to GDP<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[342]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_science" title="Agricultural science">agricultural sciences</a> are well developed.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup> It has 6 public research based agricultural university, and they are: <a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu_Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_Agricultural_University" title="Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Agricultural University">Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Agricultural University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Agricultural_University" title="Bangladesh Agricultural University">Bangladesh Agricultural University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sher-e-Bangla_Agricultural_University" title="Sher-e-Bangla Agricultural University">Sher-e-Bangla Agricultural University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sylhet_Agricultural_University" title="Sylhet Agricultural University">Sylhet Agricultural University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khulna_Agricultural_University" title="Khulna Agricultural University">Khulna Agricultural University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Veterinary_and_Animal_Sciences_University" title="Chittagong Veterinary and Animal Sciences University">Chittagong Veterinary and Animal Sciences University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/BUET" class="mw-redirect" title="BUET">BUET</a>, <a href="/wiki/CUET" class="mw-redirect" title="CUET">CUET</a>, <a href="/wiki/KUET" class="mw-redirect" title="KUET">KUET</a> and <a href="/wiki/RUET" class="mw-redirect" title="RUET">RUET</a> are Bangladesh's four public engineering universities. <a href="/wiki/BUTEX" class="mw-redirect" title="BUTEX">BUTEX</a> and <a href="/wiki/DUET" class="mw-redirect" title="DUET">DUET</a> are two specialised engineering universities; BUTEX specialises in <a href="/wiki/Textile_engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Textile engineering">textile engineering</a>, and DUET offers higher education to diploma engineers. The <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Textile_Engineering_and_Research" title="National Institute of Textile Engineering and Research">NITER</a> is a specialised public-private partnership institute that provides higher education in textile engineering. Science and technology universities include <a href="/wiki/Hajee_Mohammad_Danesh_Science_%26_Technology_University" title="Hajee Mohammad Danesh Science &amp; Technology University">Hajee Mohammad Danesh Science &amp; Technology University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mawlana_Bhashani_Science_and_Technology_University" title="Mawlana Bhashani Science and Technology University">Mawlana Bhashani Science and Technology University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu_Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_Science_and_Technology_University" title="Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Science and Technology University">Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Science and Technology University</a>, <a href="/wiki/SUST" class="mw-redirect" title="SUST">SUST</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jessore_University_of_Science_%26_Technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Jessore University of Science &amp; Technology">JUST</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pabna_University_of_Science_%26_Technology" title="Pabna University of Science &amp; Technology">PUST</a>, <a href="/wiki/Noakhali_Science_and_Technology_University" title="Noakhali Science and Technology University">NSTU</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patuakhali_Science_and_Technology_University" title="Patuakhali Science and Technology University">PSTU</a>. The country's first higher education institution on <a href="/wiki/Aerospace_engineering" title="Aerospace engineering">aerospace engineering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu_Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_Aviation_and_Aerospace_University" title="Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Aviation and Aerospace University">Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman Aviation and Aerospace University</a>, has been established in 2019 and is expected to launch its on-campus academic activities from the start of 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Medical education is provided by 29 government and private <a href="/wiki/List_of_medical_colleges_in_Bangladesh" title="List of medical colleges in Bangladesh">medical colleges</a>. All medical colleges are affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_and_Family_Welfare_(Bangladesh)" title="Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Bangladesh)">Ministry of Health and Family Welfare</a>. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh's 2015 literacy rate rose to 71 percent due to education modernisation and improved funding, with 16,087 schools and 2,363 colleges receiving Monthly Pay Order (MPO) facilities. According to then education minister <a href="/wiki/Nurul_Islam_Nahid" title="Nurul Islam Nahid">Nurul Islam Nahid</a>, 27,558 madrasas and technical and vocational institutions were enlisted for the facility. 6,036 educational institutions were outside MPO coverage, and the government enlisted 1,624 private schools for MPO in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Bangladesh" title="Health in Bangladesh">Health in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BSMMU_A_block.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/BSMMU_A_block.jpg/220px-BSMMU_A_block.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/BSMMU_A_block.jpg/330px-BSMMU_A_block.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/BSMMU_A_block.jpg/440px-BSMMU_A_block.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4160" data-file-height="3120"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BSMMU_A_block.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu_Sheikh_Mujib_Medical_University" title="Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Medical University">Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Medical University</a>, the first public medical university in Bangladesh established in 1998
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Healthcare facilities in Bangladesh are considered less than adequate, although they have improved as poverty levels have decreased significantly. Findings from a recent study in <a href="/wiki/Chakaria_Upazila" title="Chakaria Upazila">Chakaria</a> (a rural <a href="/wiki/Upazila" title="Upazila">upazila</a> under <a href="/wiki/Cox%27s_Bazar_District" title="Cox's Bazar District">Cox's Bazar District</a>) revealed that the "village doctors", practicing allopathic medicine without formal training, were reported to have provided 65% of the healthcare sought for illness episodes occurring within 14 days prior to the survey. Formally-trained providers made up only four percent of the total health workforce. The Future Health Systems survey indicated significant deficiencies in the treatment practices of village doctors, with widespread harmful and inappropriate drug prescribing.<sup id="cite_ref-FHS_Research_Brief_2_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FHS_Research_Brief_2-350">[350]</a></sup> Receiving health care from informal providers is encouraged.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[351]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A 2007 study of 1,000 households in rural Bangladesh found that direct payments to formal and informal healthcare providers and indirect costs (loss of earnings because of illness) associated with illness were deterrents to accessing healthcare from qualified providers.<sup id="cite_ref-FHS_Research_Brief_2_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FHS_Research_Brief_2-350">[350]</a></sup> A community survey of 6,183 individuals in rural Bangladesh found a gender difference in treatment-seeking behaviour, with women less likely to seek treatment than to men.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> The use of skilled birth attendant (SBA) services, however, rose from 2005 to 2007 among women from all socioeconomic <a href="/wiki/Quantile" title="Quantile">quintiles</a> except the highest.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup> A health watch, a pilot community-empowerment tool, was successfully developed and implemented in south-eastern Bangladesh to improve the uptake and monitoring of public-health services.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladesh's poor health conditions are attributed to the lack of healthcare provision by the government. According to a 2010 World Bank report, 2009 healthcare spending was 3.35 percent of the country's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-apps.who.int_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-apps.who.int-355">[355]</a></sup> Government spending on healthcare that year was 7.9 percent of the total budget; out-of-pocket expenditures totalled 96.5 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-apps.who.int_355-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-apps.who.int-355">[355]</a></sup> According to the government sources, the number of hospital beds is 8 per 10,000 population (as of 2015).<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">Malnutrition</a> has been a persistent problem in Bangladesh, with the World Bank ranking the country first in the number of malnourished children worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup> More than 54% of preschool-age children are stunted, 56% are underweight and more than 17% are wasted.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup> More than 45 percent of rural families and 76 percent of urban families were below the acceptable caloric-intake level.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Bangladesh" title="Culture of Bangladesh">Culture of Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Bengal" title="Culture of Bengal">Culture of Bengal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance" title="Bengali Renaissance">Bengali Renaissance</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_art" title="Bangladeshi art">Bangladeshi art</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ZainulAbedin1971.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/ZainulAbedin1971.jpg/260px-ZainulAbedin1971.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="190" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/ZainulAbedin1971.jpg/390px-ZainulAbedin1971.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/ZainulAbedin1971.jpg/520px-ZainulAbedin1971.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="467"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ZainulAbedin1971.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Liberation War by Zainul Abedin
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The recorded history of art in Bangladesh can be traced to the 3rd century BCE, when <a href="/wiki/Terracotta" title="Terracotta">terracotta</a> sculptures were made in the region. In classical antiquity, a notable school of sculptural Hindu, Jain and Buddhist art developed in the Pala Empire and the Sena dynasty. Islamic art evolved since the 14th century. The architecture of the Bengal Sultanate saw a distinct style of domed mosques with complex niche pillars that had no minarets. <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughal Bengal">Mughal Bengal</a>'s most celebrated artistic tradition was the weaving of <a href="/wiki/Jamdani" title="Jamdani">Jamdani</a> <a href="/wiki/Motif_(textile_arts)" title="Motif (textile arts)">motifs</a> on fine muslin, which is now classified by UNESCO as an <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">intangible cultural heritage</a>. Jamdani motifs were similar to Iranian textile art (buta motifs) and Western textile art (<a href="/wiki/Paisley_(design)" title="Paisley (design)">paisley</a>). The Jamdani weavers in Dhaka received imperial patronage.<sup id="cite_ref-star_66-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-star-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ivory" title="Ivory">Ivory</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brass" title="Brass">brass</a> were also widely used in Mughal art. <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">Pottery</a> is widely used in Bengali culture. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">modern art</a> movement in Bangladesh took shape during the 1950s, particularly with the pioneering works of <a href="/wiki/Zainul_Abedin" title="Zainul Abedin">Zainul Abedin</a>. East Bengal developed its own modernist painting and sculpture traditions, which were distinct from the art movements in West Bengal. The <a href="/wiki/Art_Institute_Dhaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Art Institute Dhaka">Art Institute Dhaka</a> has been an important center for visual art in the region. Its annual <a href="/wiki/Mangal_Shobhajatra" title="Mangal Shobhajatra">Bengali New Year parade</a> was enlisted as an intangible cultural heritage by UNESCO in 2016. </p>
      <p>Modern Bangladesh has produced many of South Asia's leading painters, including <a href="/wiki/SM_Sultan" title="SM Sultan">SM Sultan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Kibria" title="Mohammad Kibria">Mohammad Kibria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahabuddin_Ahmed_(artist)" title="Shahabuddin Ahmed (artist)">Shahabuddin Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanak_Chanpa_Chakma" title="Kanak Chanpa Chakma">Kanak Chanpa Chakma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kafil_Ahmed" title="Kafil Ahmed">Kafil Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saifuddin_Ahmed" title="Saifuddin Ahmed">Saifuddin Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qayyum_Chowdhury" title="Qayyum Chowdhury">Qayyum Chowdhury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rashid_Choudhury" title="Rashid Choudhury">Rashid Choudhury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quamrul_Hassan" title="Quamrul Hassan">Quamrul Hassan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rafiqun_Nabi" title="Rafiqun Nabi">Rafiqun Nabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syed_Jahangir" title="Syed Jahangir">Syed Jahangir</a>, among others. <a href="/wiki/Novera_Ahmed" title="Novera Ahmed">Novera Ahmed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nitun_Kundu" title="Nitun Kundu">Nitun Kundu</a> were the country's pioneers of modernist sculpture. </p>
      <p>In recent times, photography as a medium of art has become popular. Biennial <a href="/wiki/Chobi_Mela" class="mw-redirect" title="Chobi Mela">Chobi Mela</a> is considered the largest photography festival in Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[362]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladeshi literature">Bangladeshi literature</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png/220px-Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png/330px-Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png/440px-Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png 2x" data-file-width="782" data-file-height="583"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Young_tagore_and_nazrul.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
