         </div><a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a>, author of the <a href="/wiki/National_Anthem_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="National Anthem of Bangladesh">national anthem</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kazi_Nazrul_Islam" title="Kazi Nazrul Islam">Kazi Nazrul Islam</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Poet" class="mw-redirect" title="National Poet">National Poet</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg/220px-Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg/330px-Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg/440px-Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1535"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bangla_Academy_Inside_2_by_Ashfaq.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Bangla_Academy" title="Bangla Academy">Bangla Academy</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The oldest evidence of writing in Bangladesh is the Mahasthan <a href="/wiki/Brahmi" class="mw-redirect" title="Brahmi">Brahmi</a> Inscription, which dates back to the 3rd century BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup> In the Gupta Empire, Sanskrit literature thrived in the region. Bengali developed from <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Magadhi_Prakrit" title="Magadhi Prakrit">Magadhi Prakrit</a> in the 8th to 10th century. Bengali literature is a millennium-old tradition; the <a href="/wiki/Charyapada" class="mw-redirect" title="Charyapada">Charyapadas</a> are the earliest examples of Bengali poetry. Sufi spiritualism inspired many <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Muslim">Bengali Muslim</a> writers. During the Bengal Sultanate, medieval Bengali writers were influenced by <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">Arabic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian works</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chandidas" title="Chandidas">Chandidas</a> are the notable lyric poets from the early Medieval Age. <a href="/wiki/Alaol" title="Alaol">Syed Alaol</a> was a noted secular poet and translator from the <a href="/wiki/Arakan" title="Arakan">Arakan</a> region. The Bengal Renaissance shaped the emergence of modern Bengali literature, including novels, short stories and <a href="/wiki/Bengali_science_fiction" title="Bengali science fiction">science fiction</a>. Rabindranath Tagore was the first non-European laureate of the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> and is described as the Bengali Shakespeare.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[364]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kazi_Nazrul_Islam" title="Kazi Nazrul Islam">Kazi Nazrul Islam</a> was a revolutionary poet who espoused political rebellion against colonialism and fascism. <a href="/wiki/Begum_Rokeya" title="Begum Rokeya">Begum Rokeya</a> is regarded as the pioneer feminist writer of Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-Rubaiyat_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rubaiyat-365">[365]</a></sup> Other renaissance icons included Michael Madhusudan Dutt and <a href="/wiki/Sarat_Chandra_Chattopadhyay" title="Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay">Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay</a>. The writer <a href="/wiki/Syed_Mujtaba_Ali" title="Syed Mujtaba Ali">Syed Mujtaba Ali</a> is noted for his cosmopolitan Bengali worldview.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[366]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jasimuddin" title="Jasimuddin">Jasimuddin</a> was a renowned pastoral poet. <a href="/wiki/Shamsur_Rahman_(poet)" title="Shamsur Rahman (poet)">Shamsur Rahman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al_Mahmud" title="Al Mahmud">Al Mahmud</a> are considered two of the greatest Bengali poets to have emerged in the 20th century. <a href="/wiki/Farrukh_Ahmad" title="Farrukh Ahmad">Farrukh Ahmad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sufia_Kamal" title="Sufia Kamal">Sufia Kamal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Ali_Ahsan" title="Syed Ali Ahsan">Syed Ali Ahsan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ahsan_Habib" title="Ahsan Habib">Ahsan Habib</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abul_Hussain" title="Abul Hussain">Abul Hussain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahid_Qadri" title="Shahid Qadri">Shahid Qadri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fazal_Shahabuddin" title="Fazal Shahabuddin">Fazal Shahabuddin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Zafar_Obaidullah" title="Abu Zafar Obaidullah">Abu Zafar Obaidullah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Omar_Ali_(poet)" title="Omar Ali (poet)">Omar Ali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Mujahidi" title="Al Mujahidi">Al Mujahidi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Shamsul_Huq" class="mw-redirect" title="Syed Shamsul Huq">Syed Shamsul Huq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nirmalendu_Goon" title="Nirmalendu Goon">Nirmalendu Goon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abid_Azad" title="Abid Azad">Abid Azad</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sanaul_Haque_Khan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sanaul Haque Khan (page does not exist)">Sanaul Haque Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hasan_Hafizur_Rahman" title="Hasan Hafizur Rahman">Hasan Hafizur Rahman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hye_Sikder" title="Abdul Hye Sikder">Abdul Hye Sikder</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sayeed_Abubakar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sayeed Abubakar (page does not exist)">Sayeed Abubakar</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jafar_Ahmad_Rashed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jafar Ahmad Rashed (page does not exist)">Jafar Ahmad Rashed</a> are important figures of modern Bangladeshi poetry. <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Sofa" title="Ahmed Sofa">Ahmed Sofa</a> is regarded as the most important Bangladeshi intellectual in the post-independence era. <a href="/wiki/Humayun_Ahmed" title="Humayun Ahmed">Humayun Ahmed</a> was a popular writer of modern Bangladeshi <a href="/wiki/Magical_realism" class="mw-redirect" title="Magical realism">magical realism</a> and science fiction. Notable writers of Bangladeshi fictions include Mir Mosharraf Hossain, <a href="/wiki/Akhteruzzaman_Elias" title="Akhteruzzaman Elias">Akhteruzzaman Elias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alauddin_Al_Azad" class="mw-redirect" title="Alauddin Al Azad">Alauddin Al Azad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahidul_Zahir" title="Shahidul Zahir">Shahidul Zahir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rashid_Karim" title="Rashid Karim">Rashid Karim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahmudul_Haque" title="Mahmudul Haque">Mahmudul Haque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Waliullah" title="Syed Waliullah">Syed Waliullah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahidullah_Kaiser" title="Shahidullah Kaiser">Shahidullah Kaiser</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shawkat_Osman" title="Shawkat Osman">Shawkat Osman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Selina_Hossain" title="Selina Hossain">Selina Hossain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahed_Ali" title="Shahed Ali">Shahed Ali</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abul_Khayer_Muslehuddin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abul Khayer Muslehuddin (page does not exist)">Abul Khayer Muslehuddin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Razia_Khan" title="Razia Khan">Razia Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anisul_Hoque" title="Anisul Hoque">Anisul Hoque</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Mannan_Syed" title="Abdul Mannan Syed">Abdul Mannan Syed</a>. </p>
      <p>The annual <a href="/wiki/Ekushey_Book_Fair" title="Ekushey Book Fair">Ekushey Book Fair</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hay_Festival_Dhaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Hay Festival Dhaka">Dhaka Literature Festival</a>, organised by the <a href="/wiki/Bangla_Academy" title="Bangla Academy">Bangla Academy</a>, are among the largest literary festivals in South Asia. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Women_in_Bangladesh">Women in Bangladesh</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg/220px-Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg/330px-Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg/440px-Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1344" data-file-height="1008"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mission_observation_FIDH.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Women make up most of the workforce of Bangladesh's <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_textile_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangladesh textile industry">export oriented garment industry</a> that makes the highest contribution to the country's <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Bangladesh" title="Economy of Bangladesh">economic growth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BILA_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BILA-367">[367]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Bangladesh" title="Women in Bangladesh">Women in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Although, as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, several women occupied major political office in Bangladesh, its women continue to live under a patriarchal social regime where violence is common.<sup id="cite_ref-whispers_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-whispers-368">[368]</a></sup> Whereas in India and Pakistan women participate less in the workforce as their education increases, the reverse is the case in Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-whispers_368-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-whispers-368">[368]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bengal has a long history of <a href="/wiki/Feminist_activism" class="mw-redirect" title="Feminist activism">feminist activism</a> dating back to the 19th century. <a href="/wiki/Begum_Rokeya" title="Begum Rokeya">Begum Rokeya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nawab_Faizunnesa" title="Nawab Faizunnesa">Faizunnessa Chowdhurani</a> played an important role in emancipating Bengali Muslim women from <a href="/wiki/Purdah" title="Purdah">purdah</a>, prior to the country's division, as well as promoting girls' education. Several women were elected to the Bengal Legislative Assembly in the British Raj. The first women's magazine, <i><a href="/wiki/Begum_(magazine)" title="Begum (magazine)">Begum</a></i>, was published in 1948. </p>
      <p>In 2008, Bangladeshi female workforce participation stood at 26%.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup> Women dominate <a href="/wiki/Blue_collar" class="mw-redirect" title="Blue collar">blue collar</a> jobs in the Bangladeshi garment industry. Agriculture, social services, healthcare and education are also major occupations for Bangladeshi women, while their employment in <a href="/wiki/White-collar_worker" title="White-collar worker">white collar</a> positions has steadily increased. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Bangladesh" title="Architecture of Bangladesh">Architecture of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg/220px-Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg/330px-Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg/440px-Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2512" data-file-height="1678"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ahsan_Manzil-Front_View.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Ahsan_Manzil" title="Ahsan Manzil">Ahsan Manzil</a> is one of the largest residences in <a href="/wiki/Old_Dhaka" title="Old Dhaka">Old Dhaka</a>, where there are many <a href="/wiki/Indo-Saracenic" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Saracenic">Indo-Saracenic</a> buildings
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The architectural traditions of Bangladesh have a 2,500-year-old heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup> Terracotta architecture is a distinct feature of Bengal. Pre-Islamic Bengali architecture reached its pinnacle in the Pala Empire, when the Pala School of Sculptural Art established grand structures such as the Somapura Mahavihara. <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">Islamic architecture</a> began developing under the Bengal Sultanate, when local terracotta styles influenced medieval mosque construction. The <a href="/wiki/Adina_Mosque" title="Adina Mosque">Adina Mosque</a> of <a href="/wiki/United_Bengal" title="United Bengal">United Bengal</a> was the largest mosque built on the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Sixty_Dome_Mosque" title="Sixty Dome Mosque">Sixty Dome Mosque</a> was the largest medieval mosque built in Bangladesh, and is a fine example of Turkic-Bengali architecture. The <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Mughal style</a> replaced indigenous architecture when Bengal became a province of the Mughal Empire and influenced the development of urban housing. The <a href="/wiki/Kantajew_Temple" title="Kantajew Temple">Kantajew Temple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dhakeshwari_Temple" title="Dhakeshwari Temple">Dhakeshwari Temple</a> are excellent examples of late medieval <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture" title="Hindu temple architecture">Hindu temple architecture</a>. <a href="/wiki/Indo-Saracenic_Revival_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture">Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture</a>, based on Indo-Islamic styles, flourished during the British period. The zamindar gentry in Bangladesh built numerous Indo-Saracenic palaces and country mansions, such as the <a href="/wiki/Ahsan_Manzil" title="Ahsan Manzil">Ahsan Manzil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajhat_Palace" title="Tajhat Palace">Tajhat Palace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uttara_Gonobhaban" class="mw-redirect" title="Uttara Gonobhaban">Dighapatia Palace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puthia_Rajbari" title="Puthia Rajbari">Puthia Rajbari</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natore_Rajbari" title="Natore Rajbari">Natore Rajbari</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Guest_house_in_Sylhet_(01).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Guest_house_in_Sylhet_%2801%29.jpg/220px-Guest_house_in_Sylhet_%2801%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Guest_house_in_Sylhet_%2801%29.jpg/330px-Guest_house_in_Sylhet_%2801%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Guest_house_in_Sylhet_%2801%29.jpg/440px-Guest_house_in_Sylhet_%2801%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4600" data-file-height="3059"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Guest_house_in_Sylhet_(01).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Bungalow" title="Bungalow">bungalow</a>, which originated in Bengal, is a common sight. The roof style seen in the picture is common in the hilly areas of <a href="/wiki/Sylhet" title="Sylhet">Sylhet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chittagong" title="Chittagong">Chittagong</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Bengali <a href="/wiki/Vernacular_architecture" title="Vernacular architecture">vernacular architecture</a> is noted for pioneering the <a href="/wiki/Bungalow" title="Bungalow">bungalow</a>. Bangladeshi villages consist of <a href="/wiki/Thatch" class="mw-redirect" title="Thatch">thatched</a> roofed houses made of natural materials like <a href="/wiki/Mud" title="Mud">mud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Straw" title="Straw">straw</a>, wood and bamboo. In modern times, village bungalows are increasingly made of <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Muzharul_Islam" title="Muzharul Islam">Muzharul Islam</a> was the pioneer of Bangladeshi modern architecture. His varied works set the course of modern architectural practice in the country. Islam brought leading global architects, including <a href="/wiki/Louis_Kahn" title="Louis Kahn">Louis Kahn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Neutra" title="Richard Neutra">Richard Neutra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Tigerman" title="Stanley Tigerman">Stanley Tigerman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Rudolph_(architect)" title="Paul Rudolph (architect)">Paul Rudolph</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Boughey" title="Robert Boughey">Robert Boughey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Konstantinos_Apostolos_Doxiadis" class="mw-redirect" title="Konstantinos Apostolos Doxiadis">Konstantinos Doxiadis</a>, to work in erstwhile East Pakistan. Louis Kahn was chosen to design the National Parliament Complex in <a href="/wiki/Sher-e-Bangla_Nagar" title="Sher-e-Bangla Nagar">Sher-e-Bangla Nagar</a>. Kahn's monumental designs, combining regional red brick aesthetics, his own concrete and marble <a href="/wiki/Brutalism" class="mw-redirect" title="Brutalism">brutalism</a> and the use of lakes to represent Bengali geography, are regarded as one of the masterpieces of the 20th century. In more recent times, award-winning architects like <a href="/wiki/Rafiq_Azam" title="Rafiq Azam">Rafiq Azam</a> have set the course of contemporary architecture by adopting influences from the works of Islam and Kahn. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_arts">Performing arts</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ektara_player.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ektara_player.jpg/160px-Ektara_player.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ektara_player.jpg/240px-Ektara_player.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ektara_player.jpg/320px-Ektara_player.jpg 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="750"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ektara_player.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A Baul from <a href="/wiki/Lalon" title="Lalon">Lalon Shah's</a> shrine in <a href="/wiki/Kushtia_District" title="Kushtia District">Kushtia</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Theatre_in_Bangladesh" title="Theatre in Bangladesh">Theatre in Bangladesh</a> includes various forms with a history dating back to the 4th century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396-372">[372]</a></sup> It includes narrative forms, song and dance forms, supra-personae forms, performances with scroll paintings, puppet theatre and processional forms.<sup id="cite_ref-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396_372-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396-372">[372]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jatra_(theatre)" title="Jatra (theatre)">Jatra</a> is the most popular form of Bengali folk theatre. The dance traditions of Bangladesh include indigenous tribal and Bengali dance forms, as well as <a href="/wiki/Classical_Indian_dance" class="mw-redirect" title="Classical Indian dance">classical Indian dances</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Kathak" title="Kathak">Kathak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odissi" title="Odissi">Odissi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manipuri_dance" title="Manipuri dance">Manipuri dances</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Bangladesh" title="Music of Bangladesh">music of Bangladesh</a> features the <a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">Baul</a> <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mystical</a> tradition, listed by UNESCO as a <a href="/wiki/Masterpiece_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity" class="mw-redirect" title="Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity">Masterpiece of Intangible Cultural Heritage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[373]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lalon" title="Lalon">Fakir Lalon Shah</a> popularised <a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">Baul</a> music in the country in the 18th century and it has been one of the most popular music genera in the country since then. Most modern <a href="/wiki/Bauls" class="mw-redirect" title="Bauls">Bauls</a> are devoted to Lalon Shah.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup> Numerous lyric-based musical traditions, varying from one region to the next, exist, including <a href="/wiki/Gombhira" title="Gombhira">Gombhira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhatiali" title="Bhatiali">Bhatiali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhawaiya" title="Bhawaiya">Bhawaiya</a>. Folk music is accompanied by a one-stringed instrument known as the <a href="/wiki/Ektara" title="Ektara">ektara</a>. Other instruments include the <a href="/wiki/Dotara" title="Dotara">dotara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dhol" title="Dhol">dhol</a>, flute, and <a href="/wiki/Tabla" title="Tabla">tabla</a>. Bengali classical music includes <a href="/wiki/Tagore_songs" class="mw-redirect" title="Tagore songs">Tagore songs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nazrul_geeti" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazrul geeti">Nazrul Sangeet</a>. Bangladesh has a rich tradition of <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Indian classical music</a>, which uses instruments like the <a href="/wiki/Sitar" title="Sitar">sitar</a>, tabla, <a href="/wiki/Sarod" title="Sarod">sarod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santoor" title="Santoor">santoor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sabina_Yasmin" title="Sabina Yasmin">Sabina Yasmin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Runa_Laila" title="Runa Laila">Runa Laila</a> are considered the leading playback singers in the modern time, while musician <a href="/wiki/Ayub_Bachchu" title="Ayub Bachchu">Ayub Bachchu</a> is credited with popularising Bengali rock music in Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Textiles">Textiles</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Textile_arts_of_Bangladesh" title="Textile arts of Bangladesh">Textile arts of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">Muslin trade in Bengal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kantha_(Quilt)_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg/220px-Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg/330px-Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg/440px-Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="1548"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kantha_(Quilt)_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Embroidery on <a href="/wiki/Nakshi_kantha" title="Nakshi kantha">Nakshi kantha</a> (embroidered <a href="/wiki/Quilt" title="Quilt">quilt</a>), centuries-old Bengali art tradition
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Nakshi_Kantha" class="mw-redirect" title="Nakshi Kantha">Nakshi Kantha</a> is a centuries-old <a href="/wiki/Embroidery" title="Embroidery">embroidery</a> tradition for <a href="/wiki/Quilt" title="Quilt">quilts</a>, said to be indigenous to eastern Bengal (i.e. Bangladesh). The sari is the national dress for Bangladeshi women. Mughal Dhaka was renowned for producing the finest <a href="/wiki/Muslin" title="Muslin">Muslin</a> saris, as well as the famed <a href="/wiki/Dhakai" title="Dhakai">Dhakai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jamdani" title="Jamdani">Jamdani</a>, the weaving of which is listed by UNESCO as one of the masterpieces of humanity's intangible cultural heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[377]</a></sup> Bangladesh also produces the <a href="/wiki/Rajshahi_silk" title="Rajshahi silk">Rajshahi silk</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez">shalwar kameez</a> is also widely worn by Bangladeshi women. In urban areas some women can be seen in western clothing. The <a href="/wiki/Kurta" title="Kurta">kurta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sherwani" title="Sherwani">sherwani</a> are the national dress of Bangladeshi men; the <a href="/wiki/Lungi" title="Lungi">lungi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a> are worn by them in informal settings. Aside from ethnic wear, domestically <a href="/wiki/Tailored" class="mw-redirect" title="Tailored">tailored</a> <a href="/wiki/Suit_(clothing)" class="mw-redirect" title="Suit (clothing)">suits</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neckties" class="mw-redirect" title="Neckties">neckties</a> are customarily worn by the country's men in offices, in schools and at social events. </p>
      <p>The handloom industry supplies 60â65% of the country's clothing demand.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup> The Bengali ethnic <a href="/wiki/Fashion_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Fashion industry">fashion industry</a> has flourished in the changing environment of the fashion world. The retailer <a href="/wiki/Aarong" title="Aarong">Aarong</a> is one of the most successful ethnic wear brands in South Asia. The development of the Bangladesh textile industry, which supplies leading international brands, has promoted the production and retail of modern Western attire locally, with the country now having a number of expanding local brands like Westecs and Yellow. Bangladesh is the world's second-largest garments exporter. Among Bangladesh's fashion designers, <a href="/wiki/Bibi_Russell" title="Bibi Russell">Bibi Russell</a> has received international acclaim for her "Fashion for Development" shows.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bengali_cuisine" title="Bengali cuisine">Bengali cuisine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_cuisine" title="Bangladeshi cuisine">Bangladeshi cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bangladeshi_cuisine.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bangladeshi_cuisine.png/220px-Bangladeshi_cuisine.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="177" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bangladeshi_cuisine.png/330px-Bangladeshi_cuisine.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bangladeshi_cuisine.png/440px-Bangladeshi_cuisine.png 2x" data-file-width="1608" data-file-height="1296"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bangladeshi_cuisine.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Traditional Bangladeshi Meal: <a href="/wiki/Mustard_seed" title="Mustard seed">Mustard seed</a> <a href="/wiki/Ilish" title="Ilish">Ilish</a> <a href="/wiki/Curry" title="Curry">Curry</a>, Dhakai <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">Biryani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pitha" title="Pitha">Pitha</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/White_rice" title="White rice">White rice</a> is the staple of Bangladeshi cuisine, along with many vegetables and <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a>. Rice preparations also include Bengali <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryanis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pulaos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Khichuri" class="mw-redirect" title="Khichuri">khichuris</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mustard_(condiment)" title="Mustard (condiment)">Mustard</a> sauce, <a href="/wiki/Ghee" title="Ghee">ghee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_oil" title="Sunflower oil">sunflower oil</a> and fruit <a href="/wiki/Chutney" title="Chutney">chutneys</a> are widely used in Bangladeshi cooking. Fish is the main source of protein in Bengali cuisine. The <a href="/wiki/Hilsa" class="mw-redirect" title="Hilsa">Hilsa</a> is the national fish and immensely popular across Bangladesh. Other kinds of fish eaten include <a href="/wiki/Rohu" title="Rohu">rohu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butterfish" class="mw-redirect" title="Butterfish">butterfish</a>, catfish, <a href="/wiki/Tilapia" title="Tilapia">tilapia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barramundi" title="Barramundi">barramundi</a>. <a href="/wiki/Fish_egg" class="mw-redirect" title="Fish egg">Fish eggs</a> are a gourmet delicacy. Seafood holds an important place in Bengali cuisine, especially <a href="/wiki/Lobster" title="Lobster">lobsters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrimp" title="Shrimp">shrimps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dried_fish" title="Dried fish">dried fish</a>. Meat consumption includes chicken, beef, <a href="/wiki/Mutton" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutton">mutton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Venison" title="Venison">venison</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duck" title="Duck">duck</a> and <a href="/wiki/Squab_(food)" class="mw-redirect" title="Squab (food)">squab</a>. In Chittagong, <i>Mezban</i> feasts are a popular tradition featuring the serving of hot beef <a href="/wiki/Curry" title="Curry">curry</a>. In Sylhet, the <i><a href="/wiki/Shatkora" class="mw-redirect" title="Shatkora">shatkora</a></i> lemons are used to marinate dishes. In the tribal Hill Tracts, bamboo shoot cooking is prevalent. Bangladesh has a vast spread of desserts, including distinctive <a href="/wiki/Sweets" class="mw-redirect" title="Sweets">sweets</a> like <i><a href="/wiki/Rasgulla" title="Rasgulla">RÃ´shogolla</a></i>, <i>RÃ´shomalai</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Chomchom" title="Chomchom">Chomchom</a></i>, <i>Mishti Doi</i> and <i>Kalojaam</i>. <a href="/wiki/Pitha" title="Pitha">Pithas</a> are traditional boiled desserts made with rice or fruits. <a href="/wiki/Halwa" class="mw-redirect" title="Halwa">Halwa</a> is served during religious festivities. <a href="/wiki/Naan" title="Naan">Naan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paratha" title="Paratha">paratha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luchi" title="Luchi">luchi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bakarkhani" title="Bakarkhani">bakarkhani</a> are the main local breads. <a href="/wiki/Milk_tea" title="Milk tea">Milk tea</a> is offered to guests as a gesture of welcome and is the most common hot beverage in the country. <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">Kebabs</a> are widely popular across Bangladesh, particularly <a href="/wiki/Seekh_kebab" title="Seekh kebab">seekh kebabs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicken_tikka" title="Chicken tikka">chicken tikka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shashlik" title="Shashlik">shashliks</a>. </p>
      <p>Bangladesh shares its culinary heritage with the neighbouring Indian state of <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>. The two regions have several differences, however. In Muslim-majority Bangladesh, meat consumption is greater; whereas in Hindu-majority West Bengal, vegetarianism is more prevalent. The Bangladeshi diaspora dominates the South Asian restaurant industry in many Western countries, particularly in the United Kingdom. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">Festivals</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Bangladesh" title="Public holidays in Bangladesh">Public holidays in Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_Bangladesh" title="List of festivals in Bangladesh">List of festivals in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg/220px-Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg/330px-Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg/440px-Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2161"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mangal_Shobhajatra_in_Dhaka.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The annual <a href="/wiki/Bengali_New_Year" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali New Year">Bengali New Year</a> parade
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><i><a href="/wiki/Pahela_Baishakh" title="Pahela Baishakh">Pahela Baishakh</a></i>, the Bengali new year, is the major festival of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Bengal" title="Culture of Bengal">Bengali culture</a> and sees widespread festivities. Of the major holidays celebrated in Bangladesh, only Pahela Baishakh comes without any pre-existing expectations (specific religious identity, culture of gift-giving, etc.) and has become an occasion for celebrating the simpler, rural roots of the Bengal. Other cultural festivals include <a href="/wiki/Nabanna" title="Nabanna">Nabonno</a>, and Poush Parbon both of which are Bengali harvest festivals. </p>
      <p>The Muslim festivals of Eid al-Fitr, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Adha" title="Eid al-Adha">Eid al-Adha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milad_un_Nabi" class="mw-redirect" title="Milad un Nabi">Milad un Nabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muharram" title="Muharram">Muharram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chand_Raat" class="mw-redirect" title="Chand Raat">Chand Raat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barat_Night" class="mw-redirect" title="Barat Night">Shab-e-Barat</a>; the Hindu festivals of <a href="/wiki/Durga_Puja" title="Durga Puja">Durga Puja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Janmashtami" class="mw-redirect" title="Janmashtami">Janmashtami</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rath_Yatra" class="mw-redirect" title="Rath Yatra">Rath Yatra</a>; the Buddhist festival of <a href="/wiki/Vesak" title="Vesak">Buddha Purnima</a>, which marks the birth of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>, and Christian festival of Christmas are <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Bangladesh" title="Public holidays in Bangladesh">national holidays</a> in Bangladesh and see the most widespread celebrations in the country. The two Eids are celebrated with long streak of public holidays and give the city-dwellers opportunity to celebrate the festivals with their families outside city. </p>
      <p>Alongside are national days like the remembrance of 21 February 1952 <a href="/wiki/Language_Movement_Day" title="Language Movement Day">Language Movement Day</a> (declared as <a href="/wiki/International_Mother_Language_Day" title="International Mother Language Day">International Mother Language Day</a> by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> in 1999),<sup id="cite_ref-UNESCO_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-380">[380]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Bangladesh)" title="Independence Day (Bangladesh)">Independence Day</a> and <a href="/wiki/Victory_day_of_Bangladesh" title="Victory day of Bangladesh">Victory Day</a>. On Language Movement Day, people congregate at the <a href="/wiki/Shaheed_Minar,_Dhaka" title="Shaheed Minar, Dhaka">Shaheed Minar</a> in Dhaka to remember the national heroes of the Bengali Language Movement. Similar gatherings are observed at the <a href="/wiki/National_Martyrs%E2%80%99_Memorial" class="mw-redirect" title="National Martyrsâ Memorial">National Martyrsâ Memorial</a> on Independence Day and Victory Day to remember the national heroes of the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a>. These occasions are celebrated with public ceremonies, parades, rallies by citizens, political speeches, fairs, concerts, and various other public and private events, celebrating the history and traditions of Bangladesh. TV and radio stations broadcast special programs and patriotic songs, and many schools and colleges organise fairs, festivals, and concerts that draw the participation of citizens from all levels of Bangladeshi society.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Sports in Bangladesh">Sports in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_(4).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg/250px-Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg/375px-Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg/500px-Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_(4).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Bangladesh team on practice session at Sher-e-Bangla National Cricket Stadium
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In rural Bangladesh, several traditional indigenous sports such as <a href="/wiki/Kabaddi" title="Kabaddi">Kabaddi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boli_Khela" class="mw-redirect" title="Boli Khela">Boli Khela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lathi_Khela" class="mw-redirect" title="Lathi Khela">Lathi Khela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nouka_Baich" title="Nouka Baich">Nouka Baich</a> remain fairly popular. While <a href="/wiki/Kabaddi" title="Kabaddi">Kabaddi</a> is the national sport<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a> is the most popular sport in the country followed by <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_national_cricket_team" title="Bangladesh national cricket team">national cricket team</a> participated in their first <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a> in 1999 and the following year was granted <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test cricket</a> status. Bangladesh reached the quarter-final of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2015 Cricket World Cup">2015 Cricket World Cup</a>, the semi-final of the <a href="/wiki/2017_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2017 ICC Champions Trophy">2017 ICC Champions Trophy</a> and they reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cup" title="Asia Cup">Asia Cup</a> 3 times â in 2012, 2016 and 2018. In February 2020, the Bangladesh youth national cricket team won the men's <a href="/wiki/2020_Under-19_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2020 Under-19 Cricket World Cup">Under-19 Cricket World Cup</a>, held in South Africa. This was Bangladesh's first World Cup victory.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Women's sports saw significant progress in the 2010s decade in Bangladesh. In 2018 the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_women%27s_national_cricket_team" title="Bangladesh women's national cricket team">Bangladesh women's national cricket team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2018_Women%27s_Twenty20_Asia_Cup" title="2018 Women's Twenty20 Asia Cup">2018 Women's Twenty20 Asia Cup</a> defeating <a href="/wiki/India_women%27s_national_cricket_team" title="India women's national cricket team">India women's national cricket team</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Bangladesh women's national football team">Bangladesh women's national football team</a> has also registered some success at regional level, especially the Under-15 and Under-18 teams. </p>
      <p>Football is a popular sport in Bangladesh, alongside cricket,<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup> and is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Football_Federation" title="Bangladesh Football Federation">Bangladesh Football Federation</a> (BFF). Football tournaments are regularly organised in and outside <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_District" title="Dhaka District">Dhaka</a> and football fever grips the nation during every <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>. On 4 November 2018, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_national_under-17_football_team" title="Bangladesh national under-17 football team">Bangladesh national under-15 football team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2018_SAFF_U-15_Championship" title="2018 SAFF U-15 Championship">2018 SAFF U-15 Championship</a>, defeating <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_national_under-17_football_team" title="Pakistan national under-17 football team">Pakistan national under-15 football team</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup> Bangladesh archers Ety Khatun and Roman Sana won several gold medals winning all the 10 <a href="/wiki/Archery" title="Archery">archery</a> events (both individual, and team events) in the <a href="/wiki/2019_South_Asian_Games" title="2019 South Asian Games">2019 South Asian Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Sports_Council" title="National Sports Council">National Sports Council</a> regulates 42 sporting federations.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup> Athletics, swimming, archery, boxing, volleyball, weight-lifting and wrestling and different forms of martial arts remain popular. <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is very popular in Bangladesh. Bangladesh has five grandmasters in chess. Among them, <a href="/wiki/Niaz_Murshed" title="Niaz Murshed">Niaz Murshed</a> was the first grandmaster in South Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup> In 2010, mountain climber <a href="/wiki/Musa_Ibrahim" title="Musa Ibrahim">Musa Ibrahim</a> became the first Bangladeshi climber to conquer <a href="/wiki/Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest">Mount Everest</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-dailystardetail_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dailystardetail-391">[391]</a></sup> He climbed the top of the summit of Mount Everest.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wasfia_Nazreen" title="Wasfia Nazreen">Wasfia Nazreen</a> is the first Bangladeshi climber to climb the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Summits" title="Seven Summits">Seven Summits</a>, which are the highest mountains of each of the seven continents of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Bangladesh hosts a number of international tournaments. <a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu_Cup" title="Bangabandhu Cup">Bangabandhu Cup</a> is an international football tournament hosted in the country. Bangladesh hosted the South Asian Games several times. In 2011, Bangladesh co-hosted the <a href="/wiki/ICC_Cricket_World_Cup_2011" class="mw-redirect" title="ICC Cricket World Cup 2011">ICC Cricket World Cup 2011</a> with India and Sri Lanka. The <a href="/wiki/2014_ICC_World_Twenty20" title="2014 ICC World Twenty20">2014 ICC World Twenty20</a> championship was solely hosted by Bangladesh. Bangladesh hosted the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cup" title="Asia Cup">Asia Cup</a> Cricket Tournament in 2000, 2012, 2014 and 2016. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_cinema">Media and cinema</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Bangladesh">Media of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Bangladesh" title="Cinema of Bangladesh">Cinema of Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg/220px-Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg/330px-Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg/440px-Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg 2x" data-file-width="660" data-file-height="451"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nawab_Sirajuddaula.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Anwar_Hossain_(actor)" title="Anwar Hossain (actor)">Anwar Hossain</a> playing <a href="/wiki/Siraj-ud-Daulah" class="mw-redirect" title="Siraj-ud-Daulah">Siraj-ud-Daulah</a>, the last independent <a href="/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal" class="mw-redirect" title="Nawab of Bengal">Nawab of Bengal</a>, in the 1967 film <i><a href="/wiki/Nawab_Sirajuddaula_(film)" title="Nawab Sirajuddaula (film)">Nawab Sirajuddaulah</a></i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Bangladeshi press is diverse, outspoken and privately owned. Over 200 newspapers are published in the country. <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Betar" title="Bangladesh Betar">Bangladesh Betar</a> is the state-run radio service.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Broadcasting_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="British Broadcasting Corporation">British Broadcasting Corporation</a> operates the popular <a href="/wiki/BBC_Bangla" title="BBC Bangla">BBC Bangla</a> news and current affairs service. Bengali broadcasts from <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a> are also very popular. <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Television" title="Bangladesh Television">Bangladesh Television</a> (BTV) is the state-owned television network. There more than 20 privately owned television networks, including several <a href="/wiki/News_channel" class="mw-redirect" title="News channel">news channels</a>. <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_media" class="mw-redirect" title="Freedom of the media">Freedom of the media</a> remains a major concern, due to government attempts at censorship and the harassment of journalists. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Bangladesh" title="Cinema of Bangladesh">cinema of Bangladesh</a> dates back to 1898, when films began screening at the Crown Theatre in Dhaka. The first bioscope on the subcontinent was established in Dhaka that year. The <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Nawab_Family" class="mw-redirect" title="Dhaka Nawab Family">Dhaka Nawab Family</a> patronised the production of several <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent films</a> in the 1920s and 30s. In 1931, the East Bengal Cinematograph Society released the first full-length feature film in Bangladesh, titled the <i>Last Kiss</i>. The first feature film in East Pakistan, <i><a href="/wiki/Mukh_O_Mukhosh" title="Mukh O Mukhosh">Mukh O Mukhosh</a></i>, was released in 1956. During the 1960s, 25â30 films were produced annually in Dhaka. By the 2000s, Bangladesh produced 80â100 films a year. While the Bangladeshi film industry has achieved limited commercial success, the country has produced notable independent filmmakers. <a href="/wiki/Zahir_Raihan" title="Zahir Raihan">Zahir Raihan</a> was a prominent documentary-maker who was assassinated in 1971. The late <a href="/wiki/Tareque_Masud" title="Tareque Masud">Tareque Masud</a> is regarded as one of Bangladesh's outstanding directors for his critically acclaimed films on social issues.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> Masud was honoured by <a href="/wiki/FIPRESCI" class="mw-redirect" title="FIPRESCI">FIPRESCI</a> at the 2002 <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> for his film <i><a href="/wiki/Matir_Moina" title="Matir Moina">The Clay Bird</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Tanvir_Mokammel" title="Tanvir Mokammel">Tanvir Mokammel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mostofa_Sarwar_Farooki" title="Mostofa Sarwar Farooki">Mostofa Sarwar Farooki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Humayun_Ahmed" title="Humayun Ahmed">Humayun Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alamgir_Kabir_(film_maker)" title="Alamgir Kabir (film maker)">Alamgir Kabir</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chashi_Nazrul_Islam" title="Chashi Nazrul Islam">Chashi Nazrul Islam</a> are some of the prominent directors of Bangladeshi cinema. Bangladesh has a very active film society culture. It started in 1963 in Dhaka. Now around 40 Film Societies are active all over Bangladesh. <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Film_Societies_of_Bangladesh" title="Federation of Film Societies of Bangladesh">Federation of Film Societies of Bangladesh</a> is the parent organisation of the film society movement of Bangladesh. Active film societies include the Rainbow Film Society, <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_Film_Society" title="Children's Film Society">Children's Film Society</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moviyana_Film_Society" title="Moviyana Film Society">Moviyana Film Society</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_University_Film_Society" title="Dhaka University Film Society">Dhaka University Film Society</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums_and_libraries">Museums and libraries</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Museums_in_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Museums in Bangladesh">Museums in Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_libraries_in_Bangladesh" title="List of libraries in Bangladesh">List of libraries in Bangladesh</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_National_Museum_(01).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Bangladesh_National_Museum_%2801%29.jpg/220px-Bangladesh_National_Museum_%2801%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Bangladesh_National_Museum_%2801%29.jpg/330px-Bangladesh_National_Museum_%2801%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Bangladesh_National_Museum_%2801%29.jpg/440px-Bangladesh_National_Museum_%2801%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6016" data-file-height="4000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_National_Museum_(01).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_National_Museum" title="Bangladesh National Museum">Bangladesh National Museum</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG/220px-Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG/330px-Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG/440px-Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Northbrook_Hall_05.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Northbrook_Hall" title="Northbrook Hall">Northbrook Hall</a>, a public library opened in 1882 with rare book collections from the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Varendra_Research_Museum" title="Varendra Research Museum">Varendra Research Museum</a> is the oldest museum in Bangladesh. It houses important collections from both the pre-Islamic and Islamic periods, including the sculptures of the Pala-Sena School of Art and the Indus Valley Civilization; as well as Sanskrit, Arabic and Persian manuscripts and inscriptions. The Ahsan Manzil, the former residence of the Nawab of Dhaka, is a national museum housing collections from the British Raj. It was the site of the founding conference of the All India Muslim League and hosted many British Viceroys in Dhaka. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Tajhat_Palace" title="Tajhat Palace">Tajhat Palace</a> Museum preserves artefacts of the rich cultural heritage of North Bengal, including Hindu-Buddhist sculptures and Islamic manuscripts. The <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh_Museum" title="Mymensingh Museum">Mymensingh Museum</a> houses the personal antique collections of Bengali aristocrats in central Bengal. The <a href="/wiki/Ethnological_Museum_of_Chittagong" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnological Museum of Chittagong">Ethnological Museum of Chittagong</a> showcases the lifestyle of various tribes in Bangladesh. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_National_Museum" title="Bangladesh National Museum">Bangladesh National Museum</a> is located in <a href="/wiki/Ramna" class="mw-redirect" title="Ramna">Ramna</a>, Dhaka and has a rich collection of antiquities. The <a href="/wiki/Liberation_War_Museum" title="Liberation War Museum">Liberation War Museum</a> documents the Bangladeshi struggle for independence and the 1971 genocide. </p>
      <p>In ancient times, manuscripts were written on palm leaves, tree barks, parchment vellum and terracotta plates and preserved at monasteries known as <i><a href="/wiki/Vihara" class="mw-redirect" title="Vihara">viharas</a></i>. The Hussain Shahi dynasty established royal libraries during the Bengal Sultanate. Libraries were established in each district of Bengal by the zamindar gentry during the Bengal Renaissance in the 19th century. The trend of establishing libraries continued until the beginning of World War II. In 1854, four major public libraries were opened, including the Bogra Woodburn Library, the Rangpur Public Library, the Jessore Institute Public Library and the Barisal Public Library. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Northbrook_Hall" title="Northbrook Hall">Northbrook Hall Public Library</a> was established in Dhaka in 1882 in honour of <a href="/wiki/Lord_Northbrook" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Northbrook">Lord Northbrook</a>, the Governor-General. Other libraries established in the British period included the Victoria Public Library, Natore (1901), the Sirajganj Public Library (1882), the <a href="/wiki/Rajshahi_Public_Library" title="Rajshahi Public Library">Rajshahi Public Library</a> (1884), the Comilla Birchandra Library (1885), the Shah Makhdum Institute Public Library, Rajshahi (1891), the Noakhali Town Hall Public Library (1896), the Prize Memorial Library, Sylhet (1897), the Chittagong Municipality Public Library (1904) and the Varendra Research Library (1910). The Great Bengal Library Association was formed in 1925.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Central_Public_Library_(Dhaka)" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Public Library (Dhaka)">Central Public Library of Dhaka</a> was established in 1959. The <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Bangladesh" title="National Library of Bangladesh">National Library of Bangladesh</a> was established in 1972. The <a href="/wiki/Bishwo_Shahitto_Kendro" title="Bishwo Shahitto Kendro">World Literature Center</a>, founded by <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Magsaysay_Award" title="Ramon Magsaysay Award">Ramon Magsaysay Award</a> winner <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_Abu_Sayeed" title="Abdullah Abu Sayeed">Abdullah Abu Sayeed</a>, is noted for operating numerous <a href="/wiki/Mobile_library" class="mw-redirect" title="Mobile library">mobile libraries</a> across Bangladesh and was awarded the UNESCO Jon Amos Comenius Medal. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>

       </ul>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFrank_E._EyetsemitanJames_T._Gire2003" class="citation book cs1">Frank E.          <li id="cite_note-kumar-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-kumar_18-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRaj_Kumar2003" class="citation book cs1">Raj Kumar (2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=qvnjXOCjv7EC"><i>Essays on Ancient India</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-ray-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ray_19-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ray_19-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFIndrajit_Ray2011" class="citation book cs1">Indrajit Ray (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=CHOrAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA57"><i>Bengal Industries and the British Industrial Revolution (1757-1857)</i></a>. id%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh"          <li id="cite_note-riaj-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-riaj_30-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-riaj_30-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://persian.packhum.org/persian/pf?file=07601010&amp;ct=11">RIYAZU-S-SALÄTÄªN: A History of Bengal</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141215055926/http://persian.packhum.org/persian/pf?file=07601010&amp;ct=11">Archived</a> 15 December 2014 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghulam_Husain_Salim" title="Ghulam Husain Salim">Ghulam Husain Salim</a>, The Asiatic Society, Calcutta, 1902.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-31">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Land of Two Rivers, <a href="/wiki/Nitish_Sengupta" title="Nitish Sengupta">Nitish Sengupta</a></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAbu'l-Fazl" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Abu%27l-Fazl" class="mw-redirect" title="Abu'l-Fazl">Abu'l-Fazl</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ain-i-Akbari" title="Ain-i-Akbari"><i>Ain-i-Akbari</i></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ain-i-Akbari&amp;rft.au=Abu%27l-Fazl&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-33">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field%28DOCID+bd0014%29">"Bangladesh: early history, 1000&nbsp;B.C.âA.D. 1202"</a>. <i>Bangladesh: A country study</i>. Washington, DC: <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">Library of Congress</a>. September 1988. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131207010051/http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd%2Fcstdy%3A%40field%28DOCID+bd0014%29">Archived</a> from the original on 7 December 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 December</span> 2014</span>. <q>Historians believe that Bengal, the area comprising present-day Bangladesh and the Indian state of <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>, was settled in about 1000 B.C. by Dravidian-speaking peoples who were later known as the Bang. Their homeland bore various titles that reflected earlier tribal names, such as Vanga, Banga, Bangala, Bangal, and Bengal.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Bangladesh%3A+A+country+study&amp;rft.atitle=Bangladesh%3A+early+history%2C+1000+B.C.%E2%80%93A.D.+1202&amp;rft.date=1988-09&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmemory.loc.gov%2Fcgi-bin%2Fquery%2Fr%3Ffrd%2Fcstdy%3A%40field%2528DOCID%2Bbd0014%2529&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-auto4-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto4_34-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto4_34-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSenGupta2012" class="citation book cs1">SenGupta, Amitabh (2012). <i>Scroll Paintings of Bengal: Art in the Village</i>.          <li id="cite_note-auto3-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-auto3_35-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-auto3_35-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKeay2000" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/John_Keay" title="John Keay">Keay, John</a> (2000). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/indiahistory00keay/page/220"><i>India: A History</i></a></span>.          <li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGhosh2012" class="citation book cs1">Ghosh, Suchandra (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Pundravardhana">"Pundravardhana"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSteel2014" class="citation web cs1">Steel, Tim (19 December 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190517063054/https://www.dhakatribune.com/uncategorized/2014/12/19/the-paradise-of-nations">"The paradise of nations"</a>. Op-ed. <i>Dhaka Tribune</i>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.theodora.com/encyclopedia/e/eastern_bengal_and_assam.html">"Eastern Bengal and Assam â Encyclopedia"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-97">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKennedy2005" class="citation magazine cs1">Kennedy, Bernard (December 2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.diplomat.com.tr/sayilar/s14/yazilar/s14-3.htm">"Ambassador Rezaqul Haider: Mediating for commerce"</a>. <i>Diplomat</i>. Ankara, Turkey. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20171010140515/http://www.diplomat.com.tr/sayilar/s14/yazilar/s14-3.htm">Archived</a> from the original on 10 October 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 July</span> 2017</span>. <q>After the First World War when the great leader Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk started his war of independence, the people of Bengal were very spontaneous in giving all sorts of support. To the extent that there is evidence that the womenfolk donated their own bangles and gold ornaments, and the funds were used for the establishment of a bank, the construction of the parliament building and the purchase of armaments and ammunitions to help the war of liberation. As you know our national poet, Nazrul Islam, was the first foreigner to write an epic poem about Mustafa Kemal.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Diplomat&amp;rft.atitle=Ambassador+Rezaqul+Haider%3A+Mediating+for+commerce&amp;rft.date=2005-12&amp;rft.aulast=Kennedy&amp;rft.aufirst=Bernard&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.diplomat.com.tr%2Fsayilar%2Fs14%2Fyazilar%2Fs14-3.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-98">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/mar/29/winston-churchill-policies-contributed-to-1943-bengal-famine-study">"Churchill's policies contributed to 1943 Bengal famine â study"</a>. <i>The Guardian</i>. 29 March 2019.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Guardian&amp;rft.atitle=Churchill%27s+policies+contributed+to+1943+Bengal+famine+%E2%80%93+study&amp;rft.date=2019-03-29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fworld%2F2019%2Fmar%2F29%2Fwinston-churchill-policies-contributed-to-1943-bengal-famine-study&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Mukherjee1987-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Mukherjee1987_99-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Benvenisti2012-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Benvenisti2012_127-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Benvenisti2012_127-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBenvenisti2012" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Eyal_Benvenisti" title="Eyal Benvenisti">Benvenisti, Eyal</a> (2012) [First published 1992]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=f19hVb54_s8C&amp;pg=PA190"><i>The International Law of Occupation</i></a> (2nd&nbsp;ed.). Oxford University Press. p.&nbsp;190. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-163957-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-163957-9"><bdi>978-0-19-163957-9</bdi></a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170214220204/https://books.google.com/books?id=f19hVb54_s8C&amp;pg=PA190">Archived</a> from the original on 14 February 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>The genuine and widely recognized claim for Bangladeshi self-determination as an entity independent of West Pakistan, coupled with the repulsion caused by the Pakistani measures to suppress that claim convinced global public opinion ... By the time its admission for membership in the United Nations came before the Security Council, in August 1972, Bangladesh had already been recognized by eighty-six countries.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+International+Law+of+Occupation&amp;rft.pages=190&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-163957-9&amp;rft.aulast=Benvenisti&amp;rft.aufirst=Eyal&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Df19hVb54_s8C%26pg%3DPA190&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-128">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-160"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-160">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2010/01/25/rangpur-becomes-a-division">"Rangpur becomes a divivion"</a>. bdnews24.com. 25 January 2010. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150903184553/http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2010/01/25/rangpur-becomes-a-division">Archived</a> from the original on 3 September 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-175"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-175">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGlennon" class="citation web cs1">Glennon, Robert. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/the-unfolding-tragedy-of-climate-change-in-bangladesh/">"The Unfolding Tragedy of Climate Change in Bangladesh"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20171201040750/https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/the-unfolding-tragedy-of-climate-change-in-bangladesh/">Archived</a> from the original on 1 December 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-189">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-dw.com-245"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-dw.com_245-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-dw.com_245-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2018/10/02/economic-reforms-can-make-bangladesh-grow-faster">"Economic Reforms Can Make Bangladesh Grow Faster"</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Economic+Reforms+Can+Make+Bangladesh+Grow+Faster&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldbank.org%2Fen%2Fnews%2Fpress-release%2F2018%2F10%2F02%2Feconomic-reforms-can-make-bangladesh-grow-faster&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-JMP-296"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-JMP_296-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">* 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWorld_Health_OrganizationUNICEF" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>; UNICEF. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080216075751/http://www.wssinfo.org/">"Joint Monitoring Program"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-rashiduzzaman-313"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-rashiduzzaman_313-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-330"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-330">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-349"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-349">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/06/16/bangladeshs-literacy-rate-rises-to-70-percent-education-minister-says">"Bangladesh's literacy rate rises to 70 percent, education minister says"</a>. <i>bdnews24</i>. 16 June 2015. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150616193252/http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/06/16/bangladeshs-literacy-rate-rises-to-70-percent-education-minister-says">Archived</a> from the original on 16 June 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-FHS_Research_Brief_2-350"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FHS_Research_Brief_2_350-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FHS_Research_Brief_2_350-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBhuiya2009" class="citation journal cs1">Bhuiya, Abbas (June 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/fhs-bangladesh-research-brief-2-costs-of-utilizing-healthcar.html">"Costs of utilizing healthcare services in Chakaria, a rural area in Bangladesh"</a>. <i>FHS Research Brief</i> (2). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20121116060704/http://www.futurehealthsystems.org/publications/fhs-bangladesh-research-brief-2-costs-of-utilizing-healthcar.html">Archived</a> from the original on 16 November 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Kube Publishing Ltd. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84774-052-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-84774-052-6"><bdi>978-1-84774-052-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Muslim+Heritage+of+Bengal%3A+The+Lives%2C+Thoughts+and+Achievements+of+Great+Muslim+Scholars%2C+Writers+and+Reformers+of+Bangladesh+and+West+Bengal&amp;rft.pub=Kube+Publishing+Ltd&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-84774-052-6&amp;rft.aulast=Mojlum+Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Muhammad&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABangladesh" class="Z3988"></span></li> 
        <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><i>Religion, identity &amp; politics: essays on Bangladesh</i>.          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSogra2014" class="citation book cs1">Sogra, Khair Jahan (2014). <i>The Impact of Gender Differences on the Conflict Management Styles of Managers in Bangladesh: An Analysis</i>.          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFUmar2006" class="citation book cs1">Umar, Badruddin (2006). <i>The Emergence of Bangladesh: Rise of Bengali nationalism, 1958â1971</i>.                   </ul></li>
